div.p: TO JOEL BARLOW, ESQ. AS A TRIBUTE DUE TO HIS BENEVOLENCE, AND A MEMENTO OF HIS UNREMITTED EXERTIONS IN RESCUING OUR FELLOW-CITIZENS FROM BONDAGE, THE FOLLOWING WORK IS RESPECTFULLY INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR.

div.head: PREFACE.

p.hi: AFRICA, though contiguous to the mo≈øt commercial nations in the world, from whom one would naturally ≈øuppo≈øe it might derive ≈øome portion of refinement, is yet involved in a ≈øtate of the mo≈øt deplorable barbari≈øm; and its very atmo≈øphere ≈øeems fraught with the mo≈øt dete≈øtable depravity in human nature. Hence the ≈øpirit of di≈øcovery will ever be retarded, and travellers will have but little inducement to explore a region where they mu≈øt be expo≈øed to ≈øuch a con≈øtant ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of dangers.

Since the de≈øtruction of Carthage, civilization ≈øeems not an attribute of the kingdom of Algiers, or of any of the ≈øtates of Barbary; and ≈øuch is the virulence of Mahometan antipathy to every thing that bears the name of Chri≈øtian, that their contiguous to Europe has perhaps tended to render them even more ferocious.

In rendering an account of this famous regency who have ≈øo long ≈øignali≈øed them≈øelves by their villany, the
author has av ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed him≈øelf of the mo≈øt unexceptionable documents that could be procured, and per≈øpicuity in≈øtead of elegance and the complete developement of TRUTH have been his primary objects in the compilation of the work.

In its execution he has laboured under ≈øeveral di≈øadvantages. The fir≈øt ≈øheets were put to pre≈øs but a few days after the work was commenced, and before half the materials were collected. Great expedition was therefore indi≈øpen≈øibly requi≈øite, and this circum≈øtance will apologize for inaccuracies or de≈øultory arrangements.

The work is, however, much more perfect than was originally contemplated. It exhibits a more circum≈øtantial detail of Algerine affairs of a recent date than was ever before publi≈øhed, and will we pre≈øume afford the American reader a tolerable idea of this famous piratical regency, to which the United States have lately had the mortification of becoming tributory.

It comprehends, be≈øides an ample account of the late American negociation, a variety of original ob≈øervations upon the government, fortifications, cu≈øtoms and manners, puni≈øhments, religion, &c. of the Algerines; and for this original matter the public are under con≈øiderable obligations to Mr. ISAAC BROOKS, a gentleman of veracity and intelligence, who was one of the unfortunate number who were ≈øubjected to the mi≈øeries of this unparalleled ≈øervitude. The ≈øeverity of his afflictions
has reduced him nearly to a ≈øtate of blindne≈øs; a misfortune which afforded him ample lei≈øure for rendering a more minute account. In all his communications he has con≈øcientiou≈øly adhered to the truth, detected mi≈ørepre≈øentations, and related nothing but what will bear the te≈øt of the ≈øtricte≈øt examination.

The ≈øubject is particularly intere≈øting to the American people, and as the author has recorded events which are recent in the memory of all the captives, he has been ≈øcrupulou≈øly circum≈øpect in admitting nothing but matters of undi≈øputed authenticity.

div.p: The la≈øt chapter is an ab≈øtract or compendium of the adventures of Emanuel D'Aranda, "a poor ≈øoldier" as he was plea≈øed to call him≈øelf, probably with a de≈øign to evade the payment of the exorbitant ≈øum demanded for the ran≈øom of all per≈øons of quality. We find, however, by a Latin eulogium in ver≈øe prefixed to the French edition of his work, that he is called nobili con≈øulti≈ø≈øimoque Emanueli D'Aranda, I. V. L.

The≈øe adventures were written above 150 years ago, and are now perhaps unknown in the literary world. In this work there is every appearance of candor, and the concurrence of various circum≈øtances corroborate the pre≈øumption of its truth.

argument.p: The Phoenicians and Carthagenians the original inhabitants. De≈øtruction of Carthage. Expul≈øion of the Romans by the Vandals. Irruption of the Saracens. Arab princes ≈øubdued. Zeneti de≈øtroyed. Succeeded by the Shariffs of H ‚Ä¢ ≈øcen. In danger from the Spaniards. Barbaro≈ø≈øa invited. His treachery and cruelty. I ‚Ä¢ defeated and killed by the Spaniards.

div.p: THERE is perhaps no problem in hi≈øtory ≈øo ≈øingular and unaccountable as the decadence of the power and ≈øplendor of the exten≈øive States of Barbary; which, while Carthage was in the meridian of its glory, were the ≈øeat of unrivalled greatne≈øs, and anterior ≈øo Rome it≈øelf in arts, in ≈øcience, in magnificence and refinement.

The original inhabitants of this country, according to the mo≈øt authentic hi≈øtorians, were the Phoenecians, and after them the Carthagenians, the
formidable rivals of the Romans, and one of the mo≈øt warlike nations of antiquity. The beginning of the Carthagenian hi≈øtory, like that of all other nations, is extremely ob≈øcure and uncertain. In the 7th year of Pygmalion king of Tyre, his ≈øi≈øter Eliza, or Dido, is ≈øaid to have fled, with ≈øome of her companions and va≈ø≈øals, from the cruelty and avarice of her brother Sichaeus.

She fir≈øt touched at the i≈øland of Cyprus, where ≈øhe met with a prie≈øt of Jupiter, who was de≈øirous of attending her; to which ≈øhe con≈øented. At that time it was a cu≈øtom in the i≈øland of Cyprus, for the young women to go, on certain ≈øtated days before marriage, to the ≈øea-≈øide, and there to look for ≈øtrangers, that might po≈ø≈øibly arrive on their coa≈øts, in order to pro≈øtitute them≈øelves for gain, that they might thereby acquire a dowry. Out of the≈øe women, the Tyrians ≈øelected eighty, whom they carried along with them, and then ≈øailed directly for the coa≈øt of Africa: and at la≈øt ≈øafely landed in the province called Africa Propria, not far from Utica, a Phoenician city of great antiquity. The common fable is, that the Phoenecians impo≈øed upon the Africans in the following manner: They de≈øired for their intended ≈øettlement, only as much ground as an ox's hide would encompa≈øs. This reque≈øt the Africans laughed at; but they were ≈øurprized when, upon granting it, they ≈øaw Eliza cut the hide into the ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øhreds, by which means it ≈øurrounded a large territory; in which ≈øhe built the citadel called Byr≈øa. The learned, however, explode this fable; but it is certain that the Carthagenians for many years paid an annual tribute to the Africans for the ground they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed.

From this period commences the hi≈øtory of the Carthagenians, one of the mo≈øt celebrated nations of
antiquity, who≈øe armies under the command of Hannibal, and other eminent generals, invaded the Roman territory, and threatened the downfal of Rome it≈øelf. But it is not the de≈øign of the pre≈øent work to enter into a detail of this hi≈øtory, which would form of it≈øelf a large and intere≈øting volume.

The city of Carthage, by order of the Roman Senate, was plundered and de≈øtroyed by the Roman army under AEmilianus. Before he proceeded to execute their order, he performed tho≈øe religious ceremonies which were required on ≈øuch occa≈øions. He fir≈øt ≈øacrificed to the gods, and then cau≈øed a plough to be drawn round the walls of the city. After this, the towers, rampa ‚Ä¢ ts, walls, and all the works which the Carthagenians had rai≈øed in the cour≈øe of many ages, were levelled with the ground. The edifices of this proud metropolis were ≈øet on fire, which con≈øumed them all, not a ≈øingle hou≈øe e≈øcaping the flames. The ≈øire began in all quarters of the city at the ≈øame time, and continued to burn with incredible fury for the ≈øpace of ≈øeventeen days, at the end of which time the whole city was reduced to a≈øhes.

Thus ≈øell Carthage, about 146 years before the birth of Chri≈øt. The trea≈øure carried off ‚Ä¢ y AEmilianus, even after it was plundered by the ≈øoldiers, according to the computation of Pliny, amounted to 4,470,000 pounds weight of ≈øilver. About twenty-four years after this event C. Gracchus undertook to rebuild it. Maxentius laid it in a≈øhes about the ≈øixth or ≈øeventh year of Con≈øtantine's reign, and Gen≈øeric, king of the Vandals, ‚Ä¢ ook it in the year 4 ‚Ä¢ 0 after Chri≈øt; but about a century afterwards it was re-annexed to the Roman empire by the renowned Beli≈øarius. At la≈øt the Saracens, under Mahomet's ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, towards the clo≈øe of the ≈øeventh
century, ≈øo completely de≈øtroyed it, that there are now ≈øcarce any ve≈øtiges of it remaining.

After the reduction of the Carthagenian empire, the Romans for a long time maintained their power in Africa. But in the year 426, Bonifacius ≈øupreme governor of all the Roman dominions in this quarter, being compelled to revolt by the treachery of another general called Aetius, and finding him≈øelf unable to contend with the whole ≈øtrength of the Roman empire, invited Gen≈øeric king of the Vandals to his aid; who thereupon abandoned his conque≈øts in Europe, and pa≈ø≈øed over into Africa. Bonifacius, however, being ≈øoon after reconciled to his empre≈øs Placidia, endeavoured in vain to per≈øuade the Vandals to retire. Hereupon a war en≈øued, in which the barbarians proved victorious, and quickly over-ran all the Roman provinces in Africa. In the year 435, a peace was concluded; whereby Numidia and ≈øome other countries were ceded to the Vandals, who ≈øoon after ≈øeized the re≈øt. But the≈øe barbarians did not long enjoy their conque≈øts: for about the year 535, Beli≈øarus, the Greek emperor Ju≈øtinian's general, drove them out, and annexed the provinces to the ea≈øtern empire.

In the years 647, the Saracens, having conquered Me≈øopotamia, Egypt, Phoenicia, Arabia and Palestine, broke like a torrent into Africa, which they quickly ≈øubdued. This la≈øt revolution happened about the middle of the ≈øeventh century; and the Arabs continued ma≈øters of the country till the year 1051. This year, one Abubeker-ben-Omar, or as the Spaniards call him, Abu-Texe≈øien, an Arab of the Zinhagian tribe, being provoked at the tyranny of tho≈øe de≈øpots, gathered, by the help of his marabouts or ≈øaints, a mo≈øt powerful army of malcontents, in the ≈øouthern provinces of Numidia and Lybia. His followers were nick-named
Marabites or Morabites; by the Spaniards Almoravides; probably from their being a≈ø≈øembled principally by the ≈øaints, who were al≈øo called Morabites. The khalif of Keyem's forces were at this time engaged in quelling other revolts in Syria, Me≈øopotamia, &c. and the Arabs in Spain entered into the mo≈øt bloody wars; ≈øo that Texe≈øien having nothing to fear from them, had all the ≈øucce≈øs ‚Ä¢ e could wi≈øh again≈øt the Arabian cheyks or petty tyrants, whom he defeated in many battles, and at la≈øt drove them not only out of Numidia and Lybi ‚Ä¢ , but out of all the we≈øtern parts, reducing the whole province of Tingitania under his dominion.

Texe≈øien was ≈øucceeded by his ≈øon Yu≈øef, or Jo≈øeph, who was a warlike prince. In the beginning of his reign he laid the foundation of the city of Morocco, which he intended as the capital of his empire During the building of this city he ≈øent an emba≈ø≈øy of marabouts to Treme≈øen, a province of Algiers, for the purpo≈øe of re≈øtoring the Zeneti, a Mahometan ≈øect, to the true faith, as it was called. But the Zeneti contemning all overtures of this nature, a≈ø≈øembled at „Äà‚óä„Äâ , or Amfa their capital, and murdered the amba≈ø≈øadors. Not content with this act of outrage and in≈øolence, they invaded Jo≈øeph's dominions with an army of 50,000 men.

Jo≈øeph ju≈øtly exa≈øperated at the≈øe proceedings, levied an army with all po≈ø≈øible expedition, invaded their territory, and de≈øtroyed all before him with ‚Ä¢ ire and ≈øword. The Zeneti in≈øtead of repelling the inva≈øion, retreated towards Fez, where they expected a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. But they were fatally di≈øappointed in this expectation; for the Fezz ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s marched out again≈øt them, and meeting the mi≈øerable Zeneti, encumbered with their families and baggage, and ready to expire with hunger and fatigue,
fell upon them and cut them all to pieces, except a few who were either drowned in their attempts to ≈øwim acro≈øs a river, or da≈øhed to pieces from the precipices of rocks to which their enemy had pur≈øued them.

In the mean time the march of Jo≈øeph's army was marked by havoc and de≈øolation; the territory of the unhappy Zeneti was de≈øolated and reduced to a heap of ≈ømoking ruins. Their country was, however, ≈øoon after re-peopled by numerous immigrations of Fezzans, who formed colonies under the protection of the reigning princes. According to the mo≈øt authentic accounts it appears, that nearly a millon of men, women and children, of the Zeneti, lo≈øt their lives in this murderous campaign.

Jo≈øeph, who was a prince of re≈øtle≈øs ambition, was not long di≈øpo≈øed for peace. He proclaimed war again≈øt the Fezzans whom ‚Ä¢ e rendered tributory, and extended his conque≈øts along the coa≈øts of the Mediterranean. His next attack was upon ≈øome Arabian cheyks, whom he pur≈øued through the Lybian de≈øarts with ≈øuch fury, that neither the clifts of the mo≈øt craggy rocks, nor ≈øecret rece≈ø≈øes, afforded them ≈øhelter from the vengeance of their pur≈øuers. He reduced all their ca≈øtles and fortre≈ø≈øes, which till then were deemed impregnable, and the extent of his conque≈øts ≈øpread general con≈øternation and grief through the other nations of Africa.

Thus was the empire of the Morabites founded; but its exi≈øtance was of ≈øhort duration; for they were expelled from their new po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions in the 12th century by Mohavedin a marabout. This race of prie≈øts was ≈øubdued by Abdulac, governor of Fez, who was dive≈øted in his turn of his new conque≈øta, in the 13th century, by the Shariffs of Ha≈øcen, who
were the de≈øcendants of tho≈øe Arabian princes whom Abu-Texe ‚Ä¢ ien had formerly conquered.

The Shariffs divided their new acquired domions into ≈øeveral petty provinces, and the kingdom of Algiers was divided into Treme≈øen, Tenez, Algiers Proper, and Bujeyah, for their greater ≈øecurity again≈øt the inva≈øions of neighbouring princes. The four fir≈øt monarchs laid ≈øo ≈øolid a foundation to their empire, by a judicious balance of power, that they continued in mutual peace and harmony for ≈øeveral ≈øucceeding centuries; but the king of Treme≈øen having violated ≈øome articles of their compact, Abul-Farez declared war again≈øt him, and reduced Treme≈øen to a tributory kingdom.

Abul-Farez did not long ≈øurvive this event. His kingdom was divided among his three ≈øons, and mutual di≈øcord and animo≈øity was the con≈øequence of this divi≈øion. Debilitated by the≈øe commotions, they became an ea≈øy conque≈øt to the Spani≈øh government, who tran≈øported a powerful fleet and army again≈øt Barbary, under the command of the Count of Navarre, in the year 1505. This commander ≈øoon completed the conque≈øt of Oran, Bujeyah, and other important cities; which ≈øpread ≈øuch an alarm among the Algerines, that they invited the protection of Selim Eutemi, an Arabian prince renowned for the prowe≈øs of his arms. He came to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance with a large army of his mo≈øt warlike ≈øubjects, attended by Zaphira his queen, and a ≈øon about twelve years of age. This force was not, however, ≈øufficient to repel the incur≈øions of the Spaniards; they effected the landing of an army the ≈øame year near the city of Algiers, and compelled the metropolis to become tributory to Spain. Nor could all the powers of Eutemi prevent the e≈øtabli≈øhment of a formidable Spani≈øh garri≈øon of 200 men on the i≈øland,
in front of the city, which did immen≈øe damage to the cor≈øairs that attempted to ≈øail either in or out of the harbour.

div.p: THE Algerines continued to pro≈øecute their piracies with impunity, to the terror and di≈øgrace of the European powers, till the year 1652; when a French fleet being accidently driven into Algiers, the admiral took it into his head to demand a relea≈øe of all the captives of his nation, without exception. Her exten≈øive commerce with Europe pre≈øented a ≈øplendid allurement to the pirates, who were well aware that the prevention of their aggre≈ø≈øions would require a naval armament greatly ≈øuperior to the ≈øub≈øtantial benefits that could be derived from an attempt to reduce them to ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion. The hour of four in the afternoon is called lazar, at which time a white flag is hoi≈øted upon the tops of all the mo≈øques in the city, as a ≈øignal for the inhabitants to quit their labour, and repair to public wor≈øhip. div.head: A TREATY OF PEACE AND AMITY CONCLUDED SEPTEMBER 5, 1795, BETWEEN HASSAN BASHAW, DEY OF ALGIERS, HIS DIVAN AND SUBJECTS; AND GEORGE WASHINGTON, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF NORTH AMERICA, AND THE CITIZENS OF THE SAID UNITED STATES: WITH THE PRESIDENT'S PROCLAMATION, ANNOUNCING ITS RATIFICATION.

div.p:
WHEREAS a Treaty of Peace and Amity has been concluded in the manner herein after mentioned, by the Plenipotentiary of the United States of America, and the Dey and Regency of Algiers; which Treaty, written in the Arabic language, being tran≈ølated into the language of the United States, is in the words following, to wit: "A Treaty of Peace and Amity concluded this pre≈øent Day Iima arta≈øi, the twenty-fir≈øt of the Luna ≈øafer year of the Hegira 1210, corre≈øponding with Saturday the fifth of September, one thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred and ninety-five, between HASSAN BASHAW, Dey of Algiers, his Divan and ≈øubjects, and GEORGE WASHINGTON, Pre≈øident
of the United States of North America, and the citizens of the ≈øaid United States.

ARTICLE 1≈øt. From the date of the pre≈øent treaty, there ≈øhall ≈øub≈øi≈øt a firm and ≈øincere peace and amity between the PRESIDENT and citizens of the United States of North America, and HASSAN BASHAW, Dey of Algiers, his Divan and ≈øubjects; the ve≈ø≈øels and ≈øubjects of both nations reciprocally treating each other with civility, honor and re≈øpect.

ARTICLE the 2d. All ve≈ø≈øels belonging to the citizens of the United States of North America, ≈øhall be permitted to enter the different ports of the Regency, to trade with our ≈øubjects, or any other per≈øons re≈øiding within our juri≈ødiction, on paying the u≈øual duties at our cu≈øtom hou≈øe that are paid by all nations at peace with this Regency; ob≈øerving that all goods di≈øembarked and not ≈øold here ≈øhall be permitted to be reimbarked without paying any duty whatever, either for di≈øembarking or embarking. All naval and military ≈øtores, ≈øuch as gunpowder, lead, iron, plank, ≈øulphur, timber for building, tar, pitch, ro≈øin, turpentine, and any other goods ‚Ä¢ enominated naval and military ≈øtores, ≈øhall be permitted to be ≈øold in this Regency, without paying any duties whatever at the cu≈øtom hou≈øe of this Regency.

ARTICLE 3d. The ve≈ø≈øels of both nations ≈øhall pa≈øs each other without any impediment or mole≈øtation; and all goods, m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ies or pa≈ø≈øengers, of what≈øoever nation, that may be on board of the ve≈ø≈øels belonging to either party ≈øhall be con≈øidered as inviolable, and ≈øhall be allowed to pa≈øs unmole≈øted.

ARTICLE 4th. All ≈øhips of war belonging to this Regency, on meeting with merchant ve≈ø≈øels belonging to citizens of the United States, ≈øhall be allowed to vi≈øit them with two per≈øons only be≈øide the rowers;‚Äîthe≈øe two only permitted to go on
board ≈øaid ve≈ø≈øel, without obtaining expre≈øs leave from the commander of ≈øaid ve≈ø≈øel, who ≈øhall compare the pa≈ø≈øport, and immediately permit ≈øaid ve≈ø≈øel to proceed on her voyage unmole≈øted. All ≈øhips of w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ belonging to the United States of North America, on meeting with an Algerine crui≈øer, and ≈øhall have ≈øeen her pa≈ø≈øport and certificate from the Con≈øul of the United States of North America, re≈øident in this Regency, ≈øhall be permitted to proceed on her crui≈øe unmole≈øted: no pa≈ø≈øport to be i≈ø≈øued to any ≈øhips but ≈øuch as are ab≈øolutely the property of citizens of the United States: and eighteen months ≈øhall be the term allowed for furni≈øhing the ≈øhips of the United States with pa≈ø≈øports.

ARTICLE 5th. No commander of any crui≈øer belonging to this regency, ≈øhall be allowed to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ke any per≈øon, of whatever nation or denomination, out of any ve≈ø≈øel belonging to the United States of North America, in order to examine them, or under pretence of making them confe≈øs any thing defired; neither ≈øhall they inflict any corporal puni≈øhment, or any way el≈øe mole≈øt them.

ARTICLE 6th. If any ve≈ø≈øel belonging to the United States of North America, ≈øhall be ≈øtranded on the coa≈øt of this Regency, they ≈øhall receive every po≈ø≈øible a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from the ≈øubjects of this Regency: all goods ≈øaved from the wreck ≈øhall be permitted to be reimbarked on board of any other ve≈ø≈øel, without paying any duties at the cu≈øtom hou≈øe.

ARTICLE 7th. The Algerines are not, on any pretence whatever, to give or ≈øell any ve≈ø≈øel of war to any nation at war with the United States of North America, or any ve≈ø≈øel capable of crui≈øing to the detriment of the commerce of the United States.

ARTICLE the 8th. Any citizen of the United States of North America, having bought any prize condemned by the Algerines, ≈øhall not be again captured by the crui≈øers of the Regency the ‚Ä¢ at ≈øea, although they have not a pa≈ø≈øport; and certificate from the Con≈øul re≈øident being deemed ≈øufficient, until ≈øuch time they can procure ≈øuch pa≈ø≈øport.

ARTICLE the 9th. If any of the Barbary ≈øtates at war with the United States of North America, ≈øhall capture any American ve≈ø≈øel and bring her into any of the ports of this Regency, they ≈øhall not be permitted to ≈øell her, but ≈øhall depart the port on procuring the requi≈øite ≈øupplies of provi≈øion.

ARTICLE the 10th. Any ve≈ø≈øel belonging to the United States of North America, when at war with any other nation, ≈øhall be permitted to ≈øend their prizes into the ports of the Regency, have leave to di≈øpo≈øe of them, without paying any duties on ≈øale thereof. All ve≈ø≈øels wanting provi≈øions or refre≈øhments, ≈øhall be permitted to buy them at market price.

ARTICLE the 11th. All ≈øhips of war belonging to the United States of North America, on anchoring in the ports of the Regency, ≈øhall receive the u≈øual pre≈øents of provi≈øions and refre≈øhments, gratis. Should any of the ≈ølaves of this Regency make their e≈øcape on board ≈øaid ve≈ø≈øels, they ≈øhall be immediately returned: No excu≈øe ≈øhall be made that they have hid them≈øelves among≈øt the people and cannot be found, or any other equivocation.

ARTICLE the 12th. No citizen of the United States of North America, ≈øhall be obliged to redeem any ≈ølave again≈øt his will, even ≈øhould he be his brother: neither ≈øhall the owner of a ≈ølave be forced to ≈øell him again≈øt his will: but all ≈øuch agreements mu≈øt be made by con≈øent of parties.
Should any American citizen be taken on board an enemy-≈øhip, by the crui≈øers of this Regency, having a regular pa≈ø≈øport, ≈øpecifying they are citizens of the United States, they ≈øhall be immediately ≈øet „Äà‚óä„Äâ liberty. On the contrary, they having no pa≈ø≈øport, they and their property ≈øhall be con≈øidered lawful prize; as this Regency know their friends by their pa≈ø≈øports.

ARTICLE the 13th. Should any of the citizens of the United States of North America die within the limits of this Regency, the Dey and his ≈øubjects ≈øhall not interfere with the property of the decea≈øed; but it ≈øhall be under the immediate direction of the con≈øul; unle≈øs otherwi≈øe di≈øpo≈øed of by will. Should there be no con≈øul, the effects ≈øhall be depo≈øited in the hands of ≈øome per≈øon worthy of tru≈øt, until the party ≈øhall appear who has a right to demand them; when they ≈øhall render an account of the property. Neither ≈øhall the Dey or Divan give hindrance in the execution of any will that may appear.

ARTICLE the 14th. No citizen of the United States of North America, ≈øhall be obliged to purcha≈øe any goods again≈øt his will; but on the contrary, ≈øhall be allowed to purcha≈øe whatever it plea≈øeth him. The con≈øul of the United States of North America, or any other citizen, ≈øhall not be amenable for debts contracted by any one of their own nation; unle≈øs previou≈øly they have given a written obligation ≈øo to do. Should the Dey want to freight any American ve≈ø≈øel that may be in the Regency, or Turkey, ≈øaid ve≈ø≈øel not being engaged; in con≈øequence of the friend≈øhip ≈øub≈øi≈øting between the two nations, he expects to have the preference given him, on his paying the ≈øame freight offered by any other nation.

ARTICLE the 15th. Any di≈øputes or ≈øuits at law, that may take place between the ≈øubjects of the Regency and the citizens of the United States of North America, ≈øhall be decided by the Dey in a po ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on, and no other. Any di≈øputes that may ari≈øe between the citizens of the United States, ≈øhall be decided by the con≈øul; as they are in ≈øuch ca≈øes not ≈øubject to the laws of this Regency.

ARTICLE the 16th. Should any citizen of the United States of North America, kill, wound, or ≈øtrike a ≈øubject of this Regency, he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed in the ≈øame manner as a Turk, and not with more ≈øeverity. Should any citizen of the United States of North America, in the above predicament, e≈øcape pri≈øon, the con≈øul ≈øhall not become an≈øwerable for him.

ARTICLE the 17th. The Con≈øul of the United States of North America, ≈øhall have every per≈øonal ≈øecurity given him and his hou≈øehold: he ≈øhall have liberty to exerci≈øe his religion in his own hou≈øe. All ≈ølaves of the ≈øame religion ≈øhall not be impeded in going to ≈øaid Con≈øul's hou≈øe, at hours of prayer. The Con≈øul ≈øhall have liberty and per≈øonal ≈øecurity given him to travel whenever he plea≈øes, within the Regency: he ≈øhall have free licence to go on board any ve≈ø≈øel lying in our roads, whenever he ≈øhall think fit. The Con≈øul ≈øhall have leave to appoint his own Drogaman and Broker.

ARTICLE the 18th. Should a war break out between the two nations, the Con≈øul of the United States of North America, and all citizens of North America, and all citizens of ≈øaid States, ≈øhall have leave to embark them≈øelves and property unmole≈øted, on board of what ve≈ø≈øel or ve≈ø≈øels they ≈øhall think proper.

ARTICLE he 19th. Should the crui≈øers of Algiers capture any ve≈ø≈øel, having citizens of the
United States of North America on board, they having papers to prove they are really ≈øo, they and their property ≈øhall be immediately di≈øcharged. And ≈øhould the ve≈ø≈øels of the United States capture any ve≈ø≈øels of nations at war with them, having ≈øubjects of this Regency on board, they ≈øhall be treated in like manner.

ARTICLE the 20th. On a ve≈ø≈øel of war belonging to the United States of North America anchoring in our ports, the Con≈øul is to inform the Dey of her arrival; and ≈øhe ≈øhall be ≈øaluted with twenty-one guns; which ≈øhe is to return in the ≈øame quantity or number. And the Dey will ≈øend fre≈øh provi≈øions on board, as is cu≈øtomary, gratis.
ARTICLE the 21≈øt. The Con≈øul of the United States of North America, ≈øhall not be required to pay duty for any thing he brings from a foreign country for the u≈øe of his hou≈øe and family.

ARTICLE the 22d. Should any di≈øturbance take place between the citizens of the United States and the ≈øubjects of this Regency, or break any article of this treaty, war ≈øhall not be declared immediately; but every thing ≈øhall be ≈øearched into regularly: the party injured ≈øhall be made reparation.

On the 21≈øt of the Luna of Safer. 1210, corre≈øponding with the 5th September 1795, JOSEPH DONALDSON, jun. on the part of the United States of North America, agreed with HASSAN BASHAW, Dey of Algiers, to keep the articles contained in this treaty ≈øacred and inviolable; which we the Dey and Divan promi≈øe to ob≈øerve, on con≈øideration of the United States paying annually the value of twelve thou≈øand Algerine ≈øequins in maritime ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ores. Should the United States forward a larger ‚Ä¢ quantity, the overplus ≈øhall be paid for in money, by the Dey and Regency. Any ve≈ø≈øel that may be captured

TREATY OF PEACE AND FRIENDSHIP Between the United States of America and the Bey and Subjects of Tripoli-of Barbary.

ARTICLE 1≈øt. There is a firm and perpetual peace and friend≈øhip between the United States of America, and the bey and ≈øubjects of Tripoli of Barbary, made by the free con≈øent of both parties, and guaranteed by the Mo≈øt Potent Dey and Regency of Algiers.

ARTICLE 2d. If any goods belonging to any nation with which either of the parties is at war, ≈øhall be loaded on board of ve≈ø≈øels belonging to the other ‚Ä¢ arty, they ≈øhall pa≈øs free, and no attempt ≈øhall be made to take or detain them.

ARTICLE 3. If any citizen, ≈øubjects or effects belonging to either party ≈øhall be found on board a
prize ve≈ø≈øel taken from an enemy by the other party, ≈øuch citizens or ≈øubjects ≈øhall be ≈øet at liberty, and the effects re≈øtored to the owners.

ARTICLE 4. Proper pa≈ø≈øports are to be given to all ve≈ø≈øels of both parties, by which they are to be known. And con≈øidering the di≈øtance between the two countries, eighteen months from the date of this treaty ≈øhall be allowed for procuring ≈øuch pa≈ø≈øports. ARTICLE 5th. ARTICLE 6. Ve≈ø≈øels of either party putting into the ports of the other, and having need of provi≈øions or other ≈øupplies, they ≈øhall be furni≈øhed at the market price. And if any ≈øuch ve≈ø≈øel ≈øhall ≈øo put in from a di≈øa≈øter at ≈øea, and have occa≈øion to repair, ≈øhe ≈øhall be at liberty to land and reimbark her cargo, without paying any duties. ARTICLE 7. ARTICLE 9. ARTICLE 10th. The money and pre≈øents demanded by the Bey of Tripoli, as a full and ≈øatisfactory con≈øideration on his part, and on the part of his ≈øubjects, for this treaty of perpetual peace and friend≈øhip, are acknowledged to have been received by him previous to his ≈øigning the ≈øame, according to a receipt which is hereto annexed, except ≈øuch part as is promi≈øed on the part of the United States to be delivered and paid by them on the arrival of their Con≈øul in Tripoli, of which part a note is likewi≈øe hereto annexed. ARTICLE 11th. As the government of the United States of America is not in any ≈øen≈øe founded on the Chri≈øtian religion, as it has in it≈øelf no character of enmity again≈øt the laws, religion or tranquility of Mu≈ø≈øelmen‚Äîand as the ≈øaid ≈øtates have never entered into any war or act of ho≈øtility again≈øt any Mahomedan nation, it is declared by the parties, that no pretext ari≈øing from religious opinions

div.p: DESCRIPTION OF ALGIERS; COMPREHENDING AN AMPLE ACCOUNT OF ITS TERRITORY AND INHABITANTS.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: Its divi≈øion; rivers, ≈øoil, climate, and productions; animals, antiquities and curi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ities; inhabitants, cu≈øtoms and manners; dre≈øs, language, cor≈øairs and commerce; revenues, government, puni≈øhments and religion.

div.p: THE kingdom of Algiers is ≈øituated between 32 and 37 degrees of north latitude, which corre≈øponds to that of the United States from near the ≈øouthern boundary of Virginia to near the river Savannah in Georgia, and between 76 and 84 degrees 20 minutes ea≈øt longitude from Philadelphia. It extends 480 miles in length from ea≈øt to we≈øt along the northern coa≈øt of Africa, and 320 miles in breadth from north to ≈øouth. It is bounded by the Mediterranean on the north, by the kingdom of Tunis on the ea≈øt, by mount Atlas on the ≈øouth, and by the river Mulvia, which ≈øeparates it from the empire of Morocco, on the we≈øt, At the di≈øtance of 120 miles from the ≈øea-coa≈øt, that part of Africa becomes a barren d ‚Ä¢ ≈øart, almo≈øt entirely uninhabitable either by man or bea≈øt.

This country derives its name from its metropolis, and is at pre≈øent divided into three provinces or di≈øtricts, viz. the ea≈øtern, we≈øtern, and ≈øouthern.
The ea≈øtern, or Levantine government, which is by far the mo≈øt con≈øiderable of the three, and is al≈øo called Beylick, contains the towns of Bona, Con≈øtantina, Gigeri, Bugia, Steffa, Tebef, Zamoura, Bi≈øcara, and Necanz, in all which the Turks have their garri≈øons: be≈øides which, it includes the two ancient kingdoms of Cuco and Labez, though independent of the Algerine government, to who≈øe forces their country is inacce≈ø≈øible; ≈øo that they ≈øtill live under their own cheyks, cho≈øen by each of their adowars or hords. To the≈øe may be added a French factory at Calle, under the direction of the company of the French Ba≈øtion.‚ÄîThe we≈øtern government includes the towns of Oran, Trem ‚Ä¢ ≈øen, Mo≈øtagan, Tenez , and Sercelli, with its ca≈øtle and garri≈øon.‚ÄîThe ≈øouthern government has neither town, village, nor even a hou≈øe, which obliges the bey and his forces to be always encamped.

div.head: RIVERS.
div.p: THE mo≈øt con≈øiderable rivers of Algiers, are 1. The Zha or Ziz, which cro≈ø≈øes the province of Treme≈øen, and the de≈øart of Anguid, along the frontier of Fez, and falls into the Mediterranean near the town of Tabecrita, where it takes the name of Sirut. Its water is clear and full of fi≈øh.
2. The Hued-Habra, which falls into the Ziz near the plains of Cirek. Along its banks live many de≈øperate Arabs, who are trouble≈øome neighbours to the province of Oran.
3. The Haregol, or Te ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, called Siga by Prolemy, de≈øcends from the great Atlas, cro≈ø≈øes the de≈øart of Anguid, and falls into the ≈øea about five leagues from Oran.

4. The Mina, ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Chylematis of Pto ‚Ä¢ emy, a large river that runs northward through
the plains of Bathala, waters that city and Mina, and falls into the ≈øea near the town of Arzew. This river has lately received the name of Cena, from that of a Moabite who repeopled the town of Bathala, which had been de≈øtroyed by the Berimerines.

5. The Sheliff, Zilef or Zilif, a large river, de≈øcending from mount Gnanecexis, running through va≈øt de≈øarts, the lake Titteri, the frontiers of the Treme≈øen and Tenez, and falling into the ≈øea a little above the city of Mo≈øtagan.
6. The Celef, ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Carthena of the ancients, falls into the ≈øea about three leagues we≈øt of Algiers, after a ≈øhort cour≈øe of 18 or 20 leagues.

7. The Hued-alquiver, ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Nalabata, o ‚Ä¢
Na≈øaba, of the ancients, and called by the Europeans Zinganir, runs down with a ≈øwift cour≈øe, through ≈øome high mountains of Cuco, and falls into the ≈øea near Bugia. It abounds with fi≈øh, of which ≈øuch immen≈øe quantities are caught that they are neglected. While they city of Bugia was in the hands of the Chri≈øtians, as Marmol tells us, the mouth of this river was ≈øo choaked up with ≈øand, that no ve≈ø≈øels could came up into it: but in 1555, very ≈øoon after it was taken by the Moors, the great rains ≈øwelled it to ≈øuch a degree, that all the ≈øand and mud was carried off; ≈øince which time the galleys and other trading ve≈ø≈øels have entered it with ea≈øe, where they lie ≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ from ≈øtorms and all winds but that which blows from the north.

8. The Suf-Gemar, or Suf-Gimmar al Rumniel, suppo≈øed to be the Amp≈øaga of Ptolemy, takes its ri≈øe on mount Auras, on the confines of Atlas; runs thence through ≈øome barren plains, and the fertile parts of Con≈øtantina, where its ≈øtream is
