10. The Guadi, or Guadel Barbar, ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Tu≈øca or Rubricatus of the ancients, ≈øprings from the head of Orbus, or Urbs in Tripoli, runs through Bugia, and falls into the ≈øea near Tabarca.

div.head: SOIL, CLIMATE and PRODUCTIONS.
div.p: THIS country con≈øi≈øts of eighteen provinces, the climate of which, along the ≈øea-coa≈øts, is remarkably delightful, and the air pure and ≈øerene.

The country of Algiers, and the ≈øtates of Barbary in general, under the Roman empire were ju≈øtly denominated the garden of the world; and to have a re≈øidence there was con≈øidered as the highe≈øt ≈øtate of luxury. The produce of their ≈øoil formed tho≈øe magazines which furni≈øhed all Italy, and a great part of the Roman empire with corn, wine and oil.

The ≈øoil is covered with almo≈øt a perpetual verdure, and is extremely fertile, particularly on the mountainous parts to the we≈øt of Tenez, Bugia, and Algiers Proper, which produce wheat and fruit in the greate≈øt perfection; and the northern parts of Treme≈øen, towards the ≈øea, abound in excellent pa≈øture grounds, But as we advance into the country, it becomes more parched and barren.

Though the lands are now uncultivated, through the barbarity and oppre≈ø≈øion of their government, yet they ≈øtill produce not only corn, wine, and oil
in the greate≈øt abundance, but dates, rai≈øins, almonds, apples, pears, cherries, plums, citrons, lemons, oranges, pomegranates, &c. and plenty of roots and herbs grow in their kitchen gardens. Excellent hemp and flax grow on their plains; and by the report of tho≈øe who have travelled thither, the country‚ñ™ abounds with all that can add to the plea≈øures of life.

Extreme heat is not common, and the climate is ≈øo temperate that the heat of ≈øummer never dries the leaves of the trees, nor the cold of winter makes them fall; ≈øo that they are con≈øtantly verdant. In February they begin to bud, and in May ≈øhew their fruit in full growth, which is ripe in June. Their vines are very large and thick, and the bunches of grapes on them are commonly a foot and an half long. The grapes are fit to gather in June, and the figs, peaches, nectarines, olives, nuts, &c. in Augu≈øt. The people find means to evade the sobriety pre≈øcribed by the Mahometan law, and make free with excellent wines and ≈øpirits of their own growth and manufacture. The plains of Moligia produce wheat, barley and oats, two or three times a year. Their melons are of an exqui≈øite-ta≈øte; ≈øome of which ripen in ≈øummer, and others in winter. Algiers produces be≈øides, ≈øalt-petre, and great quantities of excellent ≈øalt; and lead and iron have been found in ≈øeveral places.

The country round the city of Algiers is very fertile. Country ≈øeats, gardens and groves of trees are numerous. The Algerines are unacquainted with the art of pruning and grafting trees. Their gardens are not walled, but fenced round with a peculiar ≈øpecies of thorns, which, from their prickles, and the compactne≈øs with which their branches interweave
are well adapted for that purpo≈øe. Among other rich tracts in the province of Algiers Proper, the great plain of Met ‚Ä¢ ijah is admired for its a≈øtoni≈øhing fertility. It is fifty miles in length, twenty in breadth, and includes many villas, fragant groves, and delightful gardens. The ≈øoil produces ≈øuch a profu≈øion of the mo≈øt delicious fruits, rice, roots, and grain of every ≈øpecies, that the inhabitants enjoy annually two, and frequently three crops.

div.head: ANIMALS.
div.p: NEITHER the elephant nor the rhinoceros are to be found in the States of Barbary; but their de≈øarts abound with lions, tigers, leopards, hyaenas, and mon≈øtrous ≈øerpents. The Barbary hor≈øes were formerly very valuable, and thought equal to the Arabian. Camels and dromedaries, a≈ø≈øes, mules, and kumrahs (a mo≈øt ≈øerviceable creature, begot by an a≈øs upon a cow) are their bea≈øts of burden. Their ≈øheep yield but indifferent fleeces, but they are very large, as are their goats, Bears, buffaloes, wild boars, porcupines, foxes apes, hares, rabbits, ferrits, wea≈øels, moles, cameleons, and mo≈øt kinds of reptiles are found here.

There is a peculiar kind of animal, called the gapard, which can ea≈øily be tamed, and is made u≈øe of for hunting like a dog. The head of it re≈øembles that of a cat; the hind legs are longer than the fore, and the tail is finely mottled. It is ≈øo apt to exhau≈øt it≈øelf in running that the hunters are obliged to carry it now and then on their hor≈øes, till it has recovered it≈øelf. There is al≈øo another curious animal which is between a dog and a fox.

"Be≈øides vermin," ≈øays Dr. Shaw, ≈øpeaking of his travels through Barbary, "the apprehen≈øions we were under in ≈øome parts of this country, of being
bitten or ≈øtung by the ≈øcorpion, the viper, or the venemous ≈øpider, rarely failed to interrupt our repo≈øe."

But the mo≈øt ≈øingular in≈øects are the locu≈øts, which the Doctor in his travels de≈øcribes in the following manner. "They were much bigger than our common gra≈øs-hoppers, having brown ≈øpotted wings, with legs and bodies of a bright yellow. Their fir≈øt appearance was towards the latter end of March, the wind having been for ≈øome time ≈øoutherly; and in the middle of April their numbers were ≈øo va≈øtly increa≈øed, that in the heat of the day, they formed them≈øelves into large bodies, appeared like a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of clouds, and darkened the ≈øun. About the middle of May, each of the≈øe bodies began gradually to di≈øappear, retiring into the Me ‚Ä¢ tijiah, and other adjacent plains to depo≈øit their eggs. Accordingly in the month following, their young brood began gradually to make their appearance, and it was ≈øurpri≈øing to ob≈øerve, that no ≈øooner were any of them hatched, than they immediately collected them≈øelves together, each of them forming a compact body of ≈øeveral hundred yards in ≈øquare: which marching afterwards directly forward, climbed over trees, walls, and hou≈øes, ear up every plant in their way, and let nothing e≈øcape them. The inhabitants, to ≈øtop their progre≈øs, made trenches all over their fields and gardens, and filled them with water; or el≈øe placing in a row great quantities of heath, ≈øtubble, and ≈øuch like combu≈øtible matter, they ≈øet them on fire upon the approach of the locu≈øts. But all this was to no purpo≈øe; for the trenches were quickly filled up, and the fires put our by infinite ≈øwarms ≈øucceeding one another, whil≈øt the front ≈øeemed regardle≈øs of danger, and the rear pre≈ø≈øed on ≈øo clo≈øe, that a retreat was impo≈ø≈øible."

Partridges, quails, eagles, hawks, and all kinds of wild fowls are found on this coa≈øt; and of the ≈ømaller birds, the cap≈øa ≈øparrow is remarkable for its beauty, and the ≈øweetne≈øs of its note, which is thought to exceed that of any other bird; but it cannot live out of its own climate. The ≈øeas and bays of this coa≈øt abound with the fine≈øt and mo≈øt delicious fi≈øh of every kind, and were preferred by the ancients to tho≈øe of Europe.

div.head: ANTIQUITIES and CURIOSITIES.
div.p:
THESE matters are well worth the attention of an antiquary, but they are difficult of acce≈øs. The reader mu≈øt naturally conclude that the countries which were once under the dominion of the Carthagenians, and the pride of the Phoenician, Greek, and Roman works, are replete with the mo≈øt curious remains of antiquity, but they lie ≈øcattered among ignorant and barbarous inhabitants. Some remains of the Mauritanian and Numidian greatne≈øs are ≈øtill vi≈øible, and many ruins which bear evidence of their ancient grandeur and populou≈øne≈øs. The≈øe point out the old Julia Cae≈øarea of the Romans, which was little inferior in magnificence to Carthage it≈øelf. A few of the aqueducts of Carthage are ≈øaid to be ≈øtill remaining, but no ve ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ige of its walls. The ≈øame is the fate of Uttica, and many other renowned cities of antiquity; and ≈øo over-run is the country with barbari≈øm, that their very ≈øcites are not known even by their ruins, amphitheatres, and other public buildings which ≈øtill remain in tolerable pre≈øervation. Be≈øides tho≈øe of cla≈ø≈øical antiquity, many Saracen monuments of the mo≈øt ≈øtupendous magnificence, are likewi≈øe found in this tract of country. The≈øe were erected under the califs
of Bagdad, and the ancient kings of the country, before it was ≈øubdued by the Turks, or reduced to its pre≈øent form of government. Their walls form the principal fortifications in the country, both inland and maratime. We know of few or no natural curio≈øities belonging to the States of Barbary, except its ≈øalt pits, which is ≈øome places take up an area of ≈øix miles. Doctor Shaw mentions ≈øprings found here that are ≈øo hot as to boil a large piece of mutton in a quarter of an hour.

The hot baths of Meereega in the neighbourhood of the city of Algiers are al≈øo natural curio≈øities. The principal one is twelve feet ≈øquare and four feet deep. The water is very hot, and when it has filled the larger ba≈øon, it runs through into another of a ≈ømaller ≈øize, where the Jews bathe, for they are not permitted to u≈øe the ≈øame bath with Mahometans. The≈øe hot fountains are conjectured to proceed from the great quantities of ≈øulphur, nitre, and other inflamable ≈øub≈øtances in the bowels of the earth. To this cau≈øe likewi≈øe have been a≈øcribed tho≈øe earthquakes, to which the whole country, and Algiers in particular, is frequently ≈øubjected.

The city of Algiers has few ≈øubjects of antiquity, and little that merits the attention of the curious. There are, however, upon the tower of the great mo≈øque ≈øome broken in≈øcriptions; but the letters, though ≈øufficiently large to be ≈øeen at a di≈øtance, are ≈øo filled up with lime and whitewa≈øh that they cannot be particularly di≈øtingui≈øhed.

div.head: INHABITANTS.
div.p:
The inhabitants of the territory of Algiers, and particularly tho≈øe along the ≈øea-coa≈øts, are a mixture
of different nations; ≈øuch as Moors and More≈øcos driven out of Catalonia, Arragon, and other parts of Spain, about the end of the ≈øixteenth century, Jews, Jani≈øaries, and great numbers of Turks, who come from the Levant to ≈øeek their fortune: as well as mulitudes of Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves. &c.

The Berebers are ≈øome of the mo≈øt ancient inhabitants of the country; and are ≈øuppo≈øed to be de≈øcended from the ancient Sabeans, who came hither from Arabia Felix, under the conduct of one of their princes. Others believe them to be the de≈øcendants of ≈øome of the Canaanites, who were driven out of Pale≈øtine by Jo≈øhua. The≈øe are di≈øper≈øed all over Barbary, and divided into a multitude of tribes under their re≈øpective chiefs; mo≈øt of them inhabit the mountainous parts; ≈øome range from place to place, and live in tents, or portable huts; others in ≈øcattered villages; they have, neverthele≈øs, kept them≈øelves from intermixing with other nations. The Berebers are reckoned the riche≈øt of all, go better clothed, and carry on a much larger tra≈ø≈øic in cattle ‚Ä¢ hides, wax, honey, iron, and other commodities. They have al≈øo ≈øome artificers in iron, and ≈øome manufacturers in ‚Ä¢ he weaving branch. The name of Bereber is ≈øuppo≈øed to have been originally given them on account of their being fir≈øt ≈øettled in ≈øome de≈øart place. Upon their encrea≈øing in proce≈øs of time, they divided them≈øelves into five tribes, probably on account of their religious differences, called the Zinhagians, Mu≈øamedins, Zene ‚Ä¢ i, Hoares, and Gomeres; and the≈øe having produced 600 families, ≈øubdivided them≈øelves into a great number of petty tribes.

To the≈øe we may add the Z ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ owahs by European authors called the Azuagues, or A≈ø≈øagues,
who are likewi≈øe di≈øper≈øed over mo≈øt parts of Barbary and Numidia. Great numbers of the≈øe inhabit the mountainous parts of Cuco, Labez, &c. leading a wandering pa≈øtoral life. The African hi≈øtorians a≈ø≈øure us that they are ≈øome of the de≈øcendants of tho≈øe Phoenicians or Canaanites, who fled from Jo≈øhua and the I≈øraeli ‚Ä¢ es, according to an in≈øcription in the Punic tongue engraved on a ≈øtone at a fountain, thus, We are fled hither from the pre≈øence of that great robber JOSHUA the ≈øon of NUN. They are a kind of Chri≈øtians that neither ≈øhave their beards, nor cut their hair; and affect to wear a blue cro≈øs painted or burnt on their cheek or hand by way of di≈øtinction.

But the mo≈øt numerous inhabitants are the Moors and Arabs, who trace their de≈øcent from tho≈øe di≈øciples of Mahomet, who formerly ≈øubdued this country; the former compo≈øe the great body of the inhabitants of the towns. But it may readily be ≈øuppo≈øed that among ≈øuch a variety of different races, immen≈øe numbers cannot be ≈øaid to belong to any particular tribe or nation whatever.

In this country there are many wandering bands of the≈øe Arabs, who live together in camps, and remove from one place to another as they want pa≈øture for their herds and flocks, or as: any other accidental circum≈øtance happens to make it nece≈ø≈øary. They ≈øometimes pay rent to landlords in corn, fruit, honey, wax, and other productions; and the dey likewi≈øe demands a tribute from them. The excellence of the climate renders this ≈øimple way of living tolerable, though the tents of the≈øe people are mean, their uten≈øils of little value, and their lodgings filthy. The family and their dome≈øtic animals lie promi≈øcuou≈øly in the ≈øame tents together, except their dogs, which are left as guards
on the out≈øide. They rai≈øe con≈øiderable numbers of bees, and ≈øilk worms. They ≈øub≈øi≈øt chiefly on bread, rice and fruit, Wine and ≈øpiritous liquors are almo≈øt entirely unknown to them.

The dre≈øs of the men who compo≈øe the≈øe tribes is only a long piece of coar≈øe cloth wrapped round their ≈øhoulders, and falling down to their ancles, with a cap of the ≈øame ≈øtuff. The ≈øheik, or chief of a tribe, wears a cap a of fine cloth. The women pay ≈øome more attention to the ornamental part of their dre≈øs; but their children are ≈øuffered to go ≈øtark naked till ≈øeven or eight years of age.

The cu≈øtoms, language and religion of the≈øe ≈øhepherds bear a ≈øtrict affinity to tho≈øe of Arabia. They are robu≈øt, and of a ≈øwarthy complexion. The men are active, the women prolific and the children healthy. They have neither to encounter the hard≈øhips incident to the life of a North American ≈øavage, nor are their con≈øtitutions en≈øeebled, as is the ca≈øe in manufacturing towns, by ≈øedentary and unhealthy employments.

When a young man of the≈øe tribes would marry, he drives a number of cattle to the hut where the parents of his mi≈øtre≈øs re≈øide. The bride is ≈øet on hor≈øeback, and led home amid≈øt the ≈øhouts of a croud of young people, who have been invited to the nuptial fea≈øt. When ≈øhe arrives at the hut of her lover, a mixture of milk and honey is given her to drink, and a ≈øong, ≈øuitable to the occa≈øion, is ≈øung. She then alights, and is pre≈øented with a ≈øtick, which ≈øhe thru≈øts into the ground, and repeats ≈øome words to the following effect: As this ≈øtick is fa≈øtened in the earth, ≈øo am I in duty bound to my hu≈øband; as nothing but violence can remove it, ≈øo death alone ≈øhall force me from his love. She then drives his ≈øtock to
water and back again, to ≈øhew her willingne≈øs to perform any duty that he may a≈ø≈øign her. The≈øe previous ceremonies being ≈øettled, all the company enter the hut, and the evening concludes with the greate≈øt fe≈øtivity that the≈øe people are capable of enjoying. After the marriage the wife is obliged to wear a veil, and ≈øhe never ≈øtirs from her hut for the ≈øpace of a month,

The Arabs are ≈øtout, warlike, and ≈økilful hor≈øemen. Their principal arms are a ≈øhort lance and ≈øcymitar, and they are likewi≈øe acquainted with the bow and the mu≈øket. But they are ≈øo addicted to robbing, that one cannot ≈øafely travel through the country at a di≈øtance from the towns without a guard, or at lea≈øt a marabout or ≈øaint for a ≈øafeguard. For they look upon them≈øelves to be the original proprietors of the country, and not only as di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the re≈øt of the inhabitants, but reduced by them to the lowe≈øt ≈øtate of poverty, and in con≈øequence they make no ≈øcruple to plunder all they meet by way of repri≈øal.

The inhabitants of this country, e≈øpecially tho≈øe near the ≈øea-coa≈øts, generally ≈øub≈øi≈øt by piracy; they are allowed to be bold intrepid mariners, and will fight de≈øperately when they meet with a prize at ≈øea. They are, notwith≈øtanding, far inferior to the Engli≈øh, and other European ≈øtates, both in the con≈øtruction and management of their ve≈ø≈øels.

The inhabitants of the metropolis are extremely vicious; and it is a general ob≈øervation that the more di≈øtant the people are from the ≈øeat of government, the purer are their manners. Notwith≈øtanding their poverty, they have much vivacity about them, e≈øpecially tho≈øe who are of Arabic de≈øcent, which gives them an air of contentment; and
having little to lo≈øe, they are peaceable among them≈øelves.

The Turks who compo≈øe the military force, have great privileges, pay no taxes, and are exempted from public puni≈øhment. The lowe≈øt ≈øoldier domineers over the mo≈øt di≈øtingui≈øhed Moors at plea≈øure. The people are ≈øubjected to the mo≈øt ab≈øolute de≈øpoti≈øm, and mo≈øt cruelly oppre≈ø≈øed by a handful of in≈øolent Turks, the refu≈øe of the ≈øtreets of Con≈øtantinople. If a Turk finds a Moor better mounted than him≈øelf, he takes the liberty of exchanging hor≈øes without leave or ceremony, and he will take apples, oranges, nuts and other articles which the Moors bring to market, with as much indifference as if they were his property. The Turks have the exclu≈øive privilege of carrying fire-arms. Such is the de≈øpoti≈øm of the Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers that they not only turn others out of the way in the ≈øtreets, but will go to the farm hou≈øes in the country for twenty days together, living on free quarters, and making u≈øe of every thing, not excepting the women. They are u≈øed more like men of quality than private centinels. They are lodged in ≈øpacious ≈øquares, attended by ≈ølaves, and generally maintained at the public expence. The a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y of the dey is principally compo≈øed of Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers, who are called Jani≈øaries; and though their numbers are ≈ømall, yet they tyrannize in the mo≈øt in≈øolent manner over the native Moors throughout the whole country. Some good qualities, however, di≈øtingui≈øh them, notwith≈øtanding this exce≈øs of de≈øpoti≈øm. They never game for money, nor even trifles; and what cannot be ≈øaid of Chri≈øtians, they never profane the name of the Deity. They ≈øoon forget their private quarrels; and after the fir≈øt paroxy≈øm of re≈øentment has ≈øub≈øided,
it is infamy for a Turk to keep in remembrance the injuries ‚Ä¢ e has received. In this re≈øpect they are le≈øs barbarous than other nations that boa≈øt of their civilization.

When d ‚Ä¢ ficiencies happen in the army their cor≈øairs are ≈øent out to the Levant to procure recruits, which generally con≈øi≈øt of pea≈øants, outlaws, and per≈øons of the meane≈øt conditions. Mahomet Ba≈øhaw who was dey about the year 1732, was of this de≈øcription, and in his celebrated di≈øpute with the deputy of a neighbouring nation he ≈øaid, My mother ≈øold ≈øheep's ‚Ä¢ eet and my father neat's tongues, but they would have been a≈øhamed to have expo≈øed to ≈øale ≈øuch a tongue as yours. The≈øe recruits, after they have been a little in≈øtructed by their fellow ≈øoldiers, and are furni≈øhed with caps to their heads, ≈øhoes to their feet, and a pair of knives to their girdles, quickly begin to a≈ø≈øume airs of importance, and look upon the mo≈øt con≈øiderable citizens as their ≈ølaves.

The Algerines eat as in Turkey, ≈øitting cro≈øs legged round a table about four inches high, and u≈øe neither knives nor forks in eating. Before they begin, every one ≈øays B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i≈øme Allah, in the name of God. When they have done, a ≈ølave pours water on their hands as they ≈øit, and then they wa≈øh their mouths. Their drink is water, ≈øherbet and coffee. Wine is not allowed, though drank immoderately by ≈øome.

Both the men and women ≈øpend a great part of their time in indolence, the men in drinking coffee and ≈ømoking, and the women in dre≈ø≈øing, bathing, conver≈øing on their ≈øophas, vi≈øiting the tombs of their relations, and walking in their gardens.

The Algerines in general, particularly about the ≈øea-coa≈øts, have a pretty fair complexion; but tho≈øe
in the interior parts of the country, and particularly the Arabs, are ≈øwarthy They are robu≈øt and well proportioned, and expert in the u≈øe of fire arms. The Algerine women are beautiful in their per≈øons, and very delicate in their complexions, but the men are ≈øun-burnt. They improve the beauty of their eyes by art, particularly by the powder of lead ore, the ≈øame pigment, according to the opinion of the learned Doctor Shaw, that Jezebel made u≈øe of when ≈øhe is ≈øaid to have painted her face;2 Kings, chap. ix. ver. 30. the words of the original being that ≈øhe ≈øet off her eyes with the powder of lead ore.

The Algerines by their law may have four wives, but they u≈øually content them≈øelves with two, or three at the mo≈øt. The hu≈øband ≈øeldom ≈øees his wife before marriage, but accepts her upon the de≈øcription of a female confidant. When the match is agreed upon, the bridegroom ≈øends a pre≈øen ‚Ä¢ of ≈øweetmeats to the bride, and entertains her relations with a fea≈øt and a mu≈øical entertainment.

After the death of a man his corps is attended by a number of his male friends, or if the decea≈øed be a woman ≈øhe is attended by her female friends. The corps is wa≈øhed with warm ≈øoap-≈øuds and wrapt in clean linen. It is then laid in a coffin covered with green cloth, upon which a turban is placed, and carried with the head forward to the grave, attended by women who are hired to lament. The≈øe women ≈øcratch them≈øelves till the blood runs, di≈øtort their countenances and make a mo≈øt hideous noi≈øe. As the proce≈ø≈øion enters the burial ground ≈øome marabouts ≈øing without intermi≈ø≈øion the≈øe words, Lahilla Lah Mahomet re≈ø≈øoul allah, God is God and Mahomet is his prophet. It is then
placed in the grave in an erect po≈øture, with the face turned towards the ≈øouth. If the decea≈øed has been a per≈øon of di≈øtinction grave ≈øtones are erected at his head and feet, with epitaphs, in≈øcriptions, or ≈øelect ≈øentences out of the Alcoran.

The chief furniture of their hou≈øes con≈øi≈øts of carpets and mattr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , on which they ≈øit and lie. In eating their ≈ølovenline≈øs is di≈øgu≈øting. They are prohibited gold and ≈øilver ve≈ø≈øels, and their meat, which they ≈øwallow by handfuls, is boiled or roa≈øted to rags. Their ordinary food i ‚Ä¢ rice and fine flour made into ≈ømall grains like ≈øhot, which they call Cuzcuz; both which they boil with meat and fowls, and mo≈øt commonly eat fruit and herbs with them.

The people in general in travelling walk on foot or u≈øe a≈ø≈øes, and ≈øeldom ride on hor≈øeback, except the governors of provinces and other great per≈øonages. The women ≈øeldom walk on foot; but ride upon a≈ø≈øes in a ≈øquare box covered with a kind of canopy and drawn round with curtains. So that they are ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ely concealed, and when they ≈øet out upon their journey they are attended by a driver.

div.head: DRESS.
div.p:
The dre≈øs of the people in general is a linen ≈øhirt, over which they tie a ≈øilk or cloth ve≈ø ‚Ä¢ ment with a ≈øa≈øh, and over that a loo≈øe coat. Their drawers are made of linen. The arms and legs of the wearer are bare; but they have ≈ølippers on their feet, and per≈øons of rank ≈øometimes wear bu≈økins. They never move their turbans, but pull off their ≈ølippers when they attend religious duties, or the per≈øon of their ≈øovereign. They are fond of ≈øtriped and fancied ≈øilks. The viceroy and great men let their beards
grow; but the common people ≈øhave both their head and face, and only leave a pair of whi≈økers, and a lock of hair upon the top of the head, by which they fancy they are drawn up to paradi≈øe.

The dre≈øs of the common people is very plain; they wear a pair of linen drawers over their ≈øhirt, and a loo≈øe white woolen jacket with a hood behind, or a mantle which is commonly black, and reaches only down to the knee, in which they wrap them≈øelves; but in ≈øummer they only wear two ≈øhirts.

The men of fa≈øhion go more ≈øumptuou≈øly clad. Their gowns are made of fur, ≈øilk, or cloth: they have rich garments finely embroidered with flowers of gold; their turbans are very curiou≈øly done up, and elegantly adorned with jewels; and their legs are covered with boots of ≈øhining leather.

The women pay more attention to the ornamental part of dre≈øs than men. There is not, however, much difference between the dre≈øs of the ≈øexes; the drawers of the women are longer, and in≈øtead of a turban, they wear a ≈øort of cawl on their heads. They tie their hair behind, and ornament it with jewels and other trinkets. They wear fine collars about their necks, bracelets about their wri≈øts, large pendants in their ears, and curious caps on their heads. When they go abroad they u≈øually throw over their faces a fine veil, which they fa≈øten to their brea≈øt, and over their garments they wear an upper robe; ≈øo that they are not known, but by the ≈ølaves that attend them.

div.head: LANGUAGE.
div.p:
THE Algerines are void of all literature. The original language of this country appears to have
been the Phoenician; after which the Romans obliged them to exchange it (as they did all their conquered dominions) for their own. The Arabs afterwards introduced theirs, and after them the Turks. The native Moors make u≈øe of the More≈øco; but the people of Algiers in general ≈øpeak a compound of Arabic, More≈øco, and the remains of the ancient Phoenician language. In the metropolis the Mahometans and Chri≈øtians u≈øe the Lingua Franca, a mixture of Spani≈øh, Portugue≈øe, Italian and French. The natives of all denominations for the mo≈øt part, under≈øtand this dialect, which, without being the proper language of any country on the coa≈øt of the Mediterranean, has a kind of univer≈øal currency all over that quarter of the world, as the channel of information for people who cannot under≈øtand each other through any other medium. The public bu≈øine≈øs of the nation is tran≈øacted either in the Arabic or Turki≈øh, but commonly the former, in which their late treaty with the United States of America is written.

It is curious that in conver≈øation, the Turks tran≈øpo≈øe their nouns and verbs, in the ≈øame manner that the Greek and Latin writers have done. The Turki≈øh is a lofty language, and the Turks when they ≈øpeak affect a ≈øingular maje≈øty of tone, as expre≈ø≈øive of their ≈øuperiority: which, however, con≈øi≈øts in nothing but their indolence, for they are neither men of learning, nor warriors,‚Äîa truth that the Ru≈ø≈øians have long taught them.

div.head: GOVERNMENT.
div.p:
THOUGH Algiers has ≈øome appearance of a military republic, yet it is in fact the mo≈øt horrible of all monarchies in the world, and as mutable in its
principles as the temper and di≈øpo≈øition of tho≈øe differ, who happen to be in admini≈øtration.

Algiers was formerly ≈øubject to the Grand Signior, and is ≈øtill under his protection; but the dey at pre≈øent pays no other tribute to him, than that of a certain number of beautiful Arabian hor≈øes, and ≈øome other pre≈øents which are ≈øent thither annually. The Grand Signior formerly ≈øent a ba≈øhaw, or viceroy, to Algiers, in whom the ≈øovereignty was ve≈øted; but tho≈øe officers frequently exerci≈øed the mo≈øt tyrannical power, and exacted from the people ≈øuch exorbitant taxes, as produced popular in≈øurrections; till at length the Jani≈øaries and militia grew ≈øo powerful that they depo≈øed them and elected others in their ≈øtead; at which the Porte was obliged to connive, le≈øt they ≈øhould be provoked to an open revolt, and entirely throw off the Turki≈øh yoke; ≈øince which time the power of the Porte has been ≈øo gradually dimini≈øhed that he can do nothing here without the concurrence of the dey.

The ≈øupreme authority of ≈øtate is ve≈ø ‚Ä¢ el in the dey, who is an elective monarch, and his ≈øons never inherit the ≈øovereignty by de≈øcent. He is elected by the divan, and is compelled to accept the reins of government under penalty of death. He ≈øeldom ≈øecures his office without tumult and blood≈øhed, and often falls by the dagger of an a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øin: ≈øo that out of ≈øix deys that have reigned ≈øince 1700, four of them have been actually murdered, and a fifth re≈øigned to ≈øave his life. The ba≈øhaws ≈øeldom fail of forming parties among the ≈øoldiers again≈øt him, and they make no ≈øcruple to a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinate him even in council, and the ≈øtronge≈øt candidate then fills his place. An un≈øucce≈øsful
expedition, or too pacific a conduct, ≈øeldom fails to put an end to his life and government.

The way in which his authority is exerci≈øed, corre≈øponds with that by which it has been obtained. When Mr. Bruce, as Briti≈øh re≈øident at Algiers, had occa≈øion to vi≈øit the dey, he ≈øays he ≈øometimes found him in his hall of audience, with his clothes all be≈øpattered with blood like tho≈øe of a carca≈øe butcher. It is a very frequent amu≈øement with him, to cau≈øe the heads of his ≈øubjects to be ≈øtruck off in his pre≈øence. Mr. Bruce ≈øaid that he knew of one man who was exceuted for no greater offence than becau≈øe a gun-flint was found upon him. His indictment and trial were very conci≈øe: "You ra≈øcal, what bu≈øine≈øs have you with a flint unle≈øs you were going to con≈øpire again≈øt the ≈øtate?"

The fir≈øt deys were elected by the militia; who were then called the divan, or common council; which was at fir≈øt compo≈øed of 800 militia officers, without who≈øe concurrence he could do nothing; and upon ≈øome urgent occa≈øions, all the officers, re≈øiding in Algiers amounting to 1500, were ≈øummoned to a≈ø≈øi≈øt: but at pre≈øent he is perhaps the mo≈øt de≈øpotic prince in the world. He is abridged of no power whatever in admini≈øtration, and the divan, though they have a≈ø≈øumed a very pompous title, have little el≈øe to do but to ratify his decrees. The divan is compo≈øed of per≈øons entirely of his own election whom he removes at plea≈øure. Upon important occa≈øions he ≈øometimes a≈ø≈øembles the divan to receive their advice; but his only motive in this is to ≈øcreen him≈øelf again≈øt popular di≈øcontents; for his authority is unlimited, and he may either ratify or reject their deci≈øions as he plea≈øes. When the Grand
Signior is at war with a Chri≈øtian power, he generally requires his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; but he is only obeyed as the dey thinks proper.

The dey has a corps of body-guards called foulacks. This is a very nece≈ø≈øary, though ≈øometimes a fruitle≈øs precaution, as any Turki≈øh ≈øoldier who has the courage to murder him, ≈øtands an equal chance of becoming his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor. Experiments of this kind are ≈øometimes made. Since the beginning of the pre≈øent century, ≈øix private ≈øoldiers entered into a con≈øpiracy to kill a dey of one of the ≈øtates of Barbary. They gave him a mortal wound in his palace, and in the mid≈øt of a croud of people. He expired, exclaiming, Has nobody the courage to kill the villain? One of the con≈øpirators, the intended ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, in≈øtantly a≈øcended the vacant throne, and brandi≈øhing his naked ≈øcymitar, declared that he would do ju≈øtice to all! His five a≈ø≈øociates went about the hall to enforce the title of their new ≈øovereign, and none pre≈øent ≈øeemed to give them≈øelves any di≈øturbance about what had happened. He kept his ≈øituation unmole≈øted, for about ten minutes, till an old veteran unob≈øerved took aim at him with a mu≈øket, and ≈øhot him dead. Upon this the five others were immediately murdered. But what ≈øhowed the nature of the government in its proper light was the ob≈øervation of the new dey, who ≈øaid, that if the u≈øurper could have held his place for twenty minutes longer, he would have obtained the ≈øovereignty.

The officer next in power to the dey is the Ca≈ø≈øan-aga or Ca≈ø≈øan-ajee, the prime mini≈øter of ≈øtate. He keeps one ≈øet of the keys of the trea≈øury, the dey another, and the aga a third, where they all attend once a month to pay the ≈øoldiers.

The officer next in power is the Aga or general of the Jani≈øaries, who is one of the olde≈øt officers in the army, and holds his po≈øt as all other officers do, at the plea≈øure of the dey. During the time the aga enjoys his dignity, the keys of the metropolis are delivered to him. All military orders are i≈ø≈øued in his name, and the ≈øentence of the dey upon any offending ≈øoldier, whether capital or not, can only he executed in the court of his palace.

The next to the aga in dignity, is the Secretary of State, who regi≈øters all the public acts; and after him the Hojecabei ‚Ä¢ y, who is a kind of chief ju≈øtice to ≈øettle di≈øputes among the Moors. This officer, and the two la≈øt mentioned, attend at the door of the dey's palace every morning about day-break, in order to ki≈øs his hand.

The next in dignity is the Vekelard, or rather Vikelhadge of the marine, who is the guardian of the navy, from whom all maritime orders i≈ø≈øue. He is ≈øeated beneath an arch near the ≈øea-≈øide called the ≈økiff, from which he has a full view of the tran≈øactions in the marine.

Below him ≈øits the Baleck ba≈øhaw, who is a kind of bailiff to execute his commands. He takes charge of the magazines of the marine; all naval articles are under his in≈øpection, and the keys of all the magazines in the town are entru≈øted to his care.
The Hojee of the Rap has the charge of the magazines of wheat in the town; under him are ≈øeveral inferior hojees who execute his orders. No ≈ølave can ri≈øe higher than this office.

The Warden Ba≈øhaw is the next inferior officer. He is chief over≈øeer of the ≈ølaves, and takes care that they duly perform their duty. He has charge of the Bagnio Gallaro, the keys of which are delivered
him every night by one of his under wardens who keeps the doors. He has a number of under wardens, who attend the ≈ølaves at their labour.

Be≈øides the≈øe there are 30 chiahs, or chows, a kind of high con≈øtables, who ≈øit next to the aga in the divan, and in the ≈øame gallery with him. Out of this cla≈øs are generally cho≈øen tho≈øe who go emba≈ø≈øadors to foreign courts, or who di≈øper≈øe the dey's orders throughout the realm. Next to them are a number of baleck-ba≈øhaws, or elde≈øt captains, who are promoted to that of chiah ba≈øhaws, according to their ≈øeniority. The oldack-ba≈øhaws, or lieutenants, are next; who amount to 400, and are regularly rai≈øed to the rank of captains in their turn, and to other employments in the ≈øtate, according to their abilities. The≈øe by way of di≈øtinction wear a leather ≈øtrap, hanging down to the middle of their back. One rule is ≈øtrickly ob≈øerved in the rotation of the≈øe troops from one deputy to a higher; viz. the right of ≈øeniority; one ≈øingle infringement of which would cau≈øe an in≈øurrection, and probably co≈øt the dey his life.

The other military officers of note are vekelards, or purveyors of the army; the peys, who are the four olde≈øt ≈øoldiers, and con≈øequently the neare≈øt to preferment; the foulacks, who are the next in ≈øeniority to them, and are part of the dey's bodyguards, always marching before him when he takes the field, and di≈øtingui≈øhed by their carbines and gilt ≈øcymitars, with a bra≈øs gun on their caps; the kayts, or Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers, each band of whom have the government of one or more adowars, or itenerant villages, and collect their taxes for the dey; and the ≈øagiards, or Turki≈øh lancemen, 100 of whom always attend the army, and watch over the water appointed for it. To the≈øe we may add
the beys, or governors of the three great provinces of the realm. All the above-mentioned officers ought to compo≈øe the great divan: but only the 30 chiah-ba≈øhaws have a right to ≈øit in the gallery next after the dey. The re≈øt are obliged to ≈øtand on the floor of the hall, or council-chamber, with their arms acro≈øs, and, as much as po≈ø≈øible, without motion; neither are they permitted to enter with their ≈øwords on. As for tho≈øe who have any matters to tran≈øact with the divan, they mu≈øt ≈øtand without, let the weather be ever ≈øo bad; and there they are commonly pre≈øented with coffee by ≈øome of the inferior officers, till they are di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.

The Li≈øberos are the dey's ≈øpies, who keep watch in different parts of the town, for the purpo≈øe of obtaining information of what is ≈øaid or tran≈øacted. They are perhaps the mo≈øt mercenary and inhuman ≈øet of beings in exi≈øtence, and ≈øuch is their ≈øervility to their ≈øovereign, that they would betray even their own fathers. When they lodge information again≈øt any per≈øon, the chows are ≈øent to arre≈øt the delinquent, and he is puni≈øhed according to his crime.

The divan, or douwan, is the common council of the nation. It is an elective body, and is principally compo≈øed of 30 chiah-ba≈øhaws, with now and then the mufti and cadi upon ≈øome emergencies; and on the election of a dey the whole ≈øoldiery are allowed to come in and give their votes. All the regulations of ≈øtate ought to be determined by this a≈ø≈øembly, before they pa≈øs into a law, or the dey has power to put them in execution. But, for many years back, the divan is of ≈øo little account that it is only convened out of formality, and to give a≈ø≈øent to what the dey and his favourites have previou≈øly concerted. They, however, arrogate to them≈øelves
the whole power of the ≈øtate, and in their edicts or national ordinances they a≈ø≈øume the pompous title of, "We the great and ≈ømall members of the powerful and invincible militia of Algiers and of the whole kingdom, do ordain," &c.

All cau≈øes whether civil or criminal, in which the ≈øoldiers are concerned, are tried in this council; but tho≈øe between the citizens are decided before one of the chiah-ba≈øhaws, and the plaintiffs and defendants always plead their own cau≈øes without the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of attornies. The evidence of two witne≈ø≈øes is always required, and he who is ca≈øt upon any trial receives a number of blows with a cudgel, and is compelled be≈øides to comply with the ≈øentence that has been pa≈ø≈øed.

While the divan are convened the dey holds a fan of feathers in his hand, and ≈øits cro≈øs-legged, after the manner of taylors, upon a large table about two feet high, covered with a ≈øhaggy carpet. Six of the principal chiahs are ≈øeated in the ≈øame manner on his right, and ≈øix on his left. The re≈øt of the members ≈øtand at both ends of the table, and form a kind of circle.

The method of gathering votes in this augu≈øt a≈ø≈øembly is perfectly agreeable to the character of tho≈øe who compo≈øe it. The aga, or the pre≈øident pro tempore, fir≈øt propo≈øes the que≈øtion; which is immediately repeated with a loud voice by the chiah-ba≈øhaws, and from them echoed again by four officers called ba≈øhaldalas; from the≈øe the que≈øtion is repeated from one member of the divan to another, with ≈øtrange contortions, and the mo≈øt hideous growlings, if it is not to their liking. From the loudne≈øs of this growling noi≈øe the aga is left to gue≈øs, as well as he can, whether the majority of the a≈ø≈øembly are plea≈øed or di≈øplea≈øed with the
que≈øtion; and from ≈øuch a prepo≈øterous method, it is not ≈øurpri≈øing that the≈øe a≈ø≈øemblies ≈øhould ≈øeldom end without „Äà‚óä„Äâ tumult or di≈øorder. As the whole body of the militia is concerned in the election of a new dey, it is ≈øeldom carried on without blows and blood≈øhed: but when once the choice is made, the per≈øon elected is ≈øaluted with the words Alla Barick, "God ble≈øs and pro≈øper you:" and the new dey u≈øually cau≈øes all the officers of the divan who had oppo≈øed his election to be ≈øtrangled, filling up their places with tho≈øe who had been mo≈øt zealous in promoting it. It is true it mu≈øt be confirmed by the Porte; but that is ≈øeldom refu≈øed, as the di≈øpo≈øitions of the people are ≈øo well known.

From this account of the election of the deys, it cannot be expected that their government ≈øhould be at all ≈øecure; and as they arrive at the throne by tumult and blood≈øhed they are generally deprived of it by the ≈øame means, ≈øcarcely one in ten of them having the good fortune to die a natural death.

div.head: CORSAIRS AND COMMERCE.
div.p:
THE Algerines pay but little attention to agriculture or the improvement of their country, and their ≈øingular genius leads them ≈øo much to the profe≈ø≈øion or piracy that they neglect all internal re≈øources or advantages that might be derived from their own country. The cor≈øairs or pirates form each a ≈ømall republic, of which the rais or captain is the ≈øupreme ba≈øhaw; who with the officers under him, form a kind of divan, in which every matter relative to the ve≈ø≈øels is decided in an arbitrary way. The≈øe cor≈øairs are chiefly in≈øtrumental in importing whatever commodities are brought into the kingdom either by
way of merchandize or prizes. The≈øe con≈øi≈øt chiefly of gold and ≈øilver ≈øtuffs, dama≈øks, cloths, ≈øpices, tin, iron, plated bra≈øs, lead, quick≈øilver, cordage, ≈øailcloth, bullets, cochineal, linen, tartar, allum, rice, ≈øugar, ≈øoap, cotton raw and ≈øpun, copperas, aloes, brazil and logwood, vermilion, &c. Very few commodities, however, are exported from this part of the world: the oil, wax, hides, pul≈øe, and corn produced, being but barely ≈øufficient to ≈øupply the country; though, before the lo≈øs of Oran, the merchants have been known to ≈øhip off from one or other the ports of Barbary ≈øeveral thou≈øand tons of corn. The con≈øumption of oil, though here in great abundance, is likewi≈øe ≈øo con≈øiderable in this kingdom, that it is ≈øeldom permitted to be ≈øhipped off for Europe.

The other exports con≈øi≈øt chiefly in o≈øtriches' feathers, copper, ruggs, ≈øilk ≈øa≈øhes, embroidered handkerchiefs, dates, and Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves. Some manufactures in ≈øilk, cotton, wool, leather, &c. are carried on in this country, but mo≈øtly by the Spaniards ≈øettled here, e≈øpecially about the metropolis. Carpets are al≈øo a manufacture of the country, which, though much inferior to tho≈øe of Turkey both in beauty and finene≈øs, are preferred by the people to lie upon, on account of their being both cheaper and ≈øofter. There are al≈øo at Algiers looms for velvet, taffaties, and other wrought ≈øilks; and a coar≈øe ≈øort of linen is likewi≈øe made in mo≈øt parts of the kingdom. The country furni≈øhes no materials for ≈øhip-building. They have neither ropes, tar, ≈øails, anchors, nor even iron. When they can procure enough of new wood of form the main timbers of a ≈øhip, they ≈øupply the re≈øt from the materials of prizes which they have made, and thus find the ≈øecret of producing new and ≈øwift ≈øailing ve≈ø≈øels
from the ruins of the old. The Algerines are more formidable at ≈øea than any other nation on the coa≈øt of Barbary, and the ≈øea-faring people are held in great e≈øteem for the prizes they capture.

The fleet of this regency at pre≈øent does not amount to more than ten or eleven ≈øail of the line, though they were formerly much more powerful, and in the time of Pinchinin their fleet amounted to 65 ≈øail of the line. At ≈øea they have been regarded as the mo≈øt de≈øperate and ferocious ≈øet of beings in the world. But this ≈øeems a fal≈øe prejudice that nations have imbibed, and according to recent accounts they are inferior in naval tactics to every nation in Europe. Almo≈øt all our late captives concur in the opinion that four American frigates, well manned and di≈øciplined, would be a force ≈øufficient to reduce them. Though the Turks are ≈øo proud and arrogant, yet it is well known that they are no warriors. Their greate≈øt di≈øplay of bravery is at the fir≈øt on≈øet, but if they meet with a ≈øpirited reception from a competent force their vanqui≈øhment is certain. Even the Moors, though they are an illiterate barbarous race, are ≈øuperior warriors to the Turks. In their cor≈øairs the mo≈øt ≈øervile part of the duty is a≈ø≈øigned to the Moors, while the Turks ≈øpend their time in ≈ømoking and in indolence, except when they come to an engagement with an enemy, when they fight with ≈ømall arms and c ‚Ä¢ la≈ø≈øes. We are ignorant of the naval force of Tunis and Tripoli; but it mu≈øt be evident that in this re≈øpect they are much inferior to the Algerines.

Since the e≈øtabli≈øhment of the independence of North America we owe the ≈øecurity of our commerce in a great mea≈øure to the wars that have exi≈øted between the Algerines, the Portugue≈øe, and the Dutch, either of which nations is much ≈øuperior
in naval ≈øtrength, and they have ≈øo vigilantly guarded the entrance of the Mediterranean, that the pirates have ≈øeldom been able to crui≈øe out into the Atlantic. Before the Algerine treaty American ve≈ø≈øels ≈øeldom entered into the Mediterranean; and when they did ≈øo, they derived their ≈øecurity either from forged or purcha≈øed Mediterranean pa≈ø≈øports. A Briti≈øh ≈øhip has for her protection a pa≈øs written upon a large ≈øheet of parchment, which has by way of ornament ≈øome da≈øhes engraved or drawn with a pen upon the margin. The Algerines cannot read Engli≈øh, and a captain of a cor≈øair would mo≈øt probably forfeit his head were he to carry a Briti≈øh ve≈ø≈øel by mi≈øtake, as a prize into the harbour of Algiers. They have therefore adopted a ≈øingular contrivance to di≈øcover whether ≈øuch pa≈ø≈øes are genuine. They keep a ≈øtick marked with notches corre≈øponding to the ≈øhape of tho≈øe da≈øhes, that are uniformly delineated on the margin of the parchment. When the pa≈øs is produced the mea≈øure is applied: ≈øo that it is not difficult for the mo≈øt bungling arti≈øt to deceive them, who has an original pa≈øs before him, and in this manner it is ≈øaid that many American ve≈ø≈øels have been pre≈øerved.

div.head: REVENUES.
div.p:
THE revenues of the dey are extremely fluctuating, and his income ri≈øes or falls in proportion to his opportunities of plundering his ≈øubjects, or foreigners; whence they are variou≈øly computed by different authors. Dr. Shaw ≈øays, that the taxes of the whole kingdom produce yearly to the dey no more than 300,000 dollars; but he ≈øuppo≈øes that the eighth part of the prizes to which he is entitled, the
property of tho≈øe per≈øons who die without children, to whom the dey falls heir, with the pre≈øents from foreign nations, fines and oppre≈ø≈øions, joined to the yearly contribution rai≈øed by the government, may amount to as much more. He is be≈øides entitled to all Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves, who≈øe ran≈øoms are his perqui≈øites, which, with the cu≈øtoms paid by the Engli≈øh, French and other nations, who are ≈øuffered to trade with the Barbary States, will tend con≈øiderably to augment his revenue. Both the dey, and officers under him, enrich them≈øelves by the mo≈øt open acts of rapine and fraud; it is therefore no wonder to find the common people impo≈øing upon one another, and e≈øpecially upon ≈øtrangers, ≈øeeing they them≈øelves are impoveri≈øhed by heavy taxes and the inju≈øtice of tho≈øe who are in authority.

The dey draws immen≈øe revenues from his own ≈øubjects, which con≈øi≈øt in money, gold, ≈øilver, corn, cattle, and ≈øuch other articles as may be mo≈øt u≈øeful to the Turks in Algiers. The prizes which the cor≈øairs take at ≈øea, ≈øome years equal the taxes on the people. It is from hence ea≈øy to collect that any calculation of revenue mu≈øt be extremely que≈øtionable, and it can hardly be ≈øuppo≈øed that the dey him≈øelf is capable of giving an accurate e≈øtimate.
The regencies of Tunis and Tripoli acknowledge ≈øome ≈øubjection to the dey; but the only annual tribute they pay him is a cargo of butter and oil.

The Alcaide, with a detachment of Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers, collects all taxes within twenty miles of the city of Algiers. Beyond that di≈øtance they dey has three Turki≈øh armies of about 2000 men each, continually reinforced as emergencies require, and ≈øtationed in different parts of his kingdom, for the purpo≈øes of rapine and extortion. The≈øe armies are
≈øeverally commanded by the ba≈øhaws of Con≈øtantina, Bi≈øcara and Deetrie, at the places of their re≈øpective re ‚Ä¢ idence. They are neither actuated by ju≈øtice nor humanity; but with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the≈øe Turki≈øh oppre≈ø≈øors they not only enforce ≈øubjection to the dey, but compel the Moors to the payment of ≈øuch taxes as they think proper. This mi≈øerable race of beings, who are the objects of every indignity and oppre≈ø≈øion that can be offered to human nature, are hunted like wild bea≈øts among the mountains: tho≈øe who di≈øcover the lea≈øt reluctance in paying the a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øments of the≈øe ba≈øhaws, or fly from the rapacity of their pur≈øuers, are beheaded and all their property confi≈øcated. If they have the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpicion that a Moor has concealed any part of his trea≈øure he is tortured till he makes a complete di≈øcovery, and many of the≈øe poor wretches who are unable to make any di≈øclo≈øure are tortured to death, without being able to ≈øatisfy their tormentors. In this manner all gold, ≈øilver and other valuable articles, are extorted from the inhabitants. Some of them, however, have courage enough ≈øometimes to attack their oppre≈ø≈øors in ≈øome of the narrow defiles of the mountains through which they are obliged to pa≈øs, where they frequently make great ≈ølaughter among the Turks; but generally after the fir≈øt fire they fly for refuge to the craggy rece≈ø≈øes of the mountains. They make the≈øe tax gathering excur≈øions twice a year, and in every expedition they bring away immen≈øe numbers of heads and ears, which are ≈øent to the dey, as an evidence of the ba≈øhaws' exertions in having rai≈øed the nece≈ø≈øary contributions. The dey requires that the heads of tho≈øe who are executed near the city ≈øhould be ≈øent in, but of tho≈øe who are murdered at a di≈øtance, he only requires the ears, and the bearer
is rewarded with a certain ≈øum of money for each pair he tenders to his humane ≈øovereign.

Once in every ≈øix months each of the≈øe ba≈øhaws ≈øends in the califs, their ≈øons, with about 50 mules laden with money and other valuable articles. They all en ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Algiers within nine days of each other. At th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ approach the ca≈ø≈øan-aga and aga go out to meet „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and they form a proce≈ø≈øion into the city.

The ba≈øhaws vi≈øit the dey once in every three years, with about 150 mules laden with the ≈øpoils of the country, and when they approach the city a grand proce≈ø≈øion is formed. The ca≈ø≈øan-aga, the aga, the vickelhadge, the chows and li≈øberos, with a detachment of five or ≈øix hundred Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers, go out to meet them, and they are e≈øcorted into the city with drums beating, French horns playing, and colours flying, attended by an immen≈øe concour≈øe of people. The booty is then taken to the dey's palace, where he di≈øtributes a portion to his favo ‚Ä¢ ite wife, and a part among the different officers of government.

After their entry into the city they wait impatiently for the Ta ‚Ä¢ tan, an elegant robe which it is u≈øual for the dey to ≈øend them to ≈øignify his approbation of their conduct; and till they receive this pre≈øent they are in the utmo≈øt ≈øu≈øpen≈øe and apprehen≈øion; for if it does not arrive the day after their entry, they know that the lo≈øs of their heads will be the con≈øequence.

div.head: PUNISHMENTS.
div.p:
IN this country it is not to be expected that ju≈øtice will be admini≈øtered with any degree of impartiality. The M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ometan ≈øoldiery in particular, are ≈øo much favoured, that they are not puni≈øhed in public, and ≈øeldom put to death for any crime, except
rebellion; in which ca≈øe they are either hanged on an iron hook, or ≈øtrangled with a bow-≈øtring, which is tied round the neck of the offender, and drawn different ways by two executioners, with all their ≈øtrength, ≈øo that he is in≈øtantly di≈øpatched. Women guilty of adultery, have a halter tied about their necks, with the other end fa≈øtened to a pole, by which they are held under water till they are ≈øuffocated.

The Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves are liable to a variety of puni≈øhments. They are ≈øometimes burned or rather roa≈øted alive. At other times they are impaled. This is done by placing the criminal on the end of a ≈øharp ≈øtake, which is thru≈øt up his po≈øteriors clo≈øe by the back-bone, till it appears above his ≈øhoulders. Crucifixion, by nailing the hands and feet to walls, is often practi≈øed.

But the mo≈øt terrible puni≈øhments are tho≈øe inflicted upon the Jews or Chri≈øtians who ≈øpeak again≈øt the Mahometan religion; in which ca≈øe they mu≈øt either turn Mahometan, or be impaled alive. If they afterwards apo≈øtatize, they are roa≈øted alive, or el≈øe thrown down from the top of the city walls, upon iron hooks. The≈øe catch by the jaws, the ribs, or other parts of the body, according as they happen to fall, and the ≈øufferers have been known to hang in different po≈øitions for ≈øeveral days alive, in the mo≈øt exqui≈øite torture; though by accident they are ≈øometimes put out of pain at once, as was the ca≈øe with John Ga≈øcon the Spani≈øh adventurer, as before related. This terrible puni≈øhment has frequently been inflicted upon ≈ølaves, but at pre≈øent it begins to be generally di≈øu≈øed.

There is a law here, by which any woman convicted of an amorous corre≈øpondence with a Chri≈øtian, is tied up in a ≈øack and thrown into the ≈øea.
Examples of this kind frequently happen, as the fair ≈øex, in this part of the world, are remarkably frail.

There is another ≈øingular puni≈øhment which is inflicted upon a gallows, which ≈øhews the ≈øavage di≈øpo≈øition of the people. Upon each ≈øide of the gallows, near the upper angle, are fixed two chains of different lengths, to each of which is fa≈øtened a ≈øharp hook. The malefactor a≈øcends the ladder with the executioner, who thru≈øts the hook on the ≈øhorte≈øt chain through the palm of his left hand; after which he thru≈øts that on the longe≈øt chain through the ≈øole of his right foot, and in this manner the criminal is left hanging in the mo≈øt excruciating torture for the ≈øpace of three of four days before he expires.

The we≈øtern Moors ≈øtill practi≈øe the barbarous puni≈øhment of ≈øawing the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øor a≈øunder; which is mo≈øtly inflicted upon per≈øons of di≈øtinction for crimes again≈øt the ≈øtate. For which purpo≈øe they prepare two boards of the ≈øame length and breadth with the delinquent, and having tied him between them, they proceed to the execution by beginning at the head. In this manner did Kardina≈øh ≈øuffer, who was formerly their amba≈ø≈øador to the Briti≈øh court.
For clipping or deba≈øing the public coin, the old Egyptian puni≈øhment is ≈øtill inflicted here, which is cutting off both the hands of the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øor.

In ≈ømaller crimes, or for tho≈øe not capital, the offenders are fined, o ‚Ä¢ their pay ≈øtopped; and if officers, they are reduced to the ≈øtation of common ≈øoldiers, from whence they may gradually rai≈øe them≈øelves to their former dignity. The mo≈øt common puni≈øhment for offences not capital is the ba≈øtinado; and the ≈øtrokes are given either upon the
belly, back, or ≈øoles of the feet, according to the plea≈øure of the cadi, who appoints the number, which ≈øometimes amount to 200 to 300, according to the indulgence the offender can obtain either by bribery or friends; and hence he often dies under this puni≈øhment, for want of advocates ≈øufficiently powerful. The mo≈øt u≈øual mode of ba≈øtinading is upon the ≈øoles of the feet. The criminal is laid on his back or belly, his feet are rai≈øed and tied to a ≈øtake, held fa≈øt by officers for the purpo≈øe, and in this po≈øture the puni≈øhment is inflicted by a number of ≈øticks tied together, of the thickne≈øs of one's little finger. A Moor convicted of hou≈øe-breaking, has his right hand cut off and fa≈øtened about his neck. He is then led through they city on an a≈øs, with his face ‚Ä¢ turned towards its tail. No re≈øpect is paid to the quality of a per≈øon; but a pecuniary mulct will arre≈øt the cour≈øe of ju≈øtice, unle≈øs the offender is guilty of the mo≈øt flagrant crimes.

The u≈øual puni≈øhment for debt is impri≈øonment, according to the practice of ≈øome nations who pretend to the more enlightened. The debtor is u≈øually detained in pri≈øon till the chows or bailiffs have ≈øeized and ≈øold his effects: If the ≈øale amounts to more than the debt, the ≈øurplus is returned to the debtor; if it falls ≈øhort, he is neverthele≈øs relea≈øed, and no future demands are made upon him.

div.head: RELIGION.
div.p:
THE inhabitants of Algiers, as is well known, are Mahometans. But ≈øuch is the depravity of their nature, that they have adopted the very wor≈øt parts of the Mahometan religion, and ≈øeem to have retained
only as much of it as counte ‚Ä¢ ences their vices.

The Mufti, the Cadi, and the grand Marabout, are the principal eccle≈øia≈øtics. The fir≈øt is the high prie≈øt of their religion; the ≈øecond, the ≈øupreme judge in eccle≈øia≈øtical cau≈øes, and in ≈øuch civil matters as the government does not interfere. The third is the chief of an order of ≈øaints or hermits. The≈øe three per≈øons are di≈øtingui≈øhed by the largene≈øs of their turbans. They ≈øit in the divan a little below the dey, on his right hand.

The Algerines have the mo≈øt ≈øingular veneration for idiots; in≈øomuch that numbers of their marabouts pretend to be of this order, that they may receive the greater re≈øpect from the people. The≈øe marabouts either live ≈øeque≈øtered in caves, or wander bare legged and bare footed from city to city, with ragged clothes and a ≈øtaff in their hands, with which they touch ‚Ä¢ uch per≈øons as they think proper, and the per≈øon who is touched in this manner regards it as the mo≈øt ≈øignal favor that can be conferred upon him, becau≈øe he is per≈øuaded that his ≈øins are thereby forgiven. The≈øe marabouts ≈øtudy magic and a≈øtrology; they undertake to cure all di≈øea≈øes, and to in≈øpire love by numbers, and the powers of incantation. They lead very au≈øtere lives, and generally employ them≈øelves in counting their beads, or in prayer and meditation. This ≈øaint≈øhip goes by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and the ≈øon is entitled to the ≈øame veneration and re≈øpect as his father, provided he can ≈øupport the ≈øame gravity and decorum. Some of them are reputed to po≈ø≈øe≈øs the ≈øame faculty as their prophet in receiving vi≈øions and conver≈øing with the Deity.

In Algiers there are many mo≈øques, in which the≈øe marabouts are buried, who are venerated as
≈øaints, and burning lamps are placed round their ≈øepulchres, to which people ≈øend pre≈øents to obtain relief in ≈øickne≈øs, or go thither upon pilgrimage, Tho≈øe who are ≈øubject to the falling ≈øickne≈øs are more highly venerated, becau≈øe Mahomet was troubled with this di≈øea≈øe, and declared that at that time God by his angel Gabriel revealed to him the mo≈øt ≈øacred my≈øteries of his religion.

All tho≈øe Algerines who are of ≈øufficient ability deem it an indi≈øpen≈øible duty to go once in their lives upon a pilgrimage to Mecca, and in con≈øequence of the immen≈øe numbers who re≈øort thither from different parts of Turkey, this city is more thronged than any city in the world.

As the impo≈øition of Mahometani≈øm has been propagated over ≈øuch exten≈øive tracts of country in the other three quarters of the globe, and forms ≈øo intere≈øting a particular in the hi≈øtory of mankind, it will not per ‚Ä¢ aps be impro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r to give ≈øome account of the great founder of this religion.

Mahomet, or Mohammed, ≈øtyled, the Impo≈øtor, was born about the end of the 6th century of the Chri≈øtian aera. He came into the world under many di≈øadvantages. His father Abd'allah was a younger ≈øon of Abd'a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ othaleb; and dying very young, and in his father's life time, left his widow and infant ≈øon in very mean circum≈øtances, his whole ≈øub≈øtance con≈øi≈øting but of five camels and one Ethiopean female ≈ølave. Abd'almotaleb was therefore obliged to take care of his grandchild Mahomet; which he not only did during his life, but at his death enjoined his elde≈øt ≈øon Abu Taleb, who was brother to Abd'allah by the ≈øame mother, to provide for him for the future, which he very affectionately did, and in≈øtructed him in the bu≈øine≈øs of a merchant, which he followed; and to that end he
took him into Syria when he was but thirteen years old. He afterwards recommended him to Khadijah, a rich widow, for her factor, in who≈øe ≈øervice he behaved him≈øelf ≈øo well, that by making him her hu≈øband ≈øhe ≈øoon rai≈øed him to an equality with the riche≈øt in Mecca.

After he began by this advantageous match to live at his ea≈øe, he formed the ≈øcheme of e≈øtabli≈øhing a new religion, or, as he expre≈ø≈øed it, of replanting the only true and ancient one profe≈ø≈øed by Adam, Noah, Abraham, Mo≈øes, Je≈øus, and all the prophets, by de≈øtroying the gro≈øs idolatry into which the generality of his countrymen had fallen, and weeding out the corruptions and ≈øuper≈øtitions which the latter Jews and Chri≈øtians had, as he thought, introduced into their religion, and reducing it to its primitive purity, which con≈øi≈øted chiefly in the wor≈øhip of one God.

Before he made any attempt abroad, he rightly judged that it was nece≈ø≈øary for him to begin with the conver≈øion of his own hou≈øehold. Having therefore retired with his family, as he had done ≈øeveral times before, to a cave in mount Hara, he there opened the ≈øecret of his mi≈ø≈øion to his wife Khadijah; and acquainted her that the angel Gabriel had ju≈øt before appeared to him, and told him that he was appointed the apo≈øtle of God. Khadijah received the news with great joy: ≈øwearing by him in who≈øe hands her ≈øoul was, that ≈øhe tru≈øted he would be the prophet of his nation.

div.head: Its Origin.
div.p: THE names of the original founders of this city have never been ≈øatisfactorily a≈øcertained. The accounts tran≈ømitted to us by hi≈øtorians are involved in much doubt and uncertainty, and its foundation has been a≈øcribed to various princes generally of Roman extraction.

The te≈øtimony of Strabo, however, ≈øeems the mo≈øt authentic. In his account of Mauritania Cae≈øarien≈øis he informs us, that there was formerly an ancient city on the Mediterranean known by the name of Jol, which was founded by Juba the father of P ‚Ä¢ olemy, and ≈øon of Juba the fir≈øt king of that name in Mauritania. div.head: Hou≈øes.

THE ≈øides of the hou≈øes are white, and in con≈øequence at a di≈øtance one would take it to be a place where they bleach linen.
