There are ≈øeveral tolerable edifices without the walls of the town, which add to the beauty of the environs. Among the≈øe are a great number of Turki≈øh ≈øepulchres and monuments; as al≈øo cells or chapels, dedicated to marabouts, or reputed ≈øaints, which the women go to vi≈øit every Friday. One of the≈øe monuments contains ≈øix magnificent tombs of a circular figure, which were erected to the memory of ≈øix deys, who were, in the cour≈øe of a few days, ≈øucce≈ø≈øively elected and murdered. With re≈øpect to the burial of their dead, the Mahometans di≈øcover a degree of delicacy, of which Chri≈øtians have no conception. Their graves are never broken up a ≈øecond time, and the profe≈ø≈øors of the Mahometan religion regard it as an act of the mo≈øt barbarous ≈øacrilege to di≈øturb the remains of the dead, by opening their graves at any di≈øtance of
time, or upon any pretence whatever. Hence their burial grounds in the neighbourhood of a large city are ≈øometimes ten miles in extent.

div.head: Bagnios.
div.p:
THERE are but two bagnios in the city, built of ≈øtone, where the ≈ølaves are lodged, the one called the Bagnio Baleck and the other the Bagnio Gallaro; the former of which i ‚Ä¢ much the large≈øt, and will contain three times as great a number as the latter. They ≈øtand in the main ≈øtreet within about fifty yards of each other, between Bubazoon and the dey's palace. The lower apartments of the≈øe bagnios are occupied as taverns, which are kept by ≈ølaves, who pay the dey an annual tribute for the privilege, according to the quantity of liquor they ≈øell. The tavern-keepers frequently manufacture their own wine in the≈øe bagnios, from g ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pes purcha≈øed of the Moors. To the≈øe places the Turks re≈øort while the ≈ølaves are at labour; but ≈øoon as the ≈ølaves return the warden ba≈øhaw compels them to retire: for they are not ≈øuffered to be with the ≈ølaves. Each apartment is large enough to accommodate about a dozen ≈ølaves. The windows are formed of round cro≈øs bars of iron about three or four inches apart, but without panes of gla≈øs. Down the ≈øides of the walls hang heavy chains of long links fixed to ≈øtaples, with rings to the ends, in which all di≈øorderly ≈ølaves are confined either by the leg or neck till morning, when they are puni≈øhed according to their crimes. The≈øe bagnios are under the guardian≈øhip of two corporals, who
are cho≈øen from among the ≈øtronge≈øt and mo≈øt robu≈øt of the ≈ølaves whom they attend at labour.

In the bagnio Gallaro five apartments are occupied by wild bea≈øts, ≈øuch as lions, tygers, leopards, &c. intended as pre≈øents to nations in alliance with the dey. Some of the≈øe bea≈øts ≈øometimes break loo≈øe from their boxes, and they are not confined again till ≈øome one falls a victim to their fury.
Be≈øides the≈øe ta ‚Ä¢ erns there is one called the Rappagee, near the the port of Bubazoon, and another called the Sanduke of the Luke, intended as a kind of ho≈øpital for lunatics.

The celebrated admiral Pinchinin was the owner of a large bagnio about the year 1640, which is de≈øcribed as follows. This bagnio was occupied by all ≈øuch ≈ølaves as were intended for his galleys. It was a ≈øpacious building through which there was a narrow pa≈ø≈øage or entry, which led into a large vault, that received only a ≈ømall portion of light from a grate above; but ≈øo in≈øufficient that in ≈øome of the apartments it was nece≈ø≈øary to keep lamps burning the whole day. In the upper parts of the building there was a large ≈øquare, containing ≈øeveral galleries two ≈øtories high, between which were ≈øeveral apartments, and a church for Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves large enough to contain 300 per≈øons. The roof was flat and terraced according to the Spani≈øh mode. This bagnio contained 550 ≈ølaves belonging to Pinchinin, whom he allowed three hours every day to provide for their own ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, which they employed in ≈øtealing and the practice of every ≈øpecies of villany. The articles that had been ≈øtolen the preceding day were ≈øold every morning at public auction in the bagnio, and thus
were the≈øe mi≈øerable beings ≈øupported. But great numbers of them, notwith≈øtanding, ≈øtarved to death every year, and a traveller informs us that twenty Engli≈øhmen died here in one winter through mere want.

div.head: Streets.
div.p: NONE of the ≈øtreets in Algiers have any names. They generally a≈øcend with the hill, and are ≈øo extremely narrow that two per≈øons can ≈øcarcely walk a-brea≈øt. The middle part is lower than the ≈øides for the purpo≈øe of conveying off the water more conveniently. The principal ≈øtreet is 1200 paces in length; it runs north and ≈øouth from the port of Bubazoon to Babloet, and is not above twelve feet wide. This ≈øtreet is filled with elegant hou≈øes, and the ≈øtores of the principal merchants, in which there are markets for corn, bread, meat, fi≈øh, &c.

When any loaded bea≈øts, ≈øuch as camels, hor≈øes mules or a≈ø≈øes pa≈øs along, one is forced to ≈øtand up clo≈øe to the wall to let them pa≈øs by; and what is ≈øtill wor≈øe, the in≈øolence of the Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers is ≈øuch that a Chri≈øtian, of whatever rank he may be, mu≈øt ≈øtand clo≈øe again≈øt the wall till they have pa≈ø≈øed by; otherwi≈øe they would not fail to ≈øhow their ≈øuperiority by acts of violence. It has been thought that the ≈øtreets were made narrow, in order that the buildings might afford a ≈øhelter again≈øt the heat of the ≈øun; but it is evident that their narrowne≈øs is intended to prevent the bad effects of earthquakes; ≈øince the fronts of almo≈øt all the hou≈øes are ≈øupported by rafters, which extend from one to the other acro≈øs the ≈øtreets.

div.head: Gates.
div.p: THE city has five gates, which are open from day-break till ≈øun-≈øet; after which no one can enter the city. 1. PORTA PISCOU, or fi≈øher's gate, opens to the mole on the ea≈øt; near this gate is the place of rendezvous for fi≈øhing boats. The fi≈øherman ≈øit in rows within the gate, and expo≈øe their fi≈øh to ≈øale in large ba≈økets. 2. PORTA NOVA, or Newgate, opens to the ≈øouth-we≈øt, and is the pa≈ø≈øage to the imperial ca≈øtle. 3. BABLOET, or as it is rather pronounced Bublywhite, ≈øtands to the north. 4. BABAZIRA, which opens into the harbour. This is the gate where the American pri≈øoners were examined when they pa≈ø≈øed from the marine. 5. BABAZON, or rather Bubazoon, is due ≈øouth: but neither this nor Babloet are of much con≈øideration. Near this gate is the place of execution for ≈ølaves: a platform is built on the top, about fifty feet high, from whence criminals are precipitated down an oblique wall, in which are fixed ganches or hooks at ≈øhort di≈øtances, by which the malefactor is either hung or torn to pieces; and ≈øhould he e≈øcape the≈øe, he is ≈øure to be da≈øhed to pieces upon ≈øharp rocks which lie below.

div.head: City Wall.
div.p:
THE city is ≈øurrounded by a wall about a league in circumference, and defended by ≈øquare towers and ba≈øtions with which they are flanked. The lower part of the wall is of hewn ≈øtone; it is
twelve feet thick, thirty feet high on the land ≈øide, and forty feet towards the ≈øea; and contains many hou≈øes.

div.head: Mole.
div.p:
THE harbour is the work of immen≈øe labour and difficulty. It is about fifteen feet deep, and extremely dangerous for ve≈ø≈øels. It is formed by a mole in the form of a ≈øemicircle, about 500 paces in length, lying north-ea≈øt and ≈øouth-we≈øt from the town to a ≈ømall i≈øland or rock called the Lantern; from which another mole of the ≈øame length is extended north and ≈øouth, for the purpo≈øe of forming a ≈øhelter. In the angle of the≈øe two moles ≈øtands a ≈øquare edifice, in the middle of which there is a court with rails, and four fountains u≈øed for ablutions when the hour of prayer is proclaimed. Round the four ≈øides is a ≈øeat covered with a mat, where the admiral and officers of the navy hold their daily meetings. The ca≈øtle called Sardinia, and the ca≈øtle of the Lantern ≈øtand on the mole; the former of which is mounted with two, and the latter with three tire of guns. The lower tire are 32 pounders; but they are never prepared for defence upon ≈øudden emergencies, for the lower apartments are ≈øo filled with large quantities of lumber and naval ≈øtores, that an enemy, ≈øuddenly running into the harbour, might de≈øtroy the city before they could bring their heavier pieces to play. Along the ≈øide of the mole there is a wharf for loading and unloading ≈øhips, and for mooring galleys and other ve≈ø≈øels. Beneath the mole on one ≈øide is a ≈øtone quay, and on the other ≈øide a ≈øandy and rocky bank. All ve≈ø≈øels lying along ≈øide the mole are moored about fifteen yards from the ≈øhore, and ≈øecured by a
number of cables which extend in different directions, and are la≈øhed fa≈øt to cannon planted in the mole. The mo≈øt boi≈øterous ≈øea is occa≈øioned by a north-ea≈øt wind. I ‚Ä¢ the time of violent ≈øtorms a number of the ≈ølaves, particularly ≈øailors, are continually ≈øtationed upon the mole, with Turki≈øh guards, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the ve≈ø≈øels in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity.
The winter is the mo≈øt dangerous ≈øea≈øon for ve≈ø≈øels, and whenever a violent northern or north-ea≈øt wind blows, they are in danger either of being greatly damaged or driven on ≈øhore.

On the north ≈øide of the rock is ≈øituated the light-hou≈øe fort, which is diligently lighted every night for the ≈øecurity of ve≈ø≈øels entering the harbour. It has three batteries of bra≈øs cannon. A little to the ≈øouthward of this there is another which defends the entrance of the harbour, and is mounted with 80 pieces of cannon, 12, 18, and 36 pounders, pointed from north to ≈øouth; mo≈øt of which were taken taken from the Tuni≈øians in 1617. On the north and ≈øouth mole there are rope-walks and ≈øeveral magazines, where naval ≈øtores, and the cargoes of captured ve≈ø≈øels are depo≈øited.

div.head: Ca≈øtles and Fortifications.
div.p:
NEAR the city on the land ≈øide are four ca≈øtles, the mo≈øt con≈øiderable of which is the imperial ca≈øtle, or the ca≈øtle of the emperor, which is ≈øituated on an eminence at the di≈øtance of half a league to the ≈øouth ≈øouth-we≈øt, and commands the whole city, harbour, and the adjacent country. It is ≈øo called becau≈øe the emperor Charles V. laid the foundation of it in 1541, when he was be≈øieging the city. But it is only mounted with a few pieces of ≈ømall cannon,
either through neglect or an apprehen≈øion that it might prove de≈øtructive to the city in ca≈øe it ≈øhould fall into the hands of an enemy; for it is ≈øituated on ≈øo advantageous an eminence that from it the city might ≈øoon be battered into ruins.

The new ca≈øtle, commonly called the Star, is built in a hepta ‚Ä¢ onal form, and ≈øituated on an eminence to the ≈øouth-we≈øt. The other two are called Bubazoon and Bobloet, becau≈øe they are near and oppo≈øite the gates of the ≈øame name; but neither of them are of much con≈øideration.

Be≈øides the≈øe there are ≈øeveral along the ≈øhore on the we≈øt ≈øide of the city. The battery of the mole gate ≈øtands upon the ea≈øt angle of the city, and is mounted with ≈øix pieces of ordnance, one of which has ≈øeven cylinders, each of them three inches in diameter. About half a league to the we≈øt ≈øouth-we≈øt of the harbour is the battery of the fi≈øher's gate, which is defended by a double tire of cannon, and commands the entrance of the port and the road before it.

The ≈øtronge≈øt fortifications are at the entrance of the harbour, the ≈øituation of which adds to its ≈øecurity; as the northern winds are generally violent, and occa≈øion ≈øuch a ≈øea, that ≈øhips would be expo≈øed to great danger, either in the road or along the ≈øhore.

Many former writers, either through ignorance, or a mi≈øgrounded prejudice, have repre≈øented all the≈øe fortification ≈øo impregnable that they bid defiance to the confederated powers of the Chri≈øtians. But recent and more accurate ob≈øervations have detected the fallacy of this account: and all per≈øons of ob≈øervation who have lately re≈øided there, unanimou≈øly concur in the opinion, that three or at mo≈øt four Briti≈øh fifty-gun ≈øhips, provided they
met with no di≈øa≈øter from the elements, would ≈øoon batter it about the ears of the inhabitants from the harbour. A late writer ob≈øerves, that notwith≈øtanding their fortifications, the city is ≈øo commanded by the adjacent kills on every ≈øide but that of the ≈øea, that from the≈øe eminencies, where it is mo≈øt vulnerable, a be≈øieging army would ≈øoon batter it into a heap of ruins.

It is not a little ≈øingular, however, that this city has, for ≈øeveral ages, braved ≈øome of the greate≈øt powers in Chri≈øtendom: but this mu≈øt be imputed to the very injudicious conduct of mo≈øt of the be≈øiegers, or the violence of tempe≈øts which have proved de≈øtructive to ≈øo many ve≈ø≈øels in their harbour. The Spaniards in their attempts to reduce Algiers, have been the mo≈øt material ≈øufferers; but the pu≈øilanimity of their forces has long been proverbial, and Spani≈øh di≈øcomfiture is no kind of criterion to judge of the defen≈øive powers of the Algerines.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Inhabitants, cu≈øtoms and manners of the city of Algiers.

div.p:
THE pre≈øent dey of Algiers was originally a Turki≈øh ≈øoldier, and was imported into Algiers from a place near Smyrna about the year 1786. He was at fir≈øt employed about the old dey's palace, and by his artifice he ≈øoon after became ≈øo great a court favorite, that he obtained the office of vichelhadge of the marine. Shortly after this event the ca≈ø≈øan-aga, or prime mini≈øter, through the intrigues of the ba≈øhaw of Con≈øtantina with the old dey, fell a victim to the bow-≈øtring, and Ha≈ø≈øan Ba≈øhaw, the pre≈øent dey, was promoted to the vacant office of ca≈ø≈øan-aga, Cedelli, who was a Grecian of an enterpri≈øing ≈øpirit, ≈øucceeded him in the office of vichelhadge, and the old dey ≈øhortly after dying a natural death, Cedelli, who was Ha≈ø≈øan's friend, in≈øi≈øted upon his a≈ø≈øuming the imperial chair. Ha≈ø≈øan di≈øcovered great reluctance; but Cedelli, who came armed with a party for the purpo≈øe, forced him into the chair and ≈øupported him there. The aga ≈øhortly after made his appearance, intending to conte≈øt the right of ≈øovereignty with him, and attempted to a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinate him him in his ≈øeat; but he was ≈øeized by the chiahs, who dragged him to the Logger Ba≈øtion, where he received the bow-≈øtring, and one of Ha≈ø≈øan's friends was appointed aga in his ≈øtead.
Ha≈ø≈øan afterward ‚Ä¢ married the daughter of the former ca≈ø≈øan-aga, who had been executed through the intrigues of the ba≈øhaw of Con≈øtantina, and after Ha≈ø≈øan was e≈øtabli≈øhed in the ≈øovereignty, ≈øhe per≈øuaded him to bow-≈øtring this ba≈øhaw; and as ≈øhe was Ha≈ø≈øan's favorite wife her de≈øire was granted, and the ba≈øhaw fell a victim to her re≈øentment.

Cedelli ≈øoon after greatly incurred the di≈øplea≈øure of Ha≈ø≈øan. The dey had i≈ø≈øued orders that no Dutch ve≈ø≈øels ≈øhould be captured within forty days; but Cedelli, either through de≈øign or inadvertence, gave in≈øtructions to the cor≈øairs to make immediate captures, and ≈øeveral Dutch ve≈ø≈øels were brought into Algiers; which ≈øo violently exa≈øperated Ha≈ø≈øan, that he demanded in a vengeful and ≈øarca≈øtic tone, whether he or Cedelli was dey of Algiers? Cedelli fortunately e≈øcaped the bow≈øtring, but was immediately bani≈øhed from Algiers.

When con≈øuls, foreign agents, and other official characters enter the dey's palace, they are reque≈øted to pull off their ≈øhoes, and this ceremony is always expected. His vi≈øitors then approach him with great reverence and ki≈øs his hand. The dey and his vi≈øitors are ≈øeated on ≈ølabs of marble or ≈ølate projecting from the wall, about three feet high, upon which are placed cu≈øhions elegantly embroidered and fringed with gold, where his vi≈øitors ≈øit cro≈øs legged. The dey ≈øits with a large fan of o≈øtriches' feathers in his hand. All other Turks of di≈øtinction receive their vi≈øitors in the ≈øame manner. While they are thus ≈øeated they are ≈øerved by ≈ølaves with coffee, which is con≈øidered the greate≈øt treat that can be given, and as a particular mark of di≈øtinction conferred upon his vi≈øitors.

No per≈øon is ≈øuffered to enter his palace with d ‚Ä¢ ggers or any kind of arms; and when ≈øuch attempts are made, the dey, through apprehen≈øion of a≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øination, makes the mo≈øt hideous outcries; the delinquent is ≈øeized, and ≈øeveral hundred ≈øtrokes of the ba≈øtinado are inflicted upon him for the offence.

When the Grand Signior approves of the dey's conduct he ≈øends him an elegant robe called a Ta ‚Ä¢
tan to ≈øignify his approbation of his conduct in admini≈øtration. A pre≈øent of this nature is highly acceptable, becau≈øe it is a great protection to his per≈øon, and conciliates the minds of the people in his favour.

The pre≈øent dey is about 50 years old. His face is decorated with a long black beard. He is a man of a venerable a≈øpect and of a meje≈øtic per≈øon, being about ≈øix feet high, but rather inclining to leanne≈øs. He ≈øpeaks in a very imperious and authoritative tone, as is the ca≈øe with all the Turks. He goes bare legged, but with ≈ølippers on his feet, and cannot be di≈øtingui≈øhed by his dre≈øs from the re≈øt of the Turks; but only by the greater veneration that is paid him.

When he walks the ≈øtreets of Algiers his li≈øberos go before him with clubs in their hands to clear the way, and as he approaches every per≈øon flies with precipitation into bye-ways; for if any one comes within the reach of their clubs he is ≈øure to be knocked down and trampled under foot. When he rides out, even upon a full gallop, the≈øe li≈øberos run before him, and every ob≈øtacle mu≈øt give way at his approach.

While the American pri≈øoners were in Algiers the dey once conde≈øcended to vi≈øit the marine, which was looked upon as the mo≈øt ≈øingular event that ever occurred; for neither the dey, the ca≈ø≈øan-aga,
nor aga, are ever known to pay ≈øuch vi≈øits. As he approached the ≈øhore the cannon of the ca≈øtles, and on the walls of the city were fired, trumpets ≈øounded, and French horns played from the marine. He was attended by all the rais or commanders of ve≈ø≈øels, who regarded this vi≈øit as the very highe≈øt compliment. He gave the warden ba≈øhaw a con≈øiderable ≈øum of money to be di≈øtributed among the ≈ølaves. After examining the marine he was invited into the ≈økiff of the vichelhadge, where he ≈øat down with his attendants and after drinking a di≈øh of coffee retired to his palace.

The dey keeps about 30 concubines in his ≈øeraglio, who are attended by black enuchs, but the women are never ≈øeen by the ≈ølaves. He has but one child, a daughter about ≈øeven years old, who is the greate≈øt favorite imaginable with the dey. She was engaged to be married to the late vichelhadge of the marine, who was the dey's relation. But he was either killed or drowned in his voyage to the Levant, where the dey ≈øent him with a large ≈øum of money, for the purpo≈øe of building a ≈øuperb mo≈øque at the place of his birth.

From the mo≈øt authentic accounts it appears that many of the people of Algiers, and the kingdom in general, are ho≈øpitable, humane, and of ≈øtrict integrity. A Moor when he finds any articles that have been lo≈øt, never clande≈øtinely appropriates them to his own u≈øe, but has them always cried through the ≈øtreets that the owner may po≈ø≈øe≈øs his property again. But in con≈øequence of the violence that is exerci≈øed over them, and their total ≈øub≈øerviency to the rapacious views of their Turki≈øh oppre≈ø≈øors, they ≈øupport perhaps the mo≈øt infamous character of any nation in the world. Every ≈øpark of political liberty is totally extingui≈øhed,
and the government has now attained to the very acme of the mo≈øt horrible de≈øpoti≈øm. As the Turks maintain their a≈øcendency by the mo≈øt rigorous mea≈øures, their government exhibits a perpetual ≈øcene of jealou≈øy, apprehen≈øion and oppre≈ø≈øion; no man can promi≈øe him≈øelf a moment's ≈øecurity either in his per≈øon or property; for the power of life and death is ve≈øted in the hands of the dey, which he exerci≈øes with impunity; and whenever he covets the riches of any of his opulent ≈øubjects, he orders them to be di≈øpatched with a bow-≈øtring, and falls heir to what they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. When the order of execution is announced to any one, he ≈øubmits patiently to his fate, which he has perhaps long anticipated, and as ≈øoon as the order is executed there is an immediate ≈øcramble among the ≈øervants for the money, jewels, and other valuable articles which belonged to their ma≈øter.

According to the common computation, the number of inhabitants in this city is 100,000 Mahometans, 1500 Jews, and 2000 Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves; but no cen≈øus can be accurate for any length of time, as thou≈øands are carried off by the plague; and the number of ≈ølaves is ≈øtill more fluctuating, as they are ≈øubject to an uncertain increa≈øe by capture, and a diminution by ran≈øom, or death by the ≈øeverity of their toils.

The city of Algiers is vi≈øited almo≈øt every year by the plague, which generally begins in May, and continues for the ≈øpace of three months. When it commences its vi≈øitation no per≈øon is at liberty to circulate any report of its exi≈øtence, or his life would be in danger; but when the contagion becomes more prevalent one of the marabouts vi≈øits the dey
and informs him of its exi≈øtence; after which the citizens are at liberty to take every precaution for their pre≈øervation; ≈øome retire into the country, but the dey and mo≈øt of the people always remain in the city. The fir≈øt ≈øtage of this di≈øorder is a violent fever which brings on a delirium, but if the patient can ≈øurvive this fever he has every a≈ø≈øurance of his recovery. The di≈øea≈øe, however, operates differently upon different con≈øtitutions; ≈øome blead at the mouth, no≈øe, and ears; ≈øome break out in lived ≈øpots all over their bodies, and many continue in a ≈øtate of coma, or lethargy, till they expire, which „Äà‚óä„Äâ generally at the end of the third day after the di≈øorder ≈øeizes them. About one half of tho≈øe who are attacked by this di≈øorder recover, but they are notwith≈øtanding always liable to, though not ≈øo ≈øu≈øceptible of the infection after they have once been ≈øeized with it.

A mo≈øt malignant plague raged in Algiers about the year 1787, which carried off immen≈øe numbers of the inhabitants; the di≈øea≈øe was ≈øo virulent that the ≈øtreets were filled with dead bodies, and the mortality ≈øo great that a ≈øufficient number of per≈øons could ≈øcarcely be procured to bury them. Slaves are very frequently ≈øeized with this di≈øorder at their labour, and they are ≈øuffered to die upon the ground without any a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and with as much unconcern as if they were bea≈øts‚ñ™ As they have neither medical books, nor men of learning, it mu≈øt naturally be ≈øuppo≈øed they have no phy≈øicians. When a per≈øon is ≈øeized with any di≈øorder the only mode of cure is to rub the patient, and at the ≈øame time to place his body in a variety of attitudes, and if this whim≈øical treatment does not ≈øucceed, nothing farther is attempted.

The people of A ‚Ä¢ giers eat no breakfa≈øt, but between ≈øix and ≈øeven o'clock in the morning they drink coffee, with which they are ≈øerved by per≈øons called coffeegees, who≈øe bu≈øine≈øs it is to ≈øupply the „Äà‚óä„Äâ every morning with this article. All the Mahometans who re≈øide near the city, immediately pro≈øtrate them≈øelves as ≈øoon as they ≈øee the flags rai≈øed on the mo≈øques; and be≈øides all this religious ≈øervitude the≈øe very righteous people daily employ them≈øelves, like the illiterate among the Roman Catholics, in counting over their ≈øtrings of beads.

The dey only attends public wor≈øhip on Fridays, at a mo≈øque nearly oppo≈øite to his palace, where the principal Turks a≈ø≈øemble, and he pa≈ø≈øes between two files of his Turki≈øh guards, who are ≈øtationed between the door of his palace and that of the mo≈øque.

Every Friday is devoted to public wor≈øhip, and corre≈øponds to the Jewi≈øh Saturday, or Chri≈øtian ‚Ä¢ unday. Many rea≈øons are given why this day was appointed for this purpo≈øe. Some are of opi
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on that it was the day on which God fini≈øhed

Though the Mahometans in general do not conceive them≈øelves obligated to keep that day ≈øo holy as the Jews and Chri≈øtians are bound to keep their Sabbath, (there being permi≈ø≈øion in the Alcoran, as is generally ≈øuppo≈øedChap. 62., that that they may return to their employments or diver≈øions after divine ≈øervice is ended,) yet the more devout di≈øapprove of the practice of applying any part of that day to worldly concerns, and require it to be wholly dedicated to the purpo≈øes of religion. The ≈ølaves are neither exempted from labour upon this, nor any other day of the week; but they are generally allowed one Friday in every month for the purpo≈øe of re≈øt or recreation.

All the≈øe religious re≈øtrictions are, however, in≈øufficient, and once every year they are ≈øubjected to a rigorous ab≈øtinence called Ramadan, or Ramazan, which generally begins in May, and continues from the time the new moon fir≈øt appears till the appearance of the next new moon, during which time they refrain from women, and neither eat, drink, ≈ønuff, nor ≈ømoke tobacco, from day-break, till ≈øun-≈øet. About ≈øun-≈øet the „Äà‚óä„Äâ
of the marabout ri≈øes, as a ≈øignal for eating, which is looked for with great anxiety; after which they are at liberty to gratify their appetites as they plea≈øe. During the time of Ramadan an univer≈øal moro≈øene≈øs prevails among the people, and the dey, who finds it nece≈ø≈øary to conform to this cu≈øtom, is ≈øo much out of humour, that no bu≈øine≈øs can be tran≈øacted with him during the continuance of this fa≈øt. val; for at the moment of its appearance the fa≈øt is at an end: the Turks then indulge the mo≈øt extravagant mirth; they fire a feu de joye to congratulate its appearance, and to proclaim the end of the fa≈øt.

This fa≈øt, which is the third point of religious practice, is a duty of ≈øo much importance, that Mahomet u≈øed to ≈øay, It was the gate of religion, and that the odour of the mouth of him who fa≈øteth is more grateful to God than that of mu≈øk.

According to the Mahometan divines there are three degrees of fa≈øting; 1≈øt. The re≈øtraining the belly and other parts of the body from ≈øatisfying their lu≈øt. 2d. The re≈øtraining the ears, eyes, tongue, hands, ‚Ä¢ eet, and others members from ≈øin. 3d. The fa≈øting of the heart from all worldly cares, and refraining the thoughts from every thing be≈øides God. The Mahometans are obliged, by expre≈øs
command of the Alcoran, to fa≈øt the whole month of Ramadan, and in con≈øequence of this ab≈øtemious ≈øeverity, which is a real ≈øin again≈øt the law of nature, an univer≈øal gloom overwhelms the minds of the people; they are extremely vengeful, and more murders and a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinations happen then than at any other time. The ≈ølaves are not compelled to conform to any of their religious ceremonies or re≈øtrictions; but during the time of Ramadan they are ≈øubjected to the infliction of the ≈øevere≈øt puni≈øhments: for ≈øuch ab≈øtinence has a tendency to excite the mo≈øt boi≈øterous pa≈ø≈øions of the human brea≈øt.

This fa≈øt is ≈øucceeded by a Bairam or fe≈øtival, called the fea≈øt of the breaking of the fa≈øt, which continues for three days, during which time the half ≈øtarved Turks riot in the oppo≈øite extreme of intemperance. But their greate≈øt fe≈øtival is on the fifth of September, the day of the nativity of their prophet, which is celebrated with great ≈øolemnity. Two of the ma≈øters carry on their ≈øhoulders a ≈øuperb pyramid ornamented with wreathes of flowers, and a cro≈øs on the top of it, and followed by a band of „Äà‚óä„Äâ and in≈øtrumental mu≈øic after the Turki≈øh manner. All the hou≈øes at the corners of the ≈øtreets are „Äà‚óä„Äâ
with tape≈øtry and burning lamps. The cooks of the divan to the number of 200 al≈øo form a proce≈ø≈øion, each carrying a clean napkin or towel on his ≈øhoulder and a torch in his hand. They parade the ≈øtreets two by two, from ≈øeven till eleven o'clock in the day, and the ceremony ends with a hymn in prai≈øe of their prophet, performed with in≈øtruments of mu≈øic before the doors of ≈øome of their great men. There is a ≈øingular cu≈øtom e≈øtabli≈øhed here, of a religious nature, for the remi≈ø≈øion of the puni≈øhment of offenders who fly to the mo≈øques for protection, which is called taking the marabout, and the≈øe places are an a≈øylum for every de≈øcription of criminals. In the front of every mo≈øque there is ≈øu≈øpended a long chain, which the criminal ≈øeizes; whereupon he is generally taken into the ≈øanctuary and covered with the marabout's colours, from whence he is not ≈øuffered to be taken till his pardon is granted. One of the≈øe chains is ≈øu≈øpended in front of the dey's palace, who ≈øometimes pardons offenders who fly thither for refuge, and another is ≈øu≈øpended at the cazarees of the Turks, where criminals are more inviolably protected.

A quarrel took place not long ≈øince between two lads about twelve years of age, the one a Turk and the other a Moor, as they were pa≈ø≈øing from the marine to the city. When they came oppo≈øite to the cazarees, the young Turk, taking the advantage
of the Moori≈øh lad, ran up to him with his drawn tahan, and gave him a wound through the back, of which he in≈øtantly expired, and immediately fled for refuge to the cazarees, where he was protected, till the friends of the Turki≈øh lad procured his pardon by paying the parents of the decea≈øed a ≈øum of money as a compen≈øation for their lo≈øs.

It is a vulgar opinion among the Algerines, and the Mahometans in general, that women have no ≈øouls; or if they have, that they die like tho≈øe of the brutes, and will receive no reward in the next life. This is probably the rea≈øon why they are never ≈øuffered to go upon a pilgrimage, or to attend public wor≈øhip in their mo≈øques. But whatever may be the vulgar belief‚ñ™ it is evident that Mahomet had too great a re≈øpect for the fair ≈øex, to inculcate ≈øuch a doctrine; for there are ≈øeveral pa≈ø≈øages in the Alcocoran, which expre≈øly affirm that women in the next life will not only be puni≈øhed for their evil deeds, but will be rewarded for their virtues as well as men, and that in this re≈øpect God will make no di≈øtinction of ≈øexes.

It is true that the general notion is, that they will not be admitted into the ≈øame abode with the men, becau≈øe their places will be ≈øupplied by paradi≈øiacal females, but that a ≈øeparate place of happine≈øs will be a≈ø≈øigned to good women, where they will enjoy every delight in its fulle≈øt extent: yet ≈øome allege that a man will have tho≈øe who were his wives in this world, or at lea≈øt ≈øuch of them as he ≈øhall de≈øire. One circum≈øtance with which Mahomet acquainted his followers, ought to corroborate their belief of the future exi≈øtence of the female ≈øoul. An old woman de≈øired him to intercede with God for her
admi≈ø≈øion into paradi≈øe; but Mahomet told her that no old women would ever enter that place; upon which the old woman began to weep immoderately, and Mahomet explained him≈øelf by a≈ø≈øuring her, that God would make her young again.

The Alcoran certainly e≈øtabli≈øhes a different belief in the following words: Verily the Mo≈ølems (or Mu≈ø≈øulmen) of either ≈øex, and the true believers of either ≈øex; and the devout men, and the devout women; and the men of veracity and the women of veracity; and the patient men and the patient women; and the humble men and the humble women; and the alms- „Äà‚óä„Äâ of either ≈øex; and the men who fa≈øt and the women who fa≈øt; and the cha≈øte men and the cha≈øte women; and tho≈øe of either ≈øex who remember God frequently; for them God has prepared forgivene≈øs and a great rewardChap. XXXIII. entitled The Confederates. .

Great numbers of the citizens of Algiers perform a journey to Mecca every year, and many ve≈ø≈øels are employed in tran≈øporting them to this holy city for the purpo≈øe of manufacturing them into ≈øaints. This pilgrimage is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary a point in practical religion, that according to a tradition of Mahomet, he who dies without performing it may as well die a Jew or Chri≈øtian. Mr. Tournefort tells us, that the four places of rendezvous for pilgrims, are Damas, Cairo, Babylon, and Zebir. At the≈øe places they dre≈øs
them≈øelves in the ≈øacred habit, which con≈øi≈øts of two woolen wrappers, one about the middle to cover their nakedne≈øs, and the other thrown over their ≈øhoulders; and in this dre≈øs they enter the ≈øacred territory. All the caravans which come from different parts of the Mahometan dominions, concert their mea≈øures in ≈øuch a manner that they arrive the ≈øame day at the hill Arafagd, which is about a day's journey from Mecca: on this celebrated hill they imagine that the angel fir≈øt appeared to their prophet, and in con≈øequence the Mahometans have founded one of their principal ≈øanctuaries on this ≈øpot.

The Grand Signior al≈øo ≈øends 500 ≈øequins, an Alcoran covered with gold, ≈øeveral rich carpets, and a great many pieces of black cloth for hangings, as pre≈øents to the mo≈øques at Mecca. The pilgrims who have performed the tour of Mecca are held in great veneration the remainder of their lives; are ab≈øolved from every ≈øin, and may commit new crimes with impunity. div.head: CHAP. IV.
div.p: WHATEVER ≈øpeculative maniacs or mercenary enthu≈øia≈øts may allege in favour of ≈ølavery, it is obviou≈øly repugnant to the impre≈øcriptible rights of human nature, and an inconte≈øtible evidence of the remains of barbari≈øm in tho≈øe nations who ≈øanction ≈øo diabolical a principle.

There appear to be three ≈øtages in the progre≈øs of mankind from ≈øavage rudene≈øs to a ≈øtate of true refinement. Fir≈øt, a ≈øtate of canibali≈øm, in which any tribe or nation of men deal indi≈øcriminate death and de≈øtruction among the re≈øt of their fellow creatures; ≈øecond, a ≈øtate of oppre≈ø≈øion, in which, though they are exempted from the fangs of ≈øavage rapacity, yet they are compelled to ≈øubmit to the lo≈øs of their liberties; third, the emancipation of mankind, when the more general diffu≈øion of ≈øcience will teach them the true principles of ju≈øtice and humanity. But the grand ≈øcience of univer≈øal benevolence mu≈øt be re≈øerved for future ages; for though many modern nations imagine them≈øelves to be eminently enlightened, yet they are in fact but ju≈øt beginning to emerge from the intermediate ≈øtate between barbarity and true refinement.

For the practice of ≈ølavery we are not to reprobate the Algerines alone; for the divan of Great Britain are equally reprehen≈øible, and have more
eminently di≈øtingui≈øhed them≈øelves in this nefarious commerce. From them we have adopted the execrable practice, and the United States, emphatically called the land of liberty, ≈øwarm with tho≈øe ≈øemi-barbarians who enthral their fellow creatures without the lea≈øt remor≈øe. With what countenance then can we reproach a ≈øet of barbarians, who have only retorted our own acts upon our≈øelves in making repri≈øals upon our citizens? For it is manife≈øt to the world, that we are equally culpable, and in whatever terms of opprobrium we may execrate the piratic di≈øpo≈øition of the Africans, yet all our recriminations will recoil upon our≈øelves.

Having premi≈øed thus much, we ≈øhall now proceed to make a few ob≈øervations upon the ≈ølaves of Algi ‚Ä¢ rs, and as a preliminary we ≈øhall detail the particulars of the capture of the ≈øhip Pre≈øident, that the public may have ≈øome idea of the≈øe banditti of the ocean.

On the 23d of October 1793, about nine o'clock in the morning, the crew of the ≈øhip Pre≈øident, when they were only within a few hours ≈øail of Cadiz, the port to which they were bound, di≈øcovered an armed xebeck of 16 guns‚ñ™ under Spani≈øh colours, bearing down upon them; upon which the American flag was immediately hoi≈øted, and as a very light breeze prevailed it was a con≈øiderable time before the two ve≈ø≈øels were within hail of each other. When the xebeck came within gun-≈øhot of the American ve≈ø≈øel ≈øhe hauled down her Spani≈øh colours, hoi≈øted the bloody flag, and fired a platoon of ≈ømall arms. This circum≈øtance threw them into the mo≈øt violent con≈øternation imaginable, and their fir≈øt aim was to ≈øecure their clothes, money, and other articles. The pirates ≈øoon after hoi≈øted out their boat, into which
about thirty armed men entered, who rowed with great violence towards the American ve≈ø≈øel, which they boarded with pi≈øtols and drawn ≈øwords, and with the greate≈øt fury and ≈øhouting imaginable, in order to impre≈øs the minds of the Americans with a conviction of their great intrepidity in a naval attack.

As ≈øoon as they were on deck, they fell foul of the crew like ≈øo many ravenous wolves that had broken loo≈øe from their kennel; they tore off their „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and the mo≈øt furious ≈øcramble ≈øucceeded „Äà‚óä„Äâ can be conceived; every one being anxious to appropriate mo≈øt of the booty to him≈øelf. One American a≈ø≈øures us that he was ≈øeized by no le≈øs than four Algerines at once, who threw him down and ≈øtripped him naked; but what evinced the mo≈øt ≈øingular ferocity in human nature, in ≈øcrambling for his clothes tho≈øe furies came to blows among them≈øelves; the moment one had torn off his coat, another attempted to wre≈øt it from him, and a bu≈øtle en≈øued between them. The two that had ≈øeized his trow≈øers tore them in pieces in their ≈øtruggle for po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and a ≈øcene of ≈øimilar rapacity was acted towards every other American. Every part of the ve≈ø≈øel was rifle ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ che≈øts were broken open, and they ≈øeized every article that could be carried off with an avaricious fury, characteri≈øtic of no other nation under heaven.

After they had loaded them≈øelves with plunder, they thru≈øt all the American crew into their boat, in this naked and in≈øulted condition, at the point of their cutla≈ø≈øes; tho≈øe who di≈øcovered any reluctance, were knocked down and kicked into the boat, where they were trampled under foot by this clan of de≈øparadoes. They were taken on board the xebeck, and another boat's crew immediately returned to take charge of the American ve≈ø≈øel.
Here they had the plea≈øure of being introduced to Rais Mahomet, the commander of the xebeck, an emaciated loath≈øome figure, who ≈øat ≈ømoking his pipe upon a ≈øheep-≈økin, and ≈øipping a di≈øh of coffee which was placed before him. It is not a little ≈øurprizing, that ≈øuch a mi≈øerable object ≈øhould be appointed to the command of a cor≈øair, and this circum≈øtance mu≈øt evince the futility of their naval policy. He appeared to be upwards of a hundred years old, and through age and impotency, was ≈øcarcely able to ≈øupport a tottering frame. His hands were pal≈øied; his eyes ≈øunk deep in his head, and through weakne≈øs dripped a continual flow of tears. From his gha≈øtly vi≈øage flowed a beard of the brighte≈øt ≈øilver, except where it was ≈øullied by the drippings of his coffee, and an involuntary di≈øcharge of ≈øpittle. His voice was ≈øcarcely audible, and in his exterior he re≈øembled ≈øome old hermit, that had been immured a hundred ye ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚ñ™

Such was the commander of the Algerine xebeck. When they had fea≈øted their curio≈øity upon this very venerable figure, their attention was turned to their new quarters, which they ≈øurveyed with new a≈øtoni≈øhment. Nearly a hundred and fifty Algerines were crowded into this ve≈ø≈øel, and whatever de≈øcription can be drawn by the mo≈øt fertile imagination, of lice, fleas, filth and ≈øtench, was here nearly reali≈øed. Their decks were never ≈øuffered to be ≈øwept or wa≈øhed, and they ≈øeemed to pre≈øerve their dirt with a kind of veneration. The≈øe delicate planks they ≈øub≈øtituted for tables, upon which they ate their provi≈øions, which con≈øi≈øted of olives, bread, vinegar and oil. When they had fini≈øhed their meals, they threw part of the fragments overboard, and the remainder was trampled into the general ma≈øs of filth.

As ≈øoon as they had ≈øecured their prize, the mo≈øt extravagant mirth and boi≈øterous exultation ≈øucceeded; to commemorate the event a ≈øheep was ≈øacrificed, and after be≈ømearing the ≈øides of the ve≈ø≈øel with its blood, they concluded the ceremony by devouring its fle≈øh.

After the termination of this fe≈øtivity, the pri≈øoners were arraigned on deck, and a ≈øecond ≈øtripping took place. Tho≈øe who had not been deprived of all their clothes at fir≈øt, were now ≈øtripped naked, and in their ≈øtead they were accommodated with a few dirty rags, which had been the refu≈øe of this lou≈øy crew. By Mahomet's order, the clothes of the captives were all thrown together in a heap, and ≈øold at public vendue.

The mo≈øt laborious part of duty in the xebeck was then a≈ø≈øigned to the Americans, and the pirates, ≈øolely intent upon ≈øecuring their prize, immediately ≈øtood in for the ≈øtreights without looking out for further plunder. In their pa≈ø≈øage the Americans could not help remarking the continual dread and apprehen≈øion of the≈øe free-booters, who were continually looking out with their gla≈ø≈øes, and like a band of thieves who were con≈øcious of the villany of their profe≈ø≈øion, they trembled with the mo≈øt vi≈øible con≈øternation at every ≈øail that hove in ≈øight. The Americans repre≈øent the≈øe pirates as the mo≈øt undi≈øciplined and pu≈øilanimous ≈øailors in the world, and in≈øi≈øt that the mo≈øt incon≈øiderate naval force with Briti≈øh di≈øcipline, is ≈øufficient to defeat or keep any of them at bay. The greate≈øt di≈øplay of Algerine bravery, is at the commencement of an engagement, when they endeavour to intimidate their enemies, like the American ≈øavages, with the mo≈øt horrible yells.

In the afternoon of the ≈øame day the Pre≈øident was captured they fell in with a Briti≈øh frigate, when the
Americans were ordered below, and on the ≈øecond day with a Briti≈øh merchantman, with whom they had before been in company without the ≈øtreights, whom they reque≈øted to publi≈øh an account of their capture at the fir≈øt port they touched.

On their pa≈ø≈øage up the ≈øtreights they had it frequently in contemplation to ri≈øe upon the Algerine crew, to di≈øarm tho≈øe upon watch, and to confine the re≈øt below by ≈øecuring the hatches; but their ≈ømall number deterred them from ≈øuch an attempt.

On the 30th of October they arrived at Algiers, and were taken a≈øhore to the vichelhadge's ≈økiff, where they were attended by the dey's ≈øcrivan or head clerk, who conducted them to the palace. Here they were lodged in an outer court, which had been occupied as a kind of black-≈ømith's ≈øhop, where they were refre≈øhed with a me≈øs of cuzcuz, and after repo≈øing the fir≈øt night upon ≈øome ≈øacks of ≈øtraw, they were ordered to the Bagnio Baleck.

When the crews of the American ve≈ø≈øels were captured they were entirely ≈øtripped of their dre≈øs, and pre≈øented in exchange with a parcel of old rags and a pair of coar≈øe trow≈øers, which only reached down to their knees. They laboured for ≈øeveral months in this wretched apparel, which was not ≈øufficient to protect them from the rays of a ≈øcorching ≈øun, till at length each captive was accommodated by the United States with a hat and a ≈øuit of blue clothes, which were ≈øent them from Alicant by Mr. Montgomery the American con≈øul; a provi≈øion which they received annually while they continued in this mi≈øerable abode. ≈øums that were ≈øeverally allotted to the captives. To each private there was granted an allowance of 3 dollars and 75 cents, to each mate 6 dollars, and to each captain 8 dollars per month‚Äîa very unju≈øt di≈øtinction, e≈øpecially as the privates were ≈øubjected to much greater hard≈øhips than either the captains or mates. Every public ≈ølave wore an iron ring round his ancle, which was always an evidence of his belonging to the public, and no Turk could mole≈øt or even in≈øult a ≈ølave of this de≈øcription with impunity; but this badge was not conferred upon the private ≈ølaves. When a cor≈øair takes a prize he carries the captives directly to the palace of the dey, where the European con≈øuls a≈ø≈øemble, to ≈øee if any of the pri≈øoners
belong to their re≈øpective nations, who are at peace with Algiers. In that ca≈øe they reclaim them, provided they were only pa≈ø≈øengers; but if they have ≈øerved on board of the ≈øhips of any people at war with this regency, they cannot be di≈øcharged without payment of the full ran≈øom.

The deys formerly had their choice only of every eighth ≈ølave, and they generally cho≈øe the ma≈øters, ≈øurgeons, carpenters, and the mo≈øt u≈øeful hands belonging to the ≈øeveral prizes, be≈øides per≈øons of quality, for whom they expected a large ran≈øom; but at pre≈øent it ≈øeems that the dey is entitled to any number he thinks proper to make choice of, who are generally employed in menial offices about the palace. The remainder of the ≈ølaves are ≈øent into the ≈øervice of the public; but if they can procure a little mo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ey from their friends, or borrow any of the Jews upon exorbitant intere≈øt, they are permitted to keep ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
verns, they paying to the dey a certain duty in proportion to the wine they ≈øell; and notwith≈øtanding this intere≈øt and duty, many have managed ≈øo well as to rai≈øe money enough to purcha≈øe their liberty, and to carry away a quantity be≈øides: for they are allowed a property in what they get. To the≈øe taverns re≈øort Turks, Moors, and Chri≈øtians promi≈øcuou≈øly. But a Mu≈ø≈øulman would not keep one of the≈øe taverns for the world him≈øelf, and con≈øequently they are kept by Chri≈øtians and Jews. to pay their reckoning; and herein he is protected by the dey him≈øelf.

The condition of tho≈øe who are ≈ølaves to private individuals, depends very much upon the di≈øpo≈øition of their ma≈øter, and the ≈ølaves' own conduct. Some of them fare better in Algiers, than ever they did in their own countries, and if they are good for any thing, are entertained rather as companions than ≈øervants; though by far the greater number are barbarous ma≈øters, who treat their ≈ølaves with great cruelty, and per≈øons of quality, or tho≈øe who are ≈øu≈øpected to be in affluent circum≈øtances, experience a greater ≈øeverity of treatment, in order that they may be compelled to redeem them≈øelves at an extraordinary price. They neither force nor tempt any of the Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves to change their religion; as it is not their intere≈øt that they ≈øhould be made converts: for in that ca≈øe they lo≈øe the benefit of their ran≈øoms. The Chri≈øtians who are free, generally fare wor≈øe than the ≈ølaves; becau≈øe the imperious Turks make it a point to in≈øult and abu≈øe them; but they dare not abu≈øe the ≈ølaves, becau≈øe their ma≈øters will re≈øent it and demand ≈øatisfaction.

Tho≈øe ≈ølaves who are ≈øold into the country are ≈øubjected to peculiar hard≈øhips. They are compelled to carry all kinds of burdens to market, and if they do not render a ≈øatisfactory account of the articles entru≈øted to their care, they are ≈øure to be beaten. Some of the≈øe ≈ølaves go naked in the fields where they tend cattle, drag ploughs, and do all other kinds of the mo≈øt ≈øervile drudgery.

Many were formerly con≈øigned to the galleys chained by one leg, and fed on water and hard bi≈øcuit, and beaten with a large cow-≈økin. When they were on ≈øhore they were locked up at night in dungeons called Ma≈ømora, where they lay ‚Ä¢ n the bare earth. But at pre≈øent no ≈ølaves are confined to the galleys, becau≈øe they have ≈øo frequently made their e≈øcape, or murdered their commanders, and ≈øet them≈øelves at liberty.

While the Americans were en≈ølaved in Algiers, the mo≈øt exaggerated accounts were circulated re≈øpecting the ≈øeverity of their afflictions. It was reported that the tongues of ≈øome were cut out, that others were ema≈øculated; and captain Lawrence of the Hull Packet, who is ≈øaid to have obtained his information at Cadiz, informs us that the Americans had their heads ≈øhaved clo≈øe, and were not permitted to wear any kind of covering on their heads. Their calamities were indeed without a parallel, but the above accounts were entirely unfounded.

The greate≈øt ≈øeverity of their toils con≈øi≈øted in the removal of the fragments of rocks from Bubly-white, as before mentionedPage 75.. It has been found by repeated experiments, that the larger the≈øe ≈øtones, the more effectually they re≈øi≈øt the impetuo≈øity of the ≈øea, and con≈øequently the great art of the ≈ølaves who are appointed to blow them, con≈øi≈øts in boring them in ≈øuch a manner that an explo≈øion of gun-powder will ≈øever the large≈øt ma≈ø≈øes po≈ø≈øible: ≈øo that the holes which are bored into the rock ≈øometimes extend to the depth of twenty feet. Round the≈øe huge fragments they la≈øh ropes,
or rather cables, of ≈øufficient ≈øtrength to drag them, and three or four hundred ≈ølaves, and ≈øometimes a greater number, are engaged in rolling one of the≈øe ≈øtones upon a carette, or ≈øtrong four wheel carriage, in order to tran≈øport it to the mole.

The Turks make the mo≈øt a≈øtoni≈øhing noi≈øe, not only in the removal of the≈øe ≈øtones, but in moving any weight whatever which requires a number of hands. They ≈øeem to imagine that the greater their vociferation, the greater will be the exertions of the ≈ølaves or labourers; it is immaterial how ≈ølowly the work proceeds, provided there is ≈øufficient noi≈øe, and the cry of Hyomoly, or heave away, is often heard at the di≈øtance of more than a league.

When they have launched the≈øe unweildy ma≈ø≈øes of ≈øtone upon the carriages, the cables are fixed to them, and four files of ≈ølaves are compelled, like ≈øo many bea≈øts of burden, to drag them from the mountain to the city. In their pa≈ø≈øage they are obliged to a≈øcend a ≈øteep hill, where their utmo≈øt efforts are ≈øometimes in≈øufficient to drag the enormous weight. Thus many become perfectly exhau≈øted with their toils; and to complete the climax of their ≈øufferings, their brutal over≈øeers, the wardens, ≈øcourge them for the lea≈øt remi≈ø≈øne≈øs with the mo≈øt ≈øavage ≈øeverity.

When they have a≈øcended the hill, it is nece≈ø≈øary to rever≈øe the ropes, and their utmo≈øt efforts are then required to prevent the carette from de≈øcending
the hill with the greate≈øt rapidity. Thus, after great labour and difficulty, they tran≈øport the≈øe ≈øtones to the wharf, where the pantoons are moored, which is about a league from the mountain, and a ≈øtone's throw from the walls of the city. Here they depo≈øit them, and by means of pulleys and a kind of ≈øleds, which de≈øcend upon gr ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d pieces of timber, they di≈øcharge them into the pantoons, which convey them to the mole.

The≈øe pantoons are nece≈ø≈øary, becau≈øe the narrowne≈øs of the ≈øtreets renders the pa≈ø≈øage of the≈øe huge ≈øtones through the city impracticable. They are a ≈øpecies of large flat bottomed boats, that cover about as much water as a ≈øeventy-four gun ≈øhip. They have low gunwhales, and long pieces of timber are nailed acro≈øs the deck, to prevent the great pre≈ø≈øure of the ≈øtones from-injuring the planks. Fifty or ≈øixty ≈ølaves are nece≈ø≈øary to man them, and by means of the≈øe cables and anchors, which are continually carried a-head as occa≈øion requires, they warp the pantoons to the mole. In their pa≈ø≈øage they are ≈øometimes ≈øubjected to great danger from ≈øudden ≈øqualls of wind, which either blow them out to ≈øea, or wreck them on the ≈øhore. When this happens the greate≈øt bu≈øtle imaginable en≈øues, and the clamour of the Turks is ≈øuch, that one would ≈øuppo≈øe that the city it≈øelf was upon the verge of de≈øtruction. Thus have the fooli≈øh Turks continued this fruitle≈øs labour for upwards of 250 years, without having conceived the project of forming a wall of ≈øufficient ≈øtrength to defend the mole from the violence, of the waves; but it is ≈øaid that the dey has now ≈øuch a project in contemplation, which he intends ≈øhortly to put in execution.

The impetuo≈øity of the ≈øea has a continual tendency to bury the≈øe ≈øtones in the ≈øand. Many ≈ølaves are employed at other places in the country. Some at a mountain called Bubazoon, ≈øome at the gardens of different con≈øuls, who re≈øide in the country, and others in the marine. But on Fridays they are ordered to Bublywhite, where the vickelhadge and warden ba≈øhaws attend, and where, on tho≈øe days, there is a general collection of all the ≈ølaves.

After they fini≈øh their daily‚ñ™ labour they all repair to town to their common lodgings the bagnios, where they are locked up every night, and prohibited all intercour≈øe with the citizens. The private ≈ølaves are not, however, deprived of this privilege, and they
are permitted to walk the ≈øtreets at night, provided they conform to the common cu≈øtom of carrying a light with them, without which every per≈øon is ≈øubject to being arre≈øted by the watchmen of the city, and to cha≈øti≈øement by the ba≈øtinado.

In the bagnios, the chief aim of the ≈ølaves is to drown the reflection of their abject ≈øituation by the mo≈øt cheerful conver≈øation. The principal ≈øtudy of the more humorous Americans, was to di≈øpel the gloom of their companions and to excite one another to laughter by ludicrous and ≈øatirical remarks upon their ≈øituation. Some of them played upon the violin, and frequently after the toils of the day, they would divert them≈øelves all night by dancing, drinking and ≈øinging, in order to bani≈øh the reflection of ≈ølavery. In their frolics they were often very clamorous, and interrupted the repo≈øe of the whole bagnio; at which time ≈øome of the ≈ølaves would often lodge complaints again≈øt them, and the corporal would then put an end to the frolic by ordering them to retire to re≈øt.

The ≈ølaves are let out of the bagnios at an early hour in the morning, and they proceed to their labour with pen≈øive hearts and reluctant ≈øteps. When they are employed in the marine they repair every morning ‚Ä¢ o a place near the gate of Babazira, which opens to the harbour, where they are paraded in files along the platforms of the hou≈øes on each ≈øide of the ≈øtreet. Here they wait the arrival of the vickelhadge, who ≈øoon makes his appearance, and as he pa≈ø≈øes between them they are compelled to pull off their hats as a token of re≈øpect. After him a proce≈ø≈øion of the
≈ølaves is immediately formed, and as he takes his ≈øeat in the ≈økiff, a trumpet is ≈øounded from the marine. They are then embarked on board the Baleck boats, which are kept for the purpo≈øe, and tran≈øported to the crui≈øers which are ≈øtationed in different parts of the harbour.

The bu≈øine≈øs of the marine is the lea≈øt laborious employment of the ≈ølaves. But even here they are ≈øubjected at times to great hard≈øhips, and e≈øpecially when an expedition is on foot; at which time they are compelled to labour all night in making the nece≈ø≈øary preparations for the crui≈øe. The ≈øhore is illuminated with lamps, and Turki≈øh guards are ≈øtationed on the mole, and in other parts, to prevent their e≈øcape.

Their food con≈øi≈øts of bread, oil, and vinegar. To each per≈øon is di≈øtributed two ≈ømall loaves of about half a pound each, and a jill of oil a day. The≈øe articles are brought to Bublywhite by muleteers, who are daily employed in carrying provi≈øions to the ≈ølaves. The bread is of the mo≈øt indifferent quality, and is made of unboulted meal, ground in mills in the city which are turned by hor≈øes. The general employment of the mul ‚Ä¢
teers, be≈øides carrying provi≈øions to the ≈ølaves, is conveying lime into the city from the lime-kilns in the country, for the purpo≈øes of building and white-wa≈øhing hou≈øes.

All the fick among the ≈ølaves who are incapable of labour are ≈øent to the ho≈øpital oppo≈øite to the Bagnio Baleck, which will accommodate about fifty. This in≈øtitution is ≈øupported at the expence of the Spani≈øh nation, and is under the ≈øuperintendance of a phy≈øician and „Äà‚óä„Äâ Spani≈øh prie≈øts. Here they are well accomm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ted with beds, and furni≈øhed with provi≈øions in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eef and
bread, and medicines are pre≈øcribed according to their ≈øeveral complaints. The upper apartments of this ho≈øpital are occupied by ≈øuch as have the plague, and the lower parts by tho≈øe who are confined with other di≈øorders. It is ≈øaid that the ≈øupport of this ho≈øpital co≈øts the Spani≈øh nation 40,000 dollars per annum, which are annualy tran≈ømitted to Algiers for this benevolent purpo≈øe.

It has been reported that the officers and men of the American ve≈ø≈øels were treated with equal ≈øeverity; but this was a mi≈øtake. Neither the American captains nor mates were ≈øubjected to the labour of the common ≈ølaves; but were employed in the ≈øail-loft in making ≈øails, or in boring pumps for ve≈ø≈øels, and ≈øometimes after lazar in the afternoon they were ≈øent to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in unloading the pantoons. The Americans ≈øupported the be≈øt characters of any ≈ølaves in Algiers, and the mo≈øt of them could always obtain credit in the bagnios for wine and other liquors; a favour that was conferred upon neither Turks nor Moors, of whom the tavern-keepers were always obliged to be extremely watchful; otherwi≈øe they would frequently ≈øteal away without pa ‚Ä¢ ing for the liquors they drank.

div.head: Letter from ≈øundry captive American captains, to colonel David Humphreys, dated Algiers, December 29th, 1793.
div.p: WE the ≈øub≈øcribers, in behalf of our≈øelves and brother ≈øufferers, at pre≈øent captives in this city of human mi≈øery, return you our ≈øincere thanks for your communications of the 29th ult. and for the provi≈øion you have been plea≈øed to allow us, in order to alleviate ≈øomewhat our ≈øufferings in our pre≈øent ≈øituation.

We have drawn up and ≈øigned two petitions, one to the Senate, the other to the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, and we ≈øhall e≈øteem it among the many favors you have rendered us, that you will plea≈øe to forward the≈øe petitions to their re≈øpective addre≈øs, ≈øo that no time may be loft; but that they be laid before the Repre≈øentives of our country, hoping that the United States will fully provide funds for extricating from captivity, and re≈øtore us to our country, families, friends and connections.

We have peru≈øed with ≈øentiments of ≈øatisfaction and approbation, your memorial to the regency of Algiers, and have to ob≈øerve, that its contents fully coincide with our ≈øentiments on this bu≈øine≈øs, which we tru≈øt in the Almighty, will terminate to the honor and intere≈øt of our common country, notwith≈øtanding the in≈øinuations, (of others in this quarter) to the prejudice of the United States.

We tru≈øt, and hope, that the United States will adopt ≈øuch effectual plans, in order to prevent any more of our brethren ≈øharing our unhappy fate, which unavoidably mu≈øt happen, if ≈øome ≈øpeedy and effectual means are not immediately put in execution, as we under≈øtand the Portugue≈øe truce with this regency was agreed on for one year.

What damps our ≈øpirits in ≈øome degree, is, that we are informed that the plague, that fatal and tremendous di≈øorder, has given its awful alarm in the country adjacent. And as your unfortunate countrymen are confined during the night time in the ≈ølave-pri≈øons, with ≈øix hundred captives of other nations, from our crowded ≈øituation we mu≈øt be expo≈øed to this contagious di≈øorder; which nece≈ø≈øitates the ≈øub≈øcribers to intreat you, ≈øir, that in this ca≈øe, tho≈øe our friends, and of influence in this regency, will be authori≈øed by you, and our
honoured countrymen Mr. Carmichael and Mr. Short, to have a hou≈øe taken for the re≈øidence of the American ma≈øters and mates, and, if po≈ø≈øible, the mariners, to ≈øhield them from the threatning ≈øtorm of mortality and danger.

We make no doubt, but in ca≈øe of Almighty's wrath vi≈øiting this city of iniquity, but the dey and regency would acquie≈øce to the propo≈øed plan of humanity, which would be e≈øtabli≈øhing an example for the general welfare of mankind‚Äîand would to po≈øterity be recorded to the immortal honor of the United States.

The ≈øame time, honoured ≈øir, and friend, be you a≈ø≈øured, for your con≈øolation, that we the American captives, in this city of bondage, will bear our ≈øufferings with fortitude and re≈øignation, as becoming a race of men endowed with ≈øuperior ≈øouls in adver≈øity.

We are much indebted to Mon≈øieur Skjoldebrand, and brother, his Swedi≈øh maje≈øty's agents, in this city, for their humanity, and attention to the American captives; and feel our≈øelves particularly obliged to you for recommending us to the good offices of con≈øuls Skjoldebrand, and Mr. Mace, whom you mention to us as friends.
With ≈øentiments of gratitude and the mo≈øt profound re≈øpect, we remain,

div.head: Attempt of fifteen ≈ølaves to e≈øcape.
div.p:
WHILE the American captives were employed at Bublywhite, a ≈øcheme was concerted between fifteen Genoe≈øe, Portugue≈øe, and Neapolitan ≈ølaves, to make their e≈øcape in one of the boats that attend the pantoons. This plot had been in agitation for ≈øeveral weeks, and in the mean time they
had prepared them≈øelves with weapons of defence, and all nece≈ø≈øary articles for their voyage. About nine o'clock one very hot morning, in the time of Ramadan, while Montenegro, the warden of the pantoon, lay a≈øleep, the≈øe fifteen ≈ølaves, at the word of command, jumped into the boat which lay along ≈øide the pantoon, and put to ≈øea in an in≈øtant. The portezero, or boat≈øwain of the pantoon, immediately waked Montenegro, who was a≈øtoni≈øhed beyond mea≈øure when he ≈øaw them under weigh, and hallowed to them in a furious tone of voice to return; upon which one of the Portugue≈øe waved his naked ≈øword in defiance, the crew gave three loud huzzas, and rowed with all their might towards the Spani≈øh coa≈øt. Montenegro, dreading the con≈øequences of this piece of neglect, immediately fled for ≈øafety to the grand mo≈øque which ≈øtands out of the town.

As ≈øoon as the news was announced to the dey, he ordered men to be ≈øtationed on eminences with ≈øpy-gla≈ø≈øes, to ob≈øerve the cour≈øe they ≈øteered; and in the mean time a Spani≈øh built boat, a ≈øwift runner (which is always moored near the ≈øeat of the vichelhadge of the marine to be in readine≈øs upon any particular emergency) was in≈øtantly ordered to pur≈øue them. The vichelhadge manned the boat with a double ‚Ä¢ ire of pi≈øcorees, or rowers, and that they might pur≈øue them with greater expedition he embarked himself. By this time the fugitives were out of ≈øight; but the pi≈øcorees ≈øteered directly towards that part of the ocean where they had di≈øappeared. The vichelhadge, in order to encourage them to greater exertions, frequently threw them money, and they rowed with ≈øuch expedition that about noon they overtook the fugitives, who had ≈øo completely exhau≈øted
them≈øelves in their endeavours to e≈øcape, that they were ≈øcarcely able to move their oars. As ≈øoon as their pur≈øuers had overtaken them they ≈øubmitted without the lea≈øt re≈øi≈øtance, and pa≈ø≈øively re≈øigned them≈øelves to the fury of their pur≈øuers, who beat them mo≈øt unmercifully, and after ≈øecuring them in chains, brought them back to the city, where they arrived about four o'clock in he afternoon. They were immediately taken before the dey, who ordered two of the principals to be executed: and they were accordingly led to the fountain in front of the dey's palace, where they kneeled down, and one of the dey's guards with a ≈øharp tahan ≈øevered their heads from their body.

The dey ob≈øerved, that had a greater number embarked he would not have pretended to have ≈øent in pur≈øuit of them; but he naturally concluded that ≈øo ≈ømall a number would ≈øoon exhau≈øt them≈øelves.

One is apt naturally to arraign their impolicy in taking their departure with ≈øo ≈ømall a number. But we ought to reflect upon the great difficulty and danger of detection in affecting an e≈øcape of this nature; for the very air of the country ≈øeems to in≈øpire the principles of villany and deception; ≈øcarcely any ≈øcheme can be concerted without detection, and there are many mi≈øcreants of ≈ølaves here, who would feel no remor≈øe whatever in betraying their mo≈øt intimate friends for a trifling reward.

div.head: Spani≈øh de≈øperado.
div.p: THE mo≈øt turbulent and intemperate ≈ølaves in Algiers are the Spaniards, who go armed with a dagger or long knife, and a quarrel with each other generally terminates in a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øination.

About ten o'clock one night, after the American ≈ølaves had retired to re≈øt in the Bagnio Gallaro, a violent quarrel happened between two Spaniards, which made ≈øuch an uproar in the bagnio, that one of the corporals, or guardians, entered the room with a lantern in his hand, in order to quell the di≈øturbance; and with his rope he fell to beating the Spaniards mo≈øt unmercifully. One of them, who did not reli≈øh the cha≈øti≈øement very well, de≈øired him to de≈øi≈øt, and threatened to ≈øtab him if he per≈øi≈øted in beating him; which ≈øo irritated the corporal, that he deal ‚Ä¢ out his blows more furiou≈øly than ever. The Spaniard grown outrageous with ≈øuch treatment, drew his dagger and gave him four or five wounds, of which he in≈øtantly expired. By this time the ≈øecond corporal entered the apartment, and as he entered, the de≈øperate Spaniard ru≈øhed furiou≈øly upon him, and in attempting to ward off the blow he received a wound in his arm; upon which he immediately retreated, and locked him≈øelf up in one of the taverns that ≈øtand near the bagnio.

The two Spaniards were now at liberty to decide their di≈øpute, and they ru≈øhed furiou≈øly upon each other with their knives; but the lea≈øt de≈øperate of the two, after receiving ≈øeveral wounds, made his e≈øcape, and left his antagoni≈øt complete ma≈øter of the bagnio. He now paraded the pa≈ø≈øage
flouri≈øhing his dagger, and threatening vengeance to any one who ≈øhould attempt to mole≈øt him. Of five or ≈øix hundred ≈ølaves and others who re≈øided there not one dur≈øt approach him, and he maintained the undi≈øputed po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the pa≈ø≈øage. At this juncture the corporal of the Bagnio Baleck, who was then confined by fickne≈øs in the Spani≈øh ho≈øpital, hallowed to him from his window, and ordered him to put up his knife and go to bed; but the Spaniard, who was little di≈øpo≈øed to obey him, challenged him with the mo≈øt abu≈øive language to come down.

In the mean time intelligence of this uproar was communicated to the warden of the bagnio, who imagined that the whole body of ≈ølaves had broken loo≈øe, and he in≈øtantly came armed and attended by a number of men in order to quell the di≈øturbance. When he arrived at the entrance into the bagnio, he commanded the Spaniard in≈øtantly to ≈øubmit; but he was now grown more furious than ever, and defied the whole city. During this conference one of his own countrymen ≈øtole ≈øoftly up behind him and knocked him down with a club. A number of men then in≈øtantly ≈øeized him, and chained him to the wall, where he remained till the next morning, when he was taken before the dey, where he received ≈øentence of death, and in a few minutes after his head was chopped off in front of the dey's palace.

div.head: Detection of a Neapolitan ≈ølave.
div.p:
A certain Neapolitan who kept a tavern in the ≈øuburbs of the city, was one afternoon di≈øcovered in company with a Mo ‚Ä¢ ri≈øh woman, by ≈øome of the

Several other ≈ølaves who happened to be pre≈øent at the ≈øame time fortunately made their e≈øcape; but the Neapolitan ≈øtood motionle≈øs with the ≈øudden ≈øurprize. The li≈øberos di≈ømounted and in≈øtantly ≈øeized both him and the woman, and immediately carried them before the dey, who in≈øtantly pa≈ø≈øed ≈øentence of death pon them both. Through the interce≈ø≈øion of ≈øome powerful friends the ≈øentence pa≈ø≈øed upon the Neapolitan was remitted; but he totally forfeited the privilege of keeping a tavern, and after receiving 500 ≈øtrokes upon different parts of his body, he was con≈øigned to hard labour among the common ≈ølaves. But the woman, after receiving ≈øentence, was immediately carried to the ≈øea-≈øide by two executioners, who tied a large bomb-≈øhell round one of her legs, and threw her into ≈øhe ≈øea ≈øome di≈øtance from the ≈øhore, in the pre≈øence of the American captives, who were then employed in the marine. She made the mo≈øt lamentable cries, and earne≈øtly entreated her executioners to permit her to take leave of her children; but they were deaf to her entreaties.

Some days after, by ≈øome means or other, the bomb-≈øhell was di≈øengaged from her leg, and ≈øhe floated upon the ≈øurface of the water. But the Algerines were greatly a≈øtoni≈øhed when they found ≈øhe had not been eaten by the fi≈øh; a circum≈øtance ≈øo extremely ≈øingular, that the ≈øuper≈øtitious Algerines regarded it as miraculous, and ≈øhe was in con≈øequence made a marabout, and ever after venerated with a kind of religious enthu≈øia≈øm.

The dey's indignation was ≈øo much excited at the atrocity of this interview, that he decreed that in future all tho≈øe ≈ølaves and Moori≈øh women who
„Äà‚óä‚óä„Äâ detected together, ≈øhould be chained with their backs to each other and burnt.

div.head: Di≈øappointment of the American ≈ølaves.
div.p: SOME time in 1795 an Engli≈øh cutter from Gibralter arrived in Algiers with a number of ≈ømall pieces of bra≈øs cannon, which were purcha≈øed by the dey and carried to his palace. The American ≈ølaves, who were then at work in the marine, ≈øoon recogni≈øed ≈øeveral per≈øons of their former acquaintance among the crew of the cutter. A general intimacy took place, and they ≈øympathi≈øed ≈øo feelingly for the di≈øtre≈øs of the Americans, that a ≈øcheme was concerted among them to effect their deliverance from this region of mi≈øery. The crew deeply intere≈øted them≈øelves in the accompli≈øhment of this project, and communicated their intentions to their captain, who perfectly approved of their plan, and promi≈øed every a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in his power to facilitate their de≈øign.

The ≈øcheme devi≈øed between the parties was as follows: The Americans were to take the advantage of the fir≈øt fair wind, and in either going to, or returning from their labour in the marine, according as the wind ≈øhould favor them, they were to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Baleck boats which tran≈øported them, and in≈øtantly row them≈øelves on board the cutter; which being a very ≈øwift ≈øailing ve≈ø≈øel would ≈øoon have wa≈øted them beyond the reach of their pur≈øuers. The in≈øtant they had boarded the cutter they were to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of her apparently by force, and the Briti≈øh crew were to affect a re≈øi≈øtance, that the dey might entertain no ≈øu≈øpicion of their being privy to the con≈øpiracy.
The cutter was in con≈øequence put into complete order, and the nece≈ø≈øary in≈øtructions were given that they might ca≈øt off and get under weigh in an in≈øtant.

No ≈ølaves were perhaps ever pre≈øented with ≈øo favorable an opportunity as the pre≈øent. But the mo≈øt ≈øingular occurrence imaginable fru≈øtrated the whole ≈øcheme, when it was upon the point of execution.

The captain of the cutter, on the day of their intended departure, went up to one of the bagnios in the city, were he accidentally fell in company with two renegado Iri≈øhmen of his acquaintance, who were dre≈ø≈øed, as u≈øual, in the Turki≈øh habit. It was re≈øolved of cour≈øe to celebrate this unexpected interview with a cour≈øe of wine; and they drank till they were all pretty well intoxicated. While they were in this animated mood they found them≈øelves ≈øo well di≈øpo≈øed for adventures, that one of the renegados made a propo≈øal to vi≈øit ≈øome of the Algerine courtezans, which was immediately acceded to, and our captain, who was not, as may well be ≈øuppo≈øed, over burthened with circum≈øpection, was conducted to a Moori≈øh brothel in the upper parts of the city, where the≈øe Iri≈øhmen had previou≈øly formed an acquaintance. Some of the li≈øberos, who had ≈øu≈øpected their de≈øigns, ≈øecretly watched their motions, and di≈øcovered the retreat of our frolic≈øome adventurers. Soon after their entry the≈øe li≈øberos ru≈øhed into the brothel, and ≈øurpri≈øed our amorous captain and his friends in the height of their mirth. He was in≈øtantly ≈øeized and carried before the dey, who ≈øentenced him to immediate execution; but as he was preparing to receive the reward of his folly, the Briti≈øh con≈øul, who had received intelligence of the

In con≈øequence he was e≈øcorted on board his cutter, which was ordered immediately out of the harbour, and ≈øhe was not even permitted to remain to take in the lea≈øt balla≈øt.

Thus was this ≈øcheme mo≈øt completely defeated by this trivial incident, and the hopes of the Americans entirely fru≈øtrated. When they ≈øaw the departure of the cutter, and were informed of the captain's folly, they were thrown into a ≈øtate of inconceivable de≈øpondency. The mo≈øt fortunate breeze imaginable prevailed when they returned from the marine; but in≈øtead of triumphing in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their liberties, they were obliged to retire to the gloomy cells of the bagnio, to indulge at lei≈øure the poignancy of their reflections.

The≈øe renegados were afterwards bani≈øhed to Tunis; not becau≈øe their intercour≈øe with the Moori≈øh women was prohibited, (for the renegados are not deprived of this privilege) but becau≈øe they had been acce≈ø≈øory to an infraction of the law. div.head: Flight of the Spani≈øh con≈øul.
div.p:
A FEW weeks before the American captives left Algiers the Spani≈øh con≈øul fled to Spain, through apprehen≈øion of a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øination by the Spani≈øh ≈ølaves. A certain muleteer called Yohan, or Spani≈øh John, who was employed in carrying provi≈øions from the

After much intemperate and abu≈øive language the Spaniard drew his knife and murdered him; and after perpetrating this act he fled to the city, determined, as his ca≈øe was de≈øperate, to be revenged upon the Spani≈øh con≈øul and prie≈øts who ≈øuperintended the ho≈øpital, as he imagined them to be the cau≈øe of the detention of the Spani≈øh ≈ølaves in AlgiersMany of the≈øe ≈ølaves are criminals, who fly from ju≈øtice in their own country and become voluntary ≈ølaves in Algiers, whom the Spani≈øh government refu≈øes to ran≈øom; a matter which they impute entirely to the influence of their con≈øul and prie≈øts, whom they ≈øuppo≈øe to be „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of their ≈ølavery, and con≈øequently they are ever „Äà‚óä„Äâ objects of their hatred and indignation..

As ≈øoon as he arrived in town he went to the con≈øul's hou≈øe, who fortunately happened to be ab≈øent, and from thence to the ho≈øpital, with an intention to murder the head prie≈øt, who, he was informed, was likewi≈øe ab≈øent; upon which he went into one of the upper apartments, where he found one of the under prie≈øts, whom he ≈øtabbed in four or five places; and then retired to the Bagnio Gallaro, where he paraded one of the apartments with his bloody knife in a po≈øture of defence.

In the mean time intelligence of the death of the clerk was ≈øent to town; whereupon the warden ba≈øhaw ≈øent one of the chief corporals, to arre≈øt the murderer, and to take him before the dey. The corporal

He alleged, that they had appropriated, to their own private purpo≈øes, all the monies that had been ≈øent by the Spani≈øh government for the ran≈øom of the Spaniards, and he a≈ø≈øured the corporal that a con≈øpiracy was formed among the ≈ølaves, and though he had failed, yet others would ≈øucceed in accompli≈øhing their de≈øtruction.

When the exi≈øtence of this con≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cy was announced to the con ‚Ä¢ ul and prie≈øts, they embarked on board a Spani≈øh ve≈ø≈øel in great con≈øternation, and ≈øet ≈øail from Algiers in the height of the plague. Provi≈øions and clothing were furni≈øhed him, and a hut was built for his accommodation, where he was confined till he was adjudged to be out of danger of the infection; after which he arrived in Spain, and thus e≈øcaped the meditated vengeance of the Spani≈øh ≈ølaves. div.head: The Renegado.
div.p: THE renegados are ≈øuch as relinqui≈øh their own religion and embrace the Mahometan faith; but this cla≈øs of men have of late betrayed ≈øo much villany, that they ≈øu≈øtain the mo≈øt indifferent characters of any people in Algiers. This will not appear ≈øingular when we con≈øider that the≈øe apo≈øtates are generally ≈øuch as fly from ju≈øtice in their own country; and be≈øide ‚Ä¢ none but the mo≈øt abandoned Chri≈øtian would renounce his religion for the fallacy of Mahometani≈øm.

It is no wonder then that ≈øo little encouragement ≈øhould be given to this order of men, and though the Mahometan „Äà‚óä„Äâ formerly con≈øidered the conver≈øion of Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves as the mo≈øt meritorious act, yet at pre≈øent it is perhaps totally impracticable for a ≈ølave to change his religion; becau≈øe in ≈øuch ca≈øes the government is deprived both of their labour and the benefit of their ran≈øom.

The pre≈øent number of renegados in Algiers is very ≈ømall. After they are initiated into the profe≈ø≈øion of their new faith, they officiate in the cazarees in the capacity of Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers, and are admitted to the participation of ≈øimilar privileges; but they are prohibited from leaving the kingdom of Algiers under penalty of death, and are never delivered up upon the demand of their nation.

Not long ≈øince the captain of a French priva≈øeer; that had brought an Engli≈øh prize into Algiers, flogged a Genoe≈øe ≈øailor who had been ≈øhipped on board the privateer. The Genoe≈øe in con≈øequence was ≈øo exa≈øperated, that he made his e≈øcape from the ve≈ø≈øel, and went to one of the marabouts with a determination to abjure his religion; to whom he ≈øo exaggerated
the cruelty of the Chri≈øtians, that he was admitted into the order of the prophet.

After a re≈øidence of two months in Algiers an Engli≈øh frigate arrived with di≈øpatches to the Briti≈øh con≈øul, and our renegado, di≈øgu≈øted with his new ≈øituation, and regretting the renunciation of his religion, was re≈øolved to e≈øcape on board the frigate. But after ≈øeveral ineffectual attempts, he was di≈øcovered by the vichelhadge of the marine, with only his handkerchief tied round his middle.
