div.head: The Muleteer.
div.p: THE cellars, or lower apartments of the hou≈øes of the Algerines are converted into ≈øtables, and their hor≈øes and mules pa≈øs through the ≈øame door with the family; and the ≈øame arrangements are made even in the palace, where foreign con≈øuls, agents, vi≈øitors, hor≈øes, mules, a≈ø≈øes and the dey of Algiers, all „Äà‚óä„Äâ through the ≈øame door, where two Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers are ≈øtationed with a red ≈øtaff to guard the pa≈ø≈øage.

Not long before the arrival of the Americans in Algiers, a certain Spani≈øh muleteer, who had been employed in carrying out the dirt of the palace in ba≈økets ≈øu≈øpended at each ≈øide of the mule, by ≈øome means or other had procured a key, by which he could unlock the door of the trea≈øury, which is kept in the palace, where immen≈øe quantities of gold and ≈øilver
are depo≈øited. Whenever this muleteer was ordered to the palace he filled the lower part of his ba≈økets with money, and covered it with dirt; and thus pa≈ø≈øed undetected, till he had by this means ran≈øomed ≈øeveral of his countrymen. But his avarice increa≈øed with his riches; and one day when „Äà‚óä„Äâ was ≈øent to remove the rubbi≈øh of the palace, he ≈øtole into the trea≈øury as u≈øual, and carried away ≈øuch an enormous load, that in pa≈ø≈øing through the court the great weight of the gold bur≈øted the bottom of one of the ba≈økets, and the money ‚Ä¢ ell down upon the marble pavement with ≈øuch a noi≈øe that it re≈øounded through all he palace. A great uproar en≈øued, and the poor muleteer ≈øtood petrified with a≈øtoni≈øhment. The Turki≈øh guards in≈øtantly ≈øeized him and carried him before the dey, where he was ≈øtrictly examined; but he would neither betray his accomplices, nor di≈øcover the place where he had concealed his trea≈øure. His puni≈øhment, as may naturally be ≈øuppo≈øed, was the lo≈øs of his head; and ≈øhortly after his death a part of the money he had purloined was found in the walls of the Bagnio Baleck, and a con≈øiderable quantity was buried without the town, where he had carried the dirt of the palace.

Since this accident the doors of the trea≈øury can only be opened by three keys, which are ≈øeverally kept by the dey, the ca≈ø≈øan-ajee, and the aga, and no money can be taken from thence without their joint attendance.

div.head: Anecdote of an American lad.
div.p:
IT is impo≈ø≈øible to conceive the con≈øternation that always prevails among the ≈ølaves in the palace.
Every one is in continual apprehen≈øion of lo≈øing his life, and when any order is given, it is executed with the greate≈øt terror and expedition imaginable.

Among the number of the dey's ≈øervants were two lads, the one an American and the other a Spaniard, who per≈øonally attended the dey in the upper apartments of the palace, and had the charge of his wardrobe. The Spani≈øh lad, conceiving ≈øome enmity again≈øt the American, concerted a ≈øcheme to be revenged upon him.

One morning the dey, intending to ride out to his country ≈øeat, ordered ≈øhe American lad in a great hurry to bring him a ≈øhirtThe ≈øhirts that are worn by the Algerines are ≈øent from the Levant. They are made of mu≈ølin, and formed ≈øomething like ≈øacks without openings at top, which are made to ≈øuit the convenience of the wearer after they are brought to Algiers.. The lad ran in≈øtantly into the wardrobe, where he met the Spani≈øh boy, who gave him a ≈øhirt without an opening in the top, and he being in too great a hurry to examine it, carried it immediately to the dey, who by this time ≈øtood naked to receive it; but in attempting to put it on, it became ≈øo entangled about his head that he could ≈øcarcely di≈øengage him≈øelf; and apprehending that a con≈øpiracy was formed again≈øt his life, he ≈øcreamed out with the greate≈øt terror imaginable. As ≈øoon as he had di≈øentangled him≈øelf he ≈øeized his tahan, and ran naked out of the room to murder the boy, who fled for refuge into a di≈øtant apartment. The dey hallowed to him with the mo≈øt vengeful tone of voice to return; upon which the boy came before him trembling and
terrified half to death, entirely ignorant of the cau≈øe that had ≈øo much excited the dey's indignation. By this time his pa≈ø≈øion had a little ≈øub≈øided, and in≈øtead of murdering the boy, he beat him ≈øo unmercifully with a rope, that it was nece≈ø≈øary to convey him to the ho≈øpital, where he was confined for a week; after which he was employed in the lower apartments of the palace among the inferior cla≈ø≈øe ‚Ä¢ of ≈øervants.

div.head: An expedition to gather cane.
div.p: ONCE in every year all the ≈ølaves are ordered into the country to cut cane, which generally happens on the fir≈øt Friday in January, and this cane is u≈øed for the purpo≈øe of lathing their hou≈øes.

The 3d of January 1794, was the fir≈øt time that the American captives went out upon one of the≈øe cane‚ñ™ gathering expeditions. The part of the country to which they were ordered, lies about a league beyond the gate of Bubazoon. Here they traver≈øed a number of cane fields without any permi≈ø≈øion from the owners, and each ≈ølave, after having collected two bundles as large as he could carry, repaired with them to a particular enclo≈øure, which was appointed as the place of general rendezvous, where the vichelhadge of the marine, the warden ba≈øhaw, and other wardens attended on hor≈øeback. An entertainment was provided at the expence of the ≈øcrivan grandee, or head clerk of the dey, and the warden‚ñ™ ba≈øhaw obliged the tavern keepers to ≈øend a ≈øupply of wine for the occa≈øion. All provi≈øions, wines, and other articles nece≈ø≈øary for the entertainment, were brought out by the muleteers in ba≈økets. Upon a part of the enclo≈øure ≈øeparate from the ≈ølaves,
the vichelhadge, the warden ba≈øhaw, and the other wardens ≈øat cro≈øs legged upon napkins, and their food was ≈øerved up to them in earthern plates, which were placed upon the ground before them. After regaling them≈øelves, a ≈øervant poured water upon their hands and they retired; and the ≈ølaves were then permitted to take their ≈øeats upon a different part of the enclo≈øure, where a number of wooden bowls were placed, filled with vinegar and oil, in which they ≈øoaked their bread, and with this ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r≈øe diet fini≈øhed their repa≈øt. After this the muleteer di≈øtributed the wine among them, without any kind of order. All tho≈øe who had neglected to provide them≈øelves with ve≈ø≈øels, received no ≈øhare, which was the misfortune of the Americans; but the old ≈ølaves took care to ‚Ä¢ urni≈øh them≈øelves with a number of horns and bottles for the occa≈øion.

This fea≈øt terminated at the ≈øound of a trumpet. All the ≈ølaves then ≈øhouldered their bundles, and marched in files up to the gardens of the aga and ca≈ø≈øan-ajee, which were upon the top of a high mountain, where they depo≈øited at each garden about 50 or 60 of the≈øe bundles, and the remainder were taken to the dey's gardens, which lie, at the di≈øtance of about three miles, upon another quarter of the town; from whence they repaired to the bagnios, and thus terminated the labour of the day.

div.head: Di≈øtribution of clothing.
div.p:
The Friday immediately ≈øucceeding this expetion was the day appointed for di≈øtributing clothing to the ≈ølaves, which happens only once in every year. It is a day of general fe≈øtivity, and all the ≈ølaves are exempted from labour. Early in the
morning on this day, they were drawn up in two files in a court adjoining the palace, where the vichelhadge, and a number of his attendants ≈øerved out to each ≈ølave in order a ≈øuit of clothes in the Turki≈øh fa≈øhion, rolled up in a ≈ømall bundle. This ≈øuit con≈øi≈øted of a pair of ≈øhort woolen trow≈ø ‚Ä¢ rs, and a jacket ≈øomewhat in the form of a ≈øack, without either buttons or ≈øleeves; a coar≈øe linen ≈øhirt with ≈øhort ≈øleeves, and a pair of pan ‚Ä¢ poo≈øes, or ≈øhoes made of yellow leather. During the di≈øtribution, the dey pre≈øented him≈øelf from an upper apartment, and looked down upon them with a ≈øteadfa≈øt countenance, and without the lea≈øt change of po≈øture during „Äà‚óä„Äâ whole time. As ≈øoon as they were withdrawn from the court, great numbers of Jewi≈øh and Moori≈øh chapman appeared, to whom many of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øold their whole ≈øuit for le≈øs than a ≈øequin, in „Äà‚óä„Äâ to rai≈øe a little money for the purpo≈øe of celebrating the day. Thus would many of the≈øe poor wretches, for the ≈øake of a momentary gratification, go nearly naked all the year, and tru≈øt to the genero≈øity of others for a ≈øupply.

div.head: The Americans bound in chains.
div.p: THOUGH Mr. Barlow was highly e≈øteemed by the Amercan captives for his benevolence, affability, and unremitted exertions to procure their freedom, yet it ≈øeems that Mr. Donald≈øon, who was of an an≈øtere di≈øpo≈øition, was not equally the object of their e≈øteem; and an occurrence took place that procured him the irreconcileable hatred of all the American captives.

After he had re≈øided nearly nine months in Algiers, waiting for the nece≈ø≈øary ≈øums to carry the treaty into effect, the Americans, who had become
extremely impatient at the delays, waited upon him one morning in a body, and reque≈øted a definitive an≈øwer, whether there was any expectation that they would ever be relea≈øed from ≈ølavery? But in≈øtead of deigning an affable reply to a ≈øet of men grown frantic with their misfortunes and the gloomy anticipation of being en≈ølaved for life, after fo≈øtering the plea≈øing hope of a ≈øpeedy deliverance, he bade them, in an imperious tone of voice, to begone immediately from his lodgings, or he would find means to compel them.

Irritated by ≈øuch hauteur of conduct in the American agent, they became very turbulent, and an≈øwered him, that they would not depart till they had received ≈øome information upon the ≈øubject. But Mr. Donald≈øon, was not to be intimidated into an explanation, and lodged information in the marine of the proceedings of the Americans, who immediately di≈øper≈øed; and in con≈øequence of ≈øuch conduct in an irritable agent, they were loaded with heavy chains for the ≈øpace of three weeks; till the Swedi≈øh con≈øul's brother, who was actuated by a little more humanity, interceded in their behalf, and procured their relea≈øe.

Thus we often meet with men who≈øe hearts are ≈øo delicately impre≈ø≈øed with the ≈øofter dictates of philanthropy, that they are ever ready to extend their benevolence to all mankind; while others, without the lea≈øt emotion, would ≈øubject their own countrymen to chains and mi≈øery. But we may ob≈øerve perhaps by way of apology, that Mr. Donald≈øon's frequent indi≈øpo≈øition might have been ‚Ä¢ he cau≈øe of his petulancy towards his countrymen. At his arrival in Algiers he was ≈øo much afflicted with the gout that he was obliged to be ≈øupported
as he walked, and was ≈øubject to other infirmities during his re≈øidence there.

div.head: Succe≈ø≈øion of Vichelhadges.
div.p: THE vichelhadge of the marine who pre≈øided previous to the arrival of the Americans, was ≈øent to the Levant with a con≈øiderable quantity of money, to build a mo≈øque in honor of the dey. But the ve≈ø≈øel in which he ≈øailed was never heard „Äà‚óä„Äâ afterwards, and it was ≈øuppo≈øed that this trea≈øure had tempted the crew to murder him.

After his departure the Baleck Ba≈øhaw officiated in his place, till the dey lo≈øing all hopes of his return, elected one of his relations to this office, who had lately come from the Levant with a new frigate as a pre≈øent to him. In con≈øequence of this election, the Spani≈øh con≈øul, who occupied the hou≈øe of the former vichelhadge after his ab≈øence, re≈øigned it to the new vichelhadge, and it was repaired for his reception.

While ≈øome of the Moori≈øh ma≈øons were engagaged in removing the old pavement in one of the lower apartments, they di≈øcovered a che≈øt of money, containing ≈øeveral thou≈øand dollars, ≈øuppo≈øed to have been depo≈øited there by Cedelli, a former vichelhadge. This che≈øt the≈øe very hone≈øt Moors conveyed to the dey, who ≈øtill entertained ≈øo ≈øtrong an enmity again≈øt Cedelli, that he refu≈øed to accept any thing belonging to him; but i≈ø≈øued orders that it ≈øhould be di≈øtributed among the officers of the marine, the Moori≈øh carpenters, and the ≈ølaves.

The new vichelhadge re≈øembled none of his predece≈ø≈øors in ferocity of di≈øpo≈øition. He was a man
of great ≈øen≈øibility, and ≈øo little calculated for this boi≈øterous employment, that he re≈øigned his office within a month after his election; and another vichelhadge was cho≈øen ≈øhortly after the Americans left Algiers.

div.head: Anecdote of an American black.
div.p: IT is cu≈øtomary whenever the ≈ølaves have fini≈øhed the careening of the cruizers, to fire three guns from one of the ca≈øtles, as a ≈øignal for her to take in her balla≈øt, guns, and other nece≈ø≈øary articles for a crui≈øe. At this time the vichelhadge of the ve≈ø≈øel, at the captain's expence, prepares an entertainment for the ≈ølaves. A quantity of rice, ma≈øhed wheat, and three or four ≈øheep are boiled together in a large copper kettle on the mole. The mutton is generally di≈øtributed among the Moori≈øh carpenters and caulkers, and the kettle with the cuzcuz is then taken on board the ve≈ø≈øel, where it is ≈øerved out to the Moors and ≈ølaves with a long iron ladle.

One day, after careening a ve≈ø≈øel and bringing the kettle aboard, a great number of the Moors and ≈ølaves thronged round to receive their ≈øhare, and among the re≈øt an American black named Scipio. While a general competition for being ≈øerved fir≈øt prevailed, one of the Americans took Scipio by the heels, and pitched him head foremo≈øt into the kettle, where he remained till one of the Moors dragged him out. A great laughter ≈øucceeded, and poor Scipio received no other injury than that of being well whi ‚Ä¢ e wa≈øhed with cuzcuz. div.head: Spani≈øh de≈øerter.
div.p: A SPANIARD, by the name of Mooris, who de≈øerted from a Spani≈øh ve≈ø≈øel at Oran, was brought to Algiers by the Moors, where he was made a ≈ølave, till the Spani≈øh con≈øul interceded for him and procured his liberty. He received him into his hou≈øe, where he was well treated, and promi≈øed that he ≈øhould return to Spain by the fir≈øt ve≈ø≈øel that arrived at Algiers. But the Spaniard, neither actuated by gratitude for the favors conferred upon him, nor a de≈øire to return home, ≈øtole one of the con≈øul's ho ‚Ä¢ ≈øes and a con≈øiderable ≈øum of money, and with this booty he took his departure into the mountains among the Moors, where he remained ≈øome months, till his money was all expended; after which they brought him to town and took him before the dey, who ≈øentenced him to receive ≈øeveral hundred blows; and the was then appointed to the office of buffidore, or bellows-blower in the black≈ømith's ≈øhop on the mole, where he continued till the plague in 1796 relea≈øed him from bondage.

div.head: The effects of jealou≈øy.
div.p:
No people in the world are addicted to ≈øuch intemperate jealou≈øy as the Turks, and this will not appear ≈øingular when we con≈øider that all intercour≈øe between the ≈øexes is prohibited before marriage; hence it rarely happens that a woman obtains the object of her affections, and a Turk when he finds him≈øelf unable to excite the e≈øteem, becomes more cautious in ≈øecuring the per≈øon of his wife; but all this rigour ≈øerves only as a ≈øtimulus to incontinence, and in
con≈øequence the ≈øpirit of intrigue is ≈øo prevalent among the women, that frequently in the ab≈øence of their hu≈øbands, they ≈øend their confidants into the ≈øtreets to invite ≈øtrangers into their hou≈øes, for the purpo≈øe of indulging an illicit love.

One of the wives of the captain of the port, or agent in the marine, who pre≈øided previous to the arrival of the Americans, happened to fall in love with a young Couloly, whom ≈øhe frequently ≈øaw pa≈ø≈øing and repa≈ø≈øing in the ≈øtreets. As the Turk was engaged the principal part of the day in the marine, it afforded the Couloly a mo≈øt favorable opportunity for frequent interviews, and he continued this amorous corre≈øpondence, till ≈øome intimation of it was whi≈øpered to the hu≈øband, who hired two Moori≈øh ≈øpies, to keep watch near his hou≈øe in his ab≈øence.

After continuing their watch a few hours the Couloly made his appearance, and entered the hou≈øe; upon which intelligence was immediately conveyed to the Turk, who ha≈øtened with all expedition from the marine, boiling with revenge again≈øt his rival, whom he detected in the pa≈ø≈øage of his hou≈øe. An immediate conflict en≈øued, and the Couloly, after receiving ≈øeveral flight wounds, made his e≈øcape. The Turk then ≈øeized his wife by the neck, and as an expiation for the crime of which he had ≈øuppo≈øed her guilty, he choaked her to death.

When the dey received intelligence of this tran≈øaction he in≈øtituted a ≈øtrict enquiry into the matter. He acknowledged the right of the Turks to put their wives to death; they being con≈øidered as merely the property of their hu≈øbands; but when it appeared, upon examination, that the woman
was in a ≈øtate of pregnancy at her death, he was violently enraged, and ob≈øerved, that though the Turk might exerci≈øe this privilege with impunity upon his wife, yet he had no power whatever over the life of the infant. In con≈øequence of this crime he was excluded from his office; but he was afterwards promoted to the command of a crui≈øer, by whom captain M'Shane and his crew were captured.

div.head: Neapolitan con≈øpiracy.
div.p: The ≈ølaves of Algiers are generally Spaniards, Portugue≈øe, Genoe≈øe, Neapolitans and others, who≈øe nations are at war with this regency. Some of the≈øe ≈ølaves have been confined 40 years in Algiers, where they have endured every calamity that can be inflicted on human nature.

About 40 years ago a ≈øcheme was concerted between about 50 Neapolitans and 150 Turks, to make their e≈øcape to Algiers, where they ≈øuppo≈øed they would be highly rewarded for effecting the deliverance of ≈øuch a number of Turks. Accordingly after murdering the officers and crew, and taking po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a Neapolitan galley, they ≈øet ≈øail and arrived ≈øafely in Algiers, where they were for ≈øome time highly care≈ø≈øed by the Turks, till the king of Naples ≈øent to the dey, and de≈øired that he might make ≈ølaves of them. This reque≈øt was readily complied with, and ≈øome of the≈øe wretched Neapolitans are ≈øtill ≈ølaves in Algiers.

div.head: Avarice of the former dey.
div.p: The former dey of Algiers, who≈øe name, if I mi≈øtake not, was Mahomet Ba≈øhaw, was the mo≈øt mi≈øerly dey that ever reigned. It is ≈øaid that his avarice increa≈øed with his „Äà‚óä„Äâ to ≈øuch a degree, that he would amu≈øe him≈øelf in hunting for a≈øpersAn a≈øper is a ≈ømall thin piece of ≈øquare tin le≈øs than a penny in value. in the ≈øtreets, which he would take up on the ends of his fingers moi≈øtened with ≈øpittle.

In changing his clothes one day, „Äà‚óä„Äâ happened to leave a few of the≈øe a≈øpers in his apartment, which the captain ProorThe captain Proor is the head ≈øweeper, and according to cu≈øtom he is always ≈øet at liberty whenever a peace is concluded with any nation. of the palace took the liberty of converting to his own u≈øe, not ≈øuppo≈øing that ≈øo trifling a ≈øum belonged to the ≈øovereign of Algiers. But the dey was greatly exa≈øperated when he mi≈ø≈øed his a≈øpers, and upon examination it was found that they had been purloined by the captain Proor, who in con≈øequence lo≈øt his head.

div.head: Naval expeditions.
div.p:
SHORTLY after captain O'Brien's arrival in Algiers, one James H ‚Ä¢ ll, belonging to his crew, who was an expert „Äà‚óä„Äâ , was rai≈øed to the office of portezero, or boat≈øwai ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a crui≈øer, formerly a French frigate, which went out upon a crui≈øe again≈øt the Neapolitans.
apolitans. Great prepar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ons had been made, and the dey promi≈øed him≈øelf great ≈øucce≈øs in this expedition, in which his whole fleet ≈øet ≈øail. Some days after they left Algiers the frigate fell in with a Neapolitan crui≈øer, and a ≈ømart engagement en≈øued, in which the frigate ≈øoon ≈øtruck to the Neapolitans. An Algerine xebeck which happened to be in company, ≈øheared off when ≈øhe ≈øaw the fate of the frigate. The Neapolitans did not think proper to pur≈øue her; but after taking out all the be≈øt hands, from the frigate, and putting them on board their own „Äà‚óä„Äâ , they ≈øtood in for Naples with their prize. Towards evening they became nearly becalmed, and the Algerine xebeck in con≈øequence deemed this a favorable opportunity for recovering the frigate. Accordingly the crew were ordered to their oars, and ≈øhe immediately bore down upon the prize: upon which the men who had charge of her, finding they were in danger of being overhauled, took to their boats, after ≈øetting fire to a match by which they intended to blow her up; but ≈øome of the old Moors who were left on board, broke loo≈øe from their confinement, and prevented the explo≈øion; ≈øoon after which ≈øhe was re-captured by the xebeck, and carried into Bona for the purpo≈øe of receiving the nece≈ø≈øary repairs.

Though the Neapolitans by this unfortunate event lo≈øt the frigate, yet they ≈øecured the crew, and carried them to Naples where they were made ≈ølaves. After the return of the xebeck, Mr. Donald≈øon wrote to Naples in Hall's behalf, who was ≈øoon after liberated and entered on board an Engli≈øh frigate.

Upon the return of the Algerine fleet the dey was mo≈øt violently exa≈øperated at the lo≈øs of the Algerine crew; immediate preparations were made
for another expedition, and the crui≈øers were promi≈øed an extraordinary reward for every Neapolitan they ≈øhould take. But after ≈øcouring the Mediterranean for ≈øeveral weeks, they only captured a few Neapolitan and Malte≈øe boats, which were bound to Sicily; the crews of which were carried to Algiers and made ≈ølaves.

div.head: Departure of the Americans from Algiers.
div.p: THE principal part of the Neapolitan ≈ølaves were exchanged for Turks at the time the American captives were ran≈øomed, and embarked with the Americans in the ≈øhip La Fortune, under the command of captain Calder, which was originally de≈øtined for Leghorn.

From the 11th to the 13th of July 1796, they were engaged in making the nece≈ø≈øary preparations for their voyage. The 13th in the evening they hauled out into the harbour, and on the 14th in the morning they prepared to get under weigh. At this time a fre≈øh we≈øterly breeze prevailed, and owing to ≈øome neglect in bracing the yards, the ≈øhip was very near being driven ≈øtern foremo≈øt upon the rocks near Porta Pi≈øcou, which obliged them to let go their anchor immediately; upon which the captain of the port came aboard in a great rage, and ≈øtruck captain Calder ≈øeveral blows; called him a ≈øans ≈øuff ‚Ä¢ eda, and a≈øked him how he dared to get under weigh before he came. The ve≈ø≈øel was then warped up to the mole, and a number of the Moori≈øh guard-boats towed her out of the harbour.

About two hours after they had hoi≈øted ≈øail, one of the Neapolitans was ≈øeized with the plague, and
being apprehen≈øive that the contagion would ≈øpread among the crew, they put about the ≈øhip and ≈øtood in for Algiers, with an intention to land the Neapolitan. As ≈øoon as they had hoi≈øted a ≈øignal a boat came off and took him a≈øhore; but the vichelhadge would not ≈øuffer him to be landed, and ordered him immediately back to the ve≈ø≈øel.

After they had been under weigh about half an hour, the dey, receiving information of what had pa≈ø≈øed, ordered a number of the pi≈øcorees to go in pur≈øuit of her, who ≈øoon after returned and brought back the ≈øick Neapolitan.

But their misfortune, did not terminate here: for the day after another Neapolitan was di≈øcovered to have the plague, of which, he died ≈øhortly after; and the ≈øucceeding day captain Baily was ≈øeized with the di≈øorder, and al≈øo died. The foreca≈øtle of the ve≈ø≈øel was then converted into an ho≈øpital, and two Americans who had had the plague in Algiers were appointed to attend them. Great precautions were then taken to prevent the contagion from ≈øpreading. The crew kept them≈øelves in con≈øtant motion, their clothes were aired and the decks were kept continually wa≈øhed, and by the≈øe means its progre≈øs was effectually checked.

At this time they re≈øolved to alter their cour≈øe; and, as they knew they would not be ≈øuffered to enter the port of Leghorn, they ≈øtood in for Mar≈øeilles, where they were obliged to ride quarantine for 80 days. As ≈øoon as they had performed quarantine all the Neapolitans who had arrived in La Fortune were impri≈øoned, as their nation was then at war with the French republic; but they were ≈øoon after liberated and ≈øent to Naples.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Siccinct account of Algiers in the time of Pinchinin.

div.p: THE city of Algiers has undergone con≈øiderable alterations in the ≈øtate of its fortifications, government, cu≈øtoms, and manners, &c. ≈øince the year 1640, the time of their famous admiral Hal ‚Ä¢ Pinchinin.

The ancient wall of the city ≈øtill remains; but ≈øcarcely any vi≈øible ve≈øtiges exi≈øt of the ditch which extended the whole length of the wall on the land ≈øide. This ditch was about ≈øixteen feet wide, and of a proportionable depth; and ≈øerved as a recepticle for the filth of the city. The inhabitants derived but little advantage from this wall, as no military force was ≈øtationed behind it for the defence of the city.
All the ≈øtreets were chained up at night; except that which extended the whole length of the city from the port of Babloet, between the great mo≈øque and the dey's palace, to the gate of Bubazoon.

The principal part of the garri≈øon was lodged in five large public edifices, with ≈øpacious courts in the middle, which ≈øerved as armories. Each of the≈øe contained about 600 ≈øoldiers, who were ≈øupported at the public expence; each of whom were accommodated with a ≈øeparate apartment. But many of the principal Turks were lodged in large hou≈øes called Fonducas, which belonged to private per≈øons.
The ca≈øtle called Alcazabar was that part of the city which lay to the ≈øouthward, divided by a wall which began at the rampart on the ea≈øt ≈øide, and extended to that on the we≈øt.

About three hundred paces from the ≈øhore ≈øtood a ≈ømall i≈øland, that was joined to the city by a mole which was fini≈øhed in the year 1533, and intended for the protection of ve≈ø≈øels. This mole was carried away by a violent tempe≈øt in the beginning of the year 1662, which occa≈øioned immen≈øe de≈øtruction among the ≈øhipping.

Without the city there were ≈øeveral incon≈øiderable fortre≈ø≈øes; the principal of which was that built by Ha≈ø≈øan Ba≈øhaw in the year 1545 at the place where Charles V. pitched his tent in 1541. This fortre≈øs is ≈øtill in exi≈øtence, and is called the imperial ca≈øtle.

The inhabitants amounted to about 100,000; of which 12,000 were Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers, 30,000 ≈ølaves of various nations, and the remainder citizens of Algiers, who con≈øi≈øted of Moors, More≈øcos, Jews, and ≈øome Chri≈øtian merchants.
The ≈øupreme authority was, as at pre≈øent, ve≈øted in the dey, or, as he was then called, the ba≈øhaw, who was frequently honored with the appellation of Sultan, with which he was highly plea≈øed.

His ≈øituation appears to have been more precarious then than at pre≈øent, and he was in continual apprehen≈øion of mutiny among the Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers; e≈øpecially if their monthly wages were withheld. His principal ≈øtudy, therefore, was to make punctual payments at every new moon, and if he delayed the≈øe payments three hours after they were due, he was in great danger either of being murdered or impri≈øoned.

The dey was obliged to be very circum≈øpect in taking no more than his due proportion of all prizes; for otherwi≈øe he was in danger of immediate execution by an incen≈øed ≈øoldiery; as happened in September 1661, when Ramadan Ba≈øhaw, who then pre≈øided, adjudged to him≈øelf a greater proportion of prize-wheat than was his due. This proceeding cau≈øed an immediate in≈øurrection of the ≈øoldiers, who cut his throat, and ma≈ø≈øacred twenty-eight of the divan, who≈øe bodies were thrown to the dogs in the ≈øtreets. The re≈øt were obliged to make their e≈øcape in a fi≈øhing boat, to avoid the fury of the ≈øoldiers, in which they were afterwards captured by the Malte≈øe and made ≈ølaves.

After the death of Ramadan, another Ba≈øhaw, whom they had impri≈øoned ≈øome years before for neglect in making punctual payments, was brought out and elected to the ≈øovereignty of Algiers, whom they exhorted to a more virtuous conduct in admini≈øtration.

But within three days after, he forgot their injunctions, and meditated nothing but the de≈øtruction of an aga, who had been acce≈ø≈øory to his impri≈øonment. In the execution of this de≈øign he promi≈øed 10,000 patacoonsThe patacoon is a Spani≈øh coin about 84 cents in value. to two ≈øoldiers if they would murder him. With this intention they went to the aga's hou≈øe, and reque≈øted to ≈øpeak with him. But the ≈ølave who came out, ≈øu≈øpecting their intentions by their countenances, an≈øwered that his ma≈øter was not at home.

When intelligence was announced to the aga of the dey's de≈øigns, he urged a complaint to the ≈øoldiers, who ≈øeized him and threw him into a dark dungeon, where he received his food through a ≈ømall hole, and only had room enough to ≈øit down.

The nece≈ø≈øity of punctual payment, often obliged the dey to procure money by every ≈øini≈øter means in his power: even by the violation or mi≈øcon≈øtruction of treaties. And this imperious nece≈ø≈øity induced him to ri≈øk a rupture with Great Britain in 1661, by making prize (contrary to their treaty of peace) of the property and per≈øons of foreigners that had been ≈øhipped on board of Briti≈øh ve≈ø≈øels. In con≈øequence of this infraction of the treaty, the earl of Sandwick was di≈øpatched to Algiers, with a fleet of eighteen ≈øail of the line, to demand re≈øtitution. The admiral entered the harbour the 22d of Augu≈øt, and di≈øpatched his lieutenant with his credentials on ≈øhore to demand ≈øatisfaction, which the dey and divan were not di≈øpo≈øed to grant. In con≈øequence, the Briti≈øh con≈øul was brought on board the fleet, and the admiral, after pouring a volley of grape ≈øhot into the city, and battering down ≈øeveral hou≈øes, took his departure.

The principal ≈øtudy of the dey was the con≈øtant practice of impo≈øition upon nations with whom he was in alliance. Their ve≈ø≈øels were frequently ≈øeized, and the captains con≈øtrained, by corporal puni≈øhment, to confe≈øs that the property belonged to other nations. Indeed it was an arduous ta≈øk for him to avoid foreign di≈øputes, and at the ≈øame time promote harmony at home. He was ≈øen≈øible that the e≈øtabli≈øhment of peace with other nations would have a tendency to abridge his perqui≈øites, and a want of finances to di≈øcharge the nece≈ø≈øary demands, would expo≈øe him to the fury of a mutinous ≈øoldiery. Treaties of peace were therefore nece≈ø≈øarily violated, and as he derived the principal part of his revenue from captured ve≈ø≈øels, he was ≈øeldom at peace with any nation.

The 12,000 men that con≈øtituted his ordinary forces, con≈øi≈øted chiefly of the refu≈øe of Turkey, and of renegados who had fled for refuge from Europe; for Algiers was ≈øuch a perfect a≈øylum for villany, that even tho≈øe who had offended the Grand Signior him≈øelf found protection upon their arrival there, as was the ca≈øe in 1640.

One Sigala, the ≈øon of a Genoe≈øe renegado a famous admiral of the ≈øame name, had been appointed to the command of a ≈øquadron of galleys belonging to the Grand Signior Morad IV. which brought home the annual tribute of Egypt. Sigala on his return anchored his fleet in ≈øome of the ports of Greece, where he went on ≈øhore to devote part of his time to the women. While he was here indulging him≈øelf in every gratification, the Malte≈øe ran into the port, and captured the ve≈ø≈øel which was freighted with the trea≈øure. Sigala, to avoid the bow ≈øtring, ≈øet ≈øail immediately with his galley to Algiers, where he ≈øub≈øi≈øted by piracy till he was pardoned by Ibrahim the ≈øucce≈ø≈øor of Morad.

Algiers was at this time a kind of military republic, and the dey was ≈øo perfectly under the controul of the ≈øoldiery, that without their concurrence he could do nothing. If they approved of his orders they were executed, and if not, the dey was compelled to relinqui≈øh them.

In the year 1642, a tributory king, refu≈øing to pay tribute, appeared with an army to ≈øhake off the Algerine yoke. Yu≈øef, the reigning dey, de≈øirous of being exempted from the command of the expedition, pretended indi≈øpo≈øition. But the ≈øoldiers were not di≈øpo≈øed to receive his excu≈øe, and compelled him to embark in one of his galleys; and le≈øt he ≈øhould de≈øert them, he was e≈øcorted by another
other galley, and was obliged to ≈øubmit to being di≈øembarked with his army at the place appointed.

At this time there were, according to ≈øome accounts, about three thou≈øand French renegados in Algiers. Before this time the renegados were prohibited from ≈øerving in the capacity of Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers; but Mahomet Ba≈øhaw fir≈øt allowed them to be incorporated with the Turks in 1568.

The pay of each ≈øoldier was eight More≈øco doublesThis double is about 25 cents in value. a month; but their pay was enhanced upon extraordinary emergencies, and in proportion to the number of years they had ≈øerved. Whenever the Sultane≈øs was delivered of a ≈øon, or they had any remarkable engagement with the Arabs, or any ≈øoldier had killed his enemy in an engagement and brought away his head, their pay was augmented a double a month: provided the number of doubles did not exceed forty.
The unmarried ≈øoldiers enjoyed greater privileges than tho≈øe who were married. To the former were di≈øtributed four loaves of bread a day, but to the latter none.

The ≈øoldiers kept no guard in the city; but a watch called Me≈øuart, con≈øi≈øting of twenty-five per≈øons, paraded the ≈øtreets. In the ≈øummer the city was nearly de≈øtitute of a garri≈øon, as the army was then di≈øper≈øed into various parts of the country to enforce the payment of taxes.

The divan were convened twice a week in a gallery of the palace, and con≈øi≈øted of 40 per≈øons. All matters were decided here by a majority; but what was remarkable, the votes were collected before
the debate was clo≈øed. All cau≈øes between the ≈øoldiers were decided in this council, but tho≈øe between the citizens were determined before the chiah, who was the dey's lieutenant.

Though thei ‚Ä¢ fortifications were then, as at pre≈øent, very incon≈øiderable, yet they were a terror to the Europeans; and, according to ≈øome computations, above 600,000 ≈ølaves died in Algiers with the ≈øeverity of their treatment between the years 1536 and 1640.

Though the Algerines were greatly elated „Äà‚óä„Äâ the ≈øignal di≈øa≈øter of Charles „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ they dur≈øt not attribute „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ own valour. Their „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ a marabout or ≈øanton who re≈øided near „Äà‚óä„Äâ city, produced the tempe≈øt that proved the de≈øtruction of the Spani≈øh fleet, by beating the ≈øea with his wand. To the memory of this marabout they „Äà‚óä„Äâ a mo≈øque near the gate of Babloet, where he was interred. The Turks had a great veneration for this place, and pretended that if a Chri≈øtian army ≈øhould ever be≈øiege Algiers again, they would rai≈øe the mo≈øt tremendous tempe≈øt ever known by ca≈øting the bones of this marabout into the ≈øea.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: A compendium of the adventures of Emanuel D'Aranda, containing an account of the treatment of the Algerine ≈ølaves in the time of Pinchinin.

div.p: EMANUEL D'ARANDA was a native of Dunkirk i ‚Ä¢ Flanders, and was a ≈ølave in Algiers for the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of two years. On the fir≈øt of Augu≈øt 1640, he left Madrid, and proceeded by land to St. Seba≈øtian, where he embarked on board an Engli≈øh ve≈ø≈øel, in order to return to his own country, after having vi≈øited various parts of Spain. After being at ≈øea a „Äà‚óä„Äâ days, they di≈øcovered a large ≈øhip bearing down upon them, which proved to be a caravel. The ma≈øter of the Engli≈øh ve≈ø≈øel immediately ordered his ≈øails to be furled up, and alledged for a rea≈øon that it was not cu≈øtomary for an Engli≈øh ve≈ø≈øel to run away at ≈øea. The caravel ≈øoon came within gun ≈øhot, but without hoi≈øting her colours; whereupon it was concluded that ≈øhe was a pirate.

But night coming on both ve≈ø≈øels lay to, waiting the events that were to take place the next morning. The pa≈ø≈øengers of the Engli≈øh ve≈ø≈øel u≈øed every argument in their power to induce the captain to make his e≈øcape; but he was inflexibly determined to maintain his ≈øtation. About ten o'clock next morning two Turki≈øh ve≈ø≈øels hove in ≈øight, and were ≈øoon within gun ≈øhot. In this ≈øituation re≈øi≈øtance was vain. One of the Turki≈øh ve≈ø≈øels hailed her, and ordered her to ≈øtrike her colours; upon which a boat's crew was ≈øent out, who immediately took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion
of the Engli≈øh ve≈ø≈øel, and her crew were ≈øent on board of one of the Turki≈øh ≈øhips, which immediately after ≈øtood for Algiers.

On the eleventh day after their capture, they pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øtreights of Gibralter, where the Turks, as they pa≈ø≈øed, ob≈øerved many ≈øuper≈øtitious ceremonies. Among a variety the following was ob≈øerved; they ca≈øt a ve≈ø≈øel of oil into the ≈øea, which they imagined ≈øwam to a mountain called La montagne des Signes, where a great ≈øanton or ≈øaint re≈øided, who ≈øub≈øi≈øted upon the oil, and in con≈øequence of this gift di≈øpen≈øed various ble≈ø≈øings to them. During the pa≈ø≈øage of the oil, lighted candles were placed upon the great guns (a ceremony that was particularly ob≈øerved by ve≈ø≈øels that pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øtreights in the night) which burnt for the purpo≈øe of affording light to the oil in its pa≈ø≈øage. All the≈øe ceremonies were performed with prayers and great devotion.

The third day after pa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtreights, they anchored oppo≈øite the city of Algiers; the guns of the ve≈ø≈øel were fired, and their report brought a large concour≈øe of people to the ≈øhore. D'Aranda with the re≈øt of the crew were now freed from their chains, and taken to the market where the Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves were ≈øold, in order to ≈øee if any of them were known; from thence they were conducted to the palace of the dey, (who was entitled to every eighth pri≈øoner) that he might make his choice out of the number of captives.

He was ≈øeated in his hall of audience, and ≈øat cro≈øs-l ‚Ä¢ gged on an elegant ≈øeat, covered with blue tape≈øtry, holding in his hand a number of plumes, re≈øembling a fan. His dre≈øs was a long gown of red ≈øilk, and a turban neatly interwoven.

After the dey had made choice of his ≈øhare of the captives, the remainder were taken to the hou≈øe of
one of the Turks who≈øe ve≈ø≈øel had taken the prize. As D'Aranda was going into the hou≈øe, the Turk a≈øked him in Italian, if he was hungry, he an≈øwered in the affirmative; whereupon a Chri≈øtian ≈ølave brought the pri≈øoners ≈øome bread and a ba≈øket of grapes, with which they regaled them≈øelves. The hou≈øe was built in the Italian manner; the galleries were formed of white marble, and the pavement, the pillars and the arches were well proportioned, according to the laws of architecture. They were confined in this hou≈øe, where they were obliged to ≈øleep on the floor in the galleries, and were not permitted to leave the hou≈øe till they were ≈øold.

After they had been confined here ≈øeven days, they were vi≈øited by Pinchinin and ≈øome of the riche≈øt Turks, who came with an intention to purcha≈øe ≈ølaves. They a≈øked the pri≈øoners whether they were able to pay the price of their ran≈øom; but they an≈øwered in the negative, and in con≈øequence no purcha≈øe was made. They were afterwards brought to the market, where an old man, with a ≈øtaff in his hand, took D'Aranda by the arm, and led him ≈øeveral times round the market-place. A number of per≈øons, de≈øirous of purcha≈øing, appeared, who a≈øked D'Aranda his profe≈ø≈øion and the place of his nativity. They took him by the hand to examine if it was hard; and ordered him to open his mouth, to ≈øee whether his teeth were ≈øufficiently good for chewing hard bi≈økets on board the galleys. They were then all ordered to be ≈øeated in a row. The old man took the fir≈øt in order and led him three or four times round the market, crying arrache, arrache, who offers mo≈øt? After the ≈øale he was placed upon the other ≈øide of the market, and in the ≈øame manner all the others were ≈øold. D'Aranda was purcha≈øed by a renegado
named Saban Gallan, who gave 200 patacoons for him.

The dey being entitled to any ≈ølave at the price offered for him in the market, they were in con≈øequence once more taken to the palace: each one having in his hat a piece of paper, on which was written the price at which he was ≈øold. The dey thought proper to purcha≈øe D'Aranda, and Cal ‚Ä¢ en and Saldens two of his companions; telling ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ em that he had heard they were per≈øons of quality, and that he expected a large ≈øum for their ran≈øom. He then ordered them to the ≈øtables of the palace, where they found 250 other ≈ølaves intended as a ≈øupply to the galleys. In the≈øe ≈øtables they were confined one and twenty days, and their daily allowance here was two ≈ømall loaves of bread a-piece.

Towards the end of September, when their galleys make their la≈øt crui≈øe, the≈øe ≈ølaves began to prepare for ≈øea. To each one was di≈øtributed, by the dey's order, ≈øome coar≈øe cloth, for the purpo≈øe of making them ≈øuch clothes as were worn in the galleys. On the day appointed for the ≈ølaves to go on board, a number of barbers attended the ≈øtables, and ≈øhaved the heads and beards of tho≈øe who were intended as rowers. After they were ≈øhaved, the dey's ≈øteward, and the captain of one of the galleys entered the ≈øtables, and ordered the ≈ølaves into an adjoining court, where each one had his office and ≈øtation a≈ø≈øigned him. After this there remained twenty ≈ølaves more than ≈øufficient to man the galleys. D'Aranda was among this number, and the captain of the galley ≈øaid to the ≈øteward as he pa≈ø≈øed them, We will leave the≈øe ra≈øcals on ≈øhore, for they are ≈øavages yet.

They were then ordered back to the dey's ≈øtables,
and the ≈øame day four galleys thus manned, left the harbour. The dey finding D'Aranda and his companions neither rich nor per≈øons of quality, ordered them to be brought into his pre≈øence in the hall of audience, where they found Pinchinin, who ≈øaid to them, Chri≈øtians I have bought you of the dey, but at a very great price. He then ≈øent them to his hou≈øe, where they found twenty female ≈ølaves who attended his wife, be≈øides twelve male ≈ølaves, and a ≈øeraglio of forty young boys between nine and fifteen years of age.

From Pinchinin's hou≈øe they were ≈øent to his bagnio, the place appointed for ≈øuch of his ≈ølaves as were intended for the galleys. This bangio was a ≈øtreet or large entry i ‚Ä¢ his hou≈øe, where pirates and Turki≈øh ≈øoldiers re≈øorted, who ≈øpent their time in drinking, and the commi≈ø≈øion of the mo≈øt unnatural crimes. D'Aranda not being acquainted with any one in this ≈øeminary of virtue, was obliged to ≈øleep the fir≈øt night upon the terrace of the bagnio, and the next morning when he ro≈øe he ≈øaw an Italian ≈ølave bringing in a great variety of articles and hou≈øehold ≈øtuff, and crying arrache, arrache. D'Aranda enquired of a certain knight of Malta with whom he had become acquainted, what the Italian meant. "As our ma≈øter Pinchinin," replied the knight, allows his ≈ølaves nothing for their ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, the greate≈øt part of them live upon ≈øtealing, and the booty of the preceding day is every morning thus ≈øold for their ≈øupport.

The next morning before ≈øun-ri≈øe the guardian coming into the bagnio, ≈øaluted D'Aranda and his companions with Sur≈øa cani, aba≈øo canalla, get up you dogs, come down you ≈øcoundrels. After this coar≈øe ≈øalutation, he ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ducted them to Babloet, in the ≈øuburbs of the city, where they
were employed in a large rope-walk. D'Aranda and Saldens were appointed to turn a large wheel. Upon their turning the wheel too ≈øwiftly, their guardian cried out to them in Lingua Franca, forti, forti, which ≈øignifies gently; but they mi≈øunder≈øtanding the term, turned the wheel with all their might, which ≈øo exa≈øperated their guardian, that he ran up to them in a rage, and with a huge cudgel taught them the ≈øignification of forti.

After they were thus initiated into the knowledge or rope making, they were compelled to pound wheat in a mortar; a much more laborious employment, in which D'Aranda acquitted him≈øelf but very indifferently; upon which his guardian ≈øaid to him, give over that work you dog, you are too ≈øavage yet. In putting the wheat into bags after it had been pounded, a little happened to be ≈øpilt on the ground; whereupon their guardian ≈øaid, Pilla e≈ø≈øe cani, take that up you dog: but D'Aranda not under≈øtanding him, his keeper gave him a mo≈øt unmerciful blow over the back with a billet of wood, which gave him a dangerous wound, from which a copious ≈øtream of blood i≈ø≈øued.

A very heavy bag of wheat was then placed upon each one's ≈øhoulder, which they had to carry a con≈øiderable di≈øtance, and D'Aranda's ≈øtrength failing him after he had gone a few paces, the bag began to ≈ølide down his back; upon which his keeper ≈øtruck him in the face ≈øeveral times with his fi≈øt, and the blood ≈øtreamed plentifully from his mouth and no≈øe; which compelled him to greater exertions, and he ≈øtaggered under the load till he arrived at Pinchinin's hou≈øe, where he fell down, perfectly exhau≈øted with the burden. But the mo≈øt arduous part of their labour was yet to be performed. They were under the nece≈ø≈øity of carrying
the≈øe bags up into a granary forty feet high; ae ta≈øk which D'Aranda would have found totally impracticable, had not his companion Saldens, who was much ≈øtronger, compa≈ø≈øionately carried it up for him, while he lay upon the ground be≈ømeared with ≈øweat, du≈øt and blood, and ≈øtill unmercifully pounded by his keeper, who threatened to murder him. In this lamentable condition he returned to the bagnio.

In the mean time Caloen, his other companion, had been employed in leading a mule, laden with bi≈øket, from Pinchinin's hou≈øe to the water ≈øide. In con≈øequence of the narrowne≈øs of the ≈øtreets, it was a cu≈øtom in Algiers, when one led a loaded mule or camel, to cry Belec, take care there. But our new mule-driver, ignorant of the cu≈øtom, gave no warning of his approach, and in pa≈ø≈øing, threw a Turk into the mud. The Turk getting up in a great rage, drew his knife, (which they carried about them in≈øtead of a ≈øword) and would have murdered Caloen, had he not been prevented by ≈øome other Turks, who hallowed out to him, don't you ≈øee that Chri≈øtian is a ≈øavage yet, and don't under≈øtand the cu≈øtom; the word SAVAGE being a term of reproach which was given him becau≈øe he was dre≈ø≈øed in a Chri≈øtian habit.

While they were in a ≈øtate of the mo≈øt extreme indigence, expecting nothing from Pinchinin, and not ver≈øed in the art of ≈øtealing, the common profe≈ø≈øion in the bagnio, they had the good fortune to borrow ≈øeventy-five patacoons from an Italian merchant in Algiers, to whom they became jointly bound for the payment of a hundred at Antwerp.

Their next employment was in a vine-yard belonging to one of Pinchinin's country-hou≈øes, where very laborious ta≈øks were a≈ø≈øigned them; for which
D'Aranda, being but indifferently qualified, agreed with his guardian to allow him four rials a month if he would give him a more ea≈øy employment: and in con≈øequence his next bu≈øine≈øs was to carry ≈øome large pots of water to the lodgings of the chief guardian. D'Aranda now fared pretty well, and was much plea≈øed with his new employment; but a trivial occurrence ≈øhortly after excluded him from this bu≈øine≈øs; for as he was pouring a pot of water one day into the Tin ‚Ä¢ ga, or great ci≈øtern, he acco≈øted a Turki≈øh woman who entered the hou≈øe, and a≈øked her if ≈øhe would drink a gla≈øs of ≈øack. This que≈øtion being overheard, he was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed from his employment, and compelled the next day to work with ≈øome other ≈ølaves in attending ma≈øons.

This happened in the month of December, when the cor≈øairs crui≈øed along the coa≈øt of Andalu≈øia, in order to capture Engli≈øh ve≈ø≈øels laden with wine and fruits. The≈øe cor≈øairs had taken a frigate of Dunkirk, in which there was a young man who was ≈øold to Pinchinin, with whom D'Aranda had been formerly acquainted. This young man ≈øhortly after had an interview with D'Aranda, and being moved at the recital of his misfortunes, gave him ≈øome jewels, which he pawned for ten crowns. This was a very ≈øea≈øonable ≈øupply, as his ≈øeventy-five patacoons were by this time ≈øpent, and his credit was in con≈øequence very much rai≈øed at the bagnio, which was more than u≈øually crouded at this time by great numbers of Turks and Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves who came to drink ≈øack, a cargo of which had been lately taken in one their prizes. About thirty ≈ølaves were taken in this frigate who were employed in unloading her. Some of th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe had the good fortune to be afterwards
employed as tavern keepers, a bu≈øine≈øs which was prohibited to Turks; others of the crew were con≈øigned to the galleys, where they were chained to the outermo≈øt oar, men whom the Algerines called Bogavands. The≈øe ≈ølaves con≈øi≈øted of Spanards, Italians and Ru≈ø≈øians, and being a little intoxicated one night a quarrel en≈øued between ≈øome of them, which made a great uproar in the bagnio. The Turks then applied to a Brabant ≈ølave called Francis the ≈øtudent, to examine ≈øome papers which were written in Latin, giving ≈øome account of the ≈ølaves. Francis, upon examination, concluded that D'Aranda and his companions were the per≈øons they were enquiring for, and told them he knew the ≈ølaves very well. Whereupon he went with them to the bagnio, where they found D'Aranda and his companions, whom they informed they were no longer ≈ølaves; at which the were greatly overjoyed.

The next day a Jew came to the bagnio, and by order of Pinchinin's wife, told D'Aranda and his companions that the dey wi≈øhed to ≈øpeak to them. When they were brought before him, he commanded them to go into a ≈ømall drawing room of the palace, where they continued about three hours with ≈øome young Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves. They all excu≈øed them≈øelves; but the ≈øteward not much di≈øpo≈øed to receive their excu≈øes, gave them all a ≈øevere beating, and told them he would come again at night and cut off their ears and no≈øes. They were here confined in this ≈ømall apartment in extreme mi≈øery for eighteen days; during which time they were frequently vi≈øited by the ≈øteward, who always carried his cudgel in his hand, and ≈øometimes beat them for his diver≈øion. The Turks now waited upon Pinchinin, who had returned, and told him they had engaged to procure an exchange of D'Aranda and his companions for ≈øeven of their Turki≈øh friends, who were pri≈øoners in Flanders, and offered him by way of ran≈øom the ≈øame ≈øum he had given for them. But
Pinchinin told them the≈øe ≈ølaves were per≈øons of quality, for each of whom he demanded 6000 patacoons as the price of ran≈øom.

While the Turks were endeavouring to effect an exchange of pri≈øoners nine weeks pa≈ø≈øed away, during which time D'Aranda and his companions were confined in the dey's palace. After much delay the Turks agreed with Pinchinin upon the price of their ran≈øom; upon which they were relea≈øed from confinement, and lodged in the hou≈øe of Cataborn Mu≈øtapha, one of the Turks, who became their new patron. Caloen was ≈øoon after ≈øent in a ve≈ø≈øel bound to Leghorn, in order to procure the liberty of the Turki≈øh pri≈øoners in exchange, according to the agreement made between the≈øe Turks and the friends of D'Aranda and his companions, who detained the Turki≈øh pri≈øoners in Flanders.

D'Aranda ≈øtill continued with Mu≈øtapha, but his re≈øidence here was of ≈øhort duration; for Mu≈øtapha getting drunk one day quarrelled with a Bulcebas, a captain of foot, whom he called a Chri≈øtian. For this offence Mu≈øtapha ≈øuffered impri≈øonment, and by order of the divan received a hundred blows on the back with a cudgel; after which he was compelled to ≈øerve ≈øix months in the field again≈øt king Bennali.

After the departure of Mu≈øtapha, D'Aranda was received into the family of Mahomet Celibi Oiga, where he was employed in the capacity of a ≈øervant. In the mean time Caloen, who was not ≈øo fortunate, was impri≈øoned in the hou≈øe of „Äà‚óä„Äâ grandmother, where he was confined „Äà‚óä‚óä„Äâ
apartment with nearly 80 weight of iron about his legs, and frequently ≈øent into the country, where his keepers were in≈øtructed to torture him with the mo≈øt oppre≈ø≈øive hunger in order to expedite the payment of his ran≈øom.

At the expiration of ≈øix months after D'Aranda had re≈øided at Oiga's hou≈øe, he received a letter from Saldens, dated at Ceuta, who reque≈øted his immediate attendance at Tetuan in the kingdom of Fez, according to contract with the two Turks. This letter contained information that Caloen's father had ab≈øolutely refu≈øed to pay the 700 patacoons that were demanded for his ran≈øom, but made no particular mention of the five Turks who were to be given in exchange for D'Aranda and his companions.

In con≈øequence of this information Mu≈øtapha's grandmother immediately ordered Caloen to be confined with a hundred weight of iron about his legs, in a ≈ømall cellar, where D'Aranda frequently vi≈øited him; and one day while he was with him, the old woman entered the cellar, and a≈øked Caloen if he was willing yet to pay the 700 patacoons. He made no an≈øwer, but laughed at her; which ≈øo greatly enraged the old lady, that ≈øhe ordered D'Aranda to be ≈øeized and loaded with irons in the ≈øame cell, becau≈øe ≈øhe had imputed Caloen's conduct entirely to his advice. Here they remained till the time fixed for the departure of a ve≈ø≈øel de≈øtined for Tetuan, when, by the interce≈ø≈øion of three Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves who intended to embark in this ve≈ø≈øel, they were relea≈øed upon a promi≈øe that her grand≈øon Mu≈øtapha, who was at Ceuta, ≈øhould be liberated in exchange.

About this time (which was the fir≈øt of January 164 ‚Ä¢ ) terminated the fa≈øt of Ramadan, which continued

To this fa≈øt ≈øucceeded the fe≈øtival or Ea≈øter of Ramadan, which continued for eight days, and was celebrated with great pomp and fe≈øtivity. Cavalcades were formed without the city, and feats of hor≈øeman≈øhip were di≈øplayed. The Turki≈øh children were drawn in ≈ømall triumphal chariots, to which Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves were harna≈ø≈øed. On the 14th of January D'Aranda and Caloen, after ≈øettling all preliminaries, embarked with a number of Turks and Chri≈øtian ≈ølaves on board the ve≈ø≈øel bound for Tetuan. On the eighth day after they arrived at Oran, which is about forty leagues from Algiers, and on the twelfth at Treme≈øen, where they lay at anchor three days, and di≈øcharged part of their Moori≈øh crew.

Treme≈øen was formerly a powerful kingdom, to which the dey of Algiers was tributory.
